APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

Sir,—
I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the MUSQUODABAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL at LESTOCK, SASK., Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child:
English name: Emma Victoria Longman
Age: Sept. 11, 1931
Name of Band: Gordon
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: 101 Gordon Band
Father's full name and No.: Michael Longman
Mother's full name and No.: Mary Pelletier
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good
Religion: Roman Catholic
Does applicant speak English? Yes
Previously attended school for years:

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

FORM NO. 1-A 406
R 7724

NOTE—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a gain-earning pupil.

Agent

Pelly Agency.

Kamsack, Sask.
22nd September, 1938.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the St. Philip's Residential School has asked for authority to transfer pupil No. 033 Mary Bryant from his school to the Mugcowequan School. The reasons are need of accommodation for another pupil and at the request of her parents.

Yours truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa,
October 19, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant the Department approves the transfer of Mary Bryant from the St. Philip's Residential School to the Muscowequan Residential School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

J.F.B. Ostrander, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

Division File No.: 

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division: Yorkton
Sub-Division: Melville
Province: Sask.
Date: Oct. 17th, 1938

File References:

Re: Edward LeRat - (Indian) - Runaway Boy, (Juvenile)
Lestock, Saskatchewan.

(ASSISTANCE TO DEPT. OF MINES AND NAT. RESOURCES & INDIAN AFFAIRS)

16-10-38

1. With reference to the above, in the late p.m. of this date Dr. J.M. Newton, Penwood, Sask., called at this office with the above named Indian boy, having picked this boy up on the road between Penwood and Melville.

2. The boy stated that he was from the Cowessess Indian Reserve and that he had been stolen by a man who was driving an automobile and brought up to the Penwood district and thrown out.

3. Contact was immediately made with H.A.W.R McKenzie, Indian Agent, Broadview, Sask., per long distance telephonic communication, and it was arranged that this boy be handed over to him at Grayson, Sask.

4. Pursuant to instructions received from the H.O.O. in charge of this detachment I patrolled per Pol/Car Ford Code No. 1752 to the village of Lestock, whereupon arrival I met Mr. McKenzie. It was noted by Mr. McKenzie that this boy was a runaway boy from the Muscowequan Indian school at Lestock and not the Edward LeRat that he had thought it to be at all. It was learned that there are several of the Indian boys of the Cowessess Indian Reserve bearing this same name. However, this boy is formerly from the Cowessess Indian Reserve, but he had been placed in the Indian school at Lestock sometime during last January, and as a result of further interrogation he admitted that he had run away from the school in question and that his former story was fictitious.

5. In view of the foregoing, the above named was brought back to Melville detachment where he remained overnight.

17-10-38

6. In the a.m. of this date Father George Jeanotte, Principle of the Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., was contacted per long distance telephonic communication and informed about this young Indian boy from his school, and in reply to this, he stated that he would be in Melville as soon as possible to take him back to the school.

7. In the early p.m. of this date the above named was duly handed over to Father George Jeanotte, a receipt being obtained for same which is now on file at this office.

HANDLED OVER

EXP. BROKEN ON F.93

The O.C. Y.S.D.
Yorkton, Sask.
Sir, Forwarded:

Muscow, Sask.
Oct 28th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Application for admission to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School from Edna Wapan, daughter of the late Chas Wapan, #136 Kinistino Band.

Mrs. Wapan is now married to J. Takowisk of the Muscowpetung Band, this Agency and the application forms were sent to me for her signature. I would recommend the admission of this girl to the school.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Booth,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

March 6th,
1939.

Sir,

I enclose herewith, application for admission, in connection with Rita Richard, a Grandchild of William George Richard, No.1 Sandy Bay Band. The Grandfather will not sign the application and the girl is reaching the age where she is running around on the Reserve without control.

The Reverend Principal of the Sandy Bay School tried to keep the girl at school without success, and owing to this, application for admission was never forwarded to the Department.

I beg to suggest that the girl be admitted to Muscowequan school, Father Chagnon concurring with my suggestion.

Will you please advise in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent

Encs.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa,
March 10, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 6th instant the admission of Rita Richard to the Muscowequan residential school is approved.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir:

Sampson Pellitier No.265, Cowessess Band has made application to have his child, Muriel Doreen Pellitier, aged 6 years, who was admitted to the Malappamia I.R. School on compassionate grounds three years ago, discharged.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter 11B R.C.
of the 24th. instant concerning daughter
of Cecile Lerat, I have to advise that her
Treaty Number is 56 and she belongs to

Yours truly,

The Principal,
Muscowequan I.R.School,
Lestock, Sask.

Revd. Sir:

Cecile Lerat had an illegitimate child about 6 years ago which is in treaty in Cowessess Band and has been taken care of by Old Mrs. Joe Lerat. The child is now really more than the old lady can handle and she has asked if it could be put in your school. Will you please advise me if you could take this girl and if so I will apply to Ottawa for permission to admit her to school.

Yours truly,

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.
Punnichy, Sask.
Nov 3 1939.

Dear Sir;

I have the honor to enclose application to admit Rosabelle Lerat to Muscowequan Indian Residential School; this girl is illegitimate daughter of treaty Indian Cecile Lerat #56 Cowesses Band of the Crooked Lake Agency and was brought to the school by her mother and is there now.

Enclosed please find letter dated April 14th last from the Indian Agent at Crooked Lake who asked the principal of the school if he could admit the girl to the school. As Mr. McKenzie is in hospital on sick leave and as I know the circumstances of the child I beg to recommend it be admitted to the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
November 6, 1939.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant you may inform the Principal of the Muscowequan residential school that the admission of Rosabelle Lerat is approved.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into
the MUSCOGEQUAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL Residential School; to remain
therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Department
of Indian Affairs may deem proper:

Indian name of child:
English name Joseph Shajalais
Age 9
Name of Band Fishing Lake
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid 120 Muscogequan Band
Father's full name and No. J.B. Shajalais 120
Mother's full name and No. Mary Ann Quill 120
Parents living or dead Living
State of child's health Good
Religion Roman Catholic
Does applicant speak English? Yes

Previously attended school for years.

This is the grandmother who educated the boy years ago, we know her as Minwayweas, or Quill of Fishing Lake Band. Application is in order.

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

(Signature of Missionary or other Witness)

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

CANADA
Punnichy, Sask.
Sept 22 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that the principal of Muscowequan School has asked if we will admit the following as pupils to his school:

Phyllis Pratt 69 Day Star Band aged 15
Jane Margaret Pratt do do " 13
Dinah Mary Pratt do do " 10
Barbara Pratt do do " 7

These children are Anglicans.

The first two were at one time pupils of Gordon Indian Residential School and were allowed out of that school to attend the day school on their reserve.

Last spring the teacher of Day Star Day School kept the girls in after school until the other children left the yard, the Pratt girls usually ganged up on the others and beat them on the way home. Then the mother came to the school and attacked Mr Torpey, quite a scrap she put up but Mr. Torpey just held her. Then she kept the children home. The father joined the army and is in N.S. or at sea now. The mother wants to put the girls in Muscowequan School for spite I presume.

I am not recommending that this should be done, they will make more trouble at Muscowequan.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

DIVISION FILE No.

DIVISION: Yorkton.
SUB-DIVISION: PUNNICHY.
DETACHMENT: Saskatchewan.
PROVINCE: Saskatchewan.
DATE: Aug. 15th/1941.

File References:
Re: John McDERMOTT & Donald POLSTROM-(Indians)
(Juvenile.) Running away- Lestock, Sask.
PUNNICHY DETACHMENT CASE.

HEADQUARTERS:

13.7.41.
1. With reference to above, in the P.M. of the 15th, inst., we were advised by Mr. Scofield of Lestock that two Indian boys were found wandering in the Village, that they were unknown and would not give any information regarding themselves, it being apparent that they were running away.

2. I had no previous information at this detachment of the absence of any such Indian Boys. In response to the above however, pol-auto G-8003 by in service on other duty, I proceeded by livery suite to Lestock where I found the boys who were handed over to me by Mr. Field.

3. These boys proved to be John McDERMOTT age 6, of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, and Donald POLSTROM, whose parents reside in the Lestock district.

4. I returned the Indian boy- McDERMOTT to the said Indian School and handed him over to Rev. Father Jeanette, his absence had not been noted and it was thought that he was in bed, as he was present at dinner time 6 P.M.

5. In the case of the boy- Donald POLSTROM- I returned this boy to his home and handed him over to his mother- the father of this boy is in the Army, Mrs. Polstrom had missed the boy from home and on my arrival was getting quite alarmed due to his absence.

6. On completing the above duty patrol returned to detachment in same P.M.

HANDED OVER:
EXP/ Shown on P.O.
Aug. 15th/1941.

The O.C.-S.O.P.,
Yorkton Sub-Divn.

Sir-Extra copies forwarded-involving Indians.

(A.S.Bond.) Cpl.
Reg.No.6612.
I/C Detachment.

**CANADA**
Ottawa,
February 3, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your voucher No. 575 amounting to $6.00 covering the cost of accompanying Freddie Joseph from Leask, Sask., to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. We do not appear to have any previous correspondence regarding the placing of this boy in the school mentioned above and before paying the account I would like to know why it was considered advisable to place him in a residential school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter file 121-5-10 dated the 3rd, instant regarding account for Freddie Joseph voucher No. 573 for an amount of $6.00.

This boy is the son of Ernest Joseph of Big River Reserve No. 118; he has been in Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital for a number of years suffering from T.B. of his right foot; he was discharged last summer, but will be a cripple all his life; his father is a trapper and roamer, who is unable to care properly for this boy or see that he gets an education.

It was decided after consulting the General Superintendent Mr. Christianson that the best thing to do would be to put him in a residential school, where he could get an education; the only Catholic school with available space was Muscowequan school at Lestock, Sask. Other schools would not take him in owing to his disability.

The application of admission for this boy will be going forward shortly.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent,
R.S. Davis.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I, Charles Wade, declare that I was present with Mr. Fred Cockerton and did personally hear the children concerned, Rosemary and Muriel Pelletier, declare that they would much rather live in Bangor with Mrs. Rose Pelletier than at the Indian School.

Sgd. Chas. Wade

Postmaster.

We, Rosemary and Muriel Pelletier, do declare that we like living in Bangor better than at the Indian School.

Sgd. Muriel Pelletier X
Rosemary Pelletier X
Waldron, Sask.,
July 14th., 1942.

Mr. L. Chase,

Dear Sir:

I received your letter about the two Pelletier girls, I went to Bangor today, had a talk with my old friend the postmaster, Charlie Wade, in fact it was the Legion boys that put Charlie in as Postmaster. While talking with Mr. Wade, the two girls, Rosemary and Marielle, with their little sister, past by. The little girls were holding hands and laughing, and quite happy. Anyway Mr. Wade called the three girls into the post office and after the girls had got over their shyness, I asked them if they played baseball yet, they said they did but not on the school team yet, then they laughingly told me how they enjoyed themselves at the Bangor Sports, so the girls and I went and had an ice cream cone.

After we were all good and friendly I asked them if they liked Bangor or if they wanted to go back to the Indian school, the girls were sure they wanted to stay here in Bangor, anyway Sir, I can assure you that these children are really happy here. When I spoke to them, they had not been near their stepmother, and the three girls were happy together. They told me their ages, Rosemary is 12 years, a fat face, nice, chunky little girl; Marielle told me she was 8 years, kind of a slim young girl, but smart and quick. I paid particular attention to how the girls were dressed. The three girls were all dressed exactly alike, nice clean white dresses, faces clean, hair brushed nicely, and white ribbon in hair, nice white socks, and a kind of running shoes but new, the stepmother I never saw but her character is excellent, a very well educated woman. You see I expect the population of Bangor is around 100 and they all know me, the same as I know them. The letter with the girls' signature is a kiss for their daddy so if you send it on to him he will know. I asked the girls what grade they were in school, Rosemary said Grade 2. By the way she spoke and answered I thought she was about grade 5. Marielle said she was Grade 1 but seemed smart enough for 3 or 4th grade.

Well, Sir, trusting this will help you out at present and I could let you know later on how things are going if you want the information but Sir when I met the children this afternoon they were three nice happy little girls and by the way, Brother, my wife was along and she says they are happy. Goodbye and best wishes,

Sgd. F. Cockerton.
Dear Sir,

Allow me to draw your attention to my immediate family affair.

At the present time I have two little girls, Rosemary A. Pelletier, aged 11, and Muriel D. Pelletier, age 9, who are at an Indian Boarding School at Lestock, Sask. After the passing away of their mother, I was forced under such circumstances to place them in the hands of another family, incidentally, their own grandfather, but no relation existed between the girls and the supposed grandmother, because she was the second wife to the grandfather. Therefore, she favoured Muriel, the youngest of the two girls, and abused Rosemary and eventually she placed her at Crooked Lake Indian Boarding School and I disapproved of a forced parting of the two girls. I was also not in the position to take them under my guardianship because I was looking for a home just then and employed on a local farm which forced me to consent to Muriel's wishes to be with her sister, Rosemary, at school, there was no other alternative decision for me just then.

In due course I married the now Mrs. Rose A. Pelletier, Banger, Sask., Box 434. Marriage took place June 19th, 1937. She also had a child, Margaret Pelletier. We had good intention of uniting our family, but, unfortunately, the Lestock Indian School management prevented our intentions to materialize, consequently, I began to look to the faults of such school, by looking back on my own experience because I was practically raised in one of them. You might say that I should be glad to have been kept in existence. But I say otherwise, I was brought up at the expense of the government in a semi-civilized manner, while summing up all the expenditure spent on me could have brought me a good education. Ever since I enlisted in the Canadian Army did I realize how urgent education really is and that is one decision I have come to, that these little girls who are at the right age to develop their education as far as their ability will allow, are going to have that privilege and only with your assistance can I achieve any results. I want the girls withdrawn from the school and placed in the hands of my wife, Mrs. Rose Pelletier.

They will also attend the same public school Margaret is attending at the present time.

My wife on previous occasions made attempts to withdraw the little girls from the school but the management refuse to consider to such much as allow them to go home for a visit.

According to recent rumours, I understand that the standard of education as greatly improved by to my estimation I still do not approve of the strict dictatorial system of
maintaining discipline in these schools. Furthermore, my education being financed by the Government paid to the Crooked Lake Indian Boarding School, was not good enough profit for the organization that manage the school, in order to improve this profit, the management harnessed what man-power they can come out of our under-nourished body to the rough and unskilled of the farm, that is to say, in conjunction with the school. If it was a training on a skilled trade I would today greatly appreciate, therefore, with the assistance of your organization to have the two girls of mine discharged from the school I've mentioned can we be able to provide them with an education. I thank you for your kind attention.

Yours truly,

S.G.D. Samson Pelletier.
Dear Sir:

Some time ago Mr. L.J. Chase, Provincial Secretary of the Canadian Legion of the British Empire Service League, forwarded to me a letter he had received from Samson Pelletier, No. 268 of the Cowessess Band, Crooked Lake Agency, regarding his two girls, Rosemary aged 12 and Muriel aged 8, who were born of a previous marriage. At that time these two girls were in residence at the Cowessess Indian Residential School and they were later transferred to the Muscowequan School at Lestock.

I am attaching copy of Samson Pelletier's letter and you will note that he wishes to have the two girls stay with their stepmother, Mrs. Rose A. Pelletier, his present wife who is living at Bangor, Saskatchewan, instead of on the reserve. I presume her home was at Bangor before she married Pelletier. At the present time the two girls are living with her since it is holiday time.

I was talking to Father Jeannotte a short time ago when he was in the office and I showed him the correspondence in this connection. He was of the opinion that the stepmother only wanted the two girls with her in order to get Dependent's allowance for them. This, however, does not seem to be the case because Mr. Chase had the home conditions of this woman investigated at Bangor, and I am attaching copy of a letter he received from Mr. F. Cockerton of Waldron, an ex-service man, together with copy of a statement from Mr. Charles Wade, Postmaster at Bangor, and statement signed by Muriel and Rosemary Pelletier. Evidently this woman enjoys a good reputation in the town where she lives and is capable of looking after the two girls. It also seems that it is the desire of the two girls to live with their stepmother instead of returning to school.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

You will note by the attached.........
You will note by the attached correspondence from Mr. Chase that reference is made to the Cowessess School. This is where the children were in residence first but they were later transferred to the Muscowequan School at Lestock and their names appear on the roll at this school at the present time.

Whatever steps the Department take in the matter I would ask to be advised so that I can inform Mr. Chase accordingly.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
MC/ed General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Ottawa,
July 23, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to Rosemary Pelletier, No. 0254, and Murielle Pelletier, No. 0255, pupils of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

I am inclined to agree with Father Jeannotte that the real reason for the stepmother's wish to have these children with her is to enable her to secure the dependent's allowance. However, if you feel perfectly satisfied that the stepmother is prepared to give the girls a proper home, the Department has no objection to granting their discharge. I feel, however, that before doing so you should again consult Father Jeannotte and, if he has any objections to the discharge, you should write again before approving the discharge.

A review of our files shows that the girls were admitted to the Cowessess School at the ages of three and four. Apparently the father put them in the school as soon as his first wife died so as to be relieved of any responsibility for them. It is rather amusing to see how much interest he is now displaying in them, even though he is not at home to enjoy their company. I feel certain that you will give this matter very careful consideration along the lines suggested in this letter.

Yours truly,

Mr. M. Christianson,
Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg.,
Searth & Victoria,
Regina, Sask.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Bangor Sask.

I am in receipt of a letter from Mrs. Samson Pelletier, Box 434, Bangor, Sask., with reference to the discharge of her stepchildren from the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. This matter is now under review, but it is doubtful if we can see our way clear to allow their discharge.

Regina, August 18, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 121-5-10 of the 20th instant regarding the two Pelletier children being discharged from the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

As directed I have written to the Reverend Father Jeannotte and in reply he has this to say:

"I have no objection at all, that these two Sam. Pelletier's children (Rose Mary and Muriel) would be discharged. The only thing, I regret for is that Sam Pelletier took a wrong way to obtain this discharge by discrediting the Cowessess and Muscowequan Indian Residential Schools."

I shall now await the decision of the Branch in the matter.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

These children were taken in by the principal of Muscowequan School this week and I notified him to return them to their home. He knows he should not admit pupils without permission of the Department, at least he has been told but he may have forgotten. I think you should also tell him again of this ruling unless you have cancelled it.

Regards Harriet Cyr. The principal of Gordons discharged her as her behaviour was so bad, I think she had been instructed by the parents to act up. I would say to leave her out of all our schools at present.

I know if one principal steals pupils on another principal he leaves himself wide open for similar treatment, besides the parents will play off one against the other and we will be in a nice mess.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir,

We have one child going to Muscogee Indian Residential School at Lestock. She was admitted last year. We have three others going to Gordon Indian Residential, admitted some years ago.

We would like to have them all together in the same school.

As we are all Roman Catholics, we want to send them all to the Catholic School at Lestock Muscogee Residential School.

Our three girls at Gordon School are:

Harriette Olive - 14 yrs old
Rachel - 12
11B C.E.

Ottawa, September 10, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 5th instant, in which you intimate that Barbara Cyr, No. 0235, and Rachel Cyr, No. 0310, pupils of the Gordon's School, have been without your permission transferred to the Muscowequan School.

In a letter dated August 22, 1942, signed by Mrs. Albert Cyr, the statement is made that they have one child enrolled at the Muscowequan Residential School. However, we have made a very diligent search of our records here, and there is nothing to indicate that an admission form for the entry of this child to the Muscowequan School has been received by the Department.

You are aware, no doubt, that it has been the policy of this Department for a number of years to do everything humanly possible to discourage the transfer of pupils from a residential school operated by one church to a residential school operated by another church. Such transfers not only tend to interrupt the pupil's studies but have a most confusing effect upon the pupil from the standpoint of his religious and moral purposes. In the case of the Cyr children, it would appear that they were enrolled at the Muscowequan School without your permission and that no admission forms duly signed and asking for their admission and enrolment have reached the Department. The Department is of the opinion, therefore, that these children should be immediately returned to their home. After they have been returned to their home, their case should be very carefully reviewed by you and, if convenient, discussed with the principals of the two schools concerned. If the parents of these children are Catholic, you should give the approximate date when they became members of the Catholic Church and whether, or not, they are Catholics at this date. You should then carefully review the entire evidence and send in a definite recommendation in respect to the education of these children. If they have been transferred from the Gordon's School to the Muscowequan School simply because the parents have temporary grudge against Mr. Freyling, then you might consider the advisability of leaving them at home for a year, after the lapse of which time their claims for enrolment at a residential school might be carefully reviewed. In any event, it is certainly the intention of the Department to do everything we possibly can to prevent such transfers in the future. I am sending a copy of this letter to the Principal of the Muscowequan School for his information. I am also returning to you copy of a letter received by the Department from Mr. and Mrs. Albert Cyr.

Yours truly,

Encl.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. W. Waddy,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

COPY SENT TO REV. GEO. JEANNOITTE, O.M.I.,
Principal, Muscowequan Residential School

Sincerely,

Mrs. Albert Casey

No.   198

"     0235

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to inform you that Agent Davis, Touchwood Agency, has brought to my attention the fact that there are two orphan children on the Nut Lake Reserve, a girl aged 7 and a boy aged 9 years. They are living with their grandfather who is an old widower about 80 years of age and he is unable to care for them.

The above mentioned children should be sent to a boarding school and the Chief and Councillors of the Nut Lake Reserve have requested that the children be sent to the Muscowequan Residential School at Lastock. However, the old grandfather refuses to let them go. You will understand that the Nut Lake Indians do not belong to any Church group, they are simply pagans.

Would you please be good enough to give the necessary authority to have these two children placed in the Muscowequan School.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
August 24, 1943.

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Scarth & Victoria, Regina,
Sask.

In view of the information contained in
your letter of the 19th instant, the Department
considers that the two children from the Nut Lake
Reserve should be placed in the Muscowequan
Residential School. The necessary action may be
taken under Section 10 of the Indian Act.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, October 26, 1943.

Mr. R. S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Saskatchewan,

With reference to the September Quarter return of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, the Department approves the admission of Pat Smoke.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
October 26th, 1943

Dear Sir,

May I ask the Department of Indian Affairs to approve the transfer of John Leclair (No. 222, Quarterly Report ended Sept 30th/43) from Muscowequan I. Residential School to St. Philip's Indian Residential School. The reasons are the following:

1) His parents are working at St. Philip's School and able to keep him there.
2) Father Tetrault, the Principal of St. Philip's School, is willing to take him.
3) He is the only one, now, coming here, from so far (140 miles one way), having to make one trip in car for him alone.
4) The boy himself likes it better also.

Upon such grounds, I trust that the Department will approve of the transfer.

I remain your truly,

[Signature]
Principal

Muscowequan Indian Residential School
Lestock, Sask.

Ottawa, September 25, 1944.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punichy, Saskatchewan,

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School:

Michael Worm,
Eliza Rose Favel,
Rose Young,
Philomene Young,
Morris Slippery,
Edith Squirrel,
Mary Young.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
September 26, 1944.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punichy, Sask.

From the information contained in your letter of the 21st instant, it is evident that the two sons of Luke Ewinin are not eligible for admission to the Gordon's Residential School. These boys should be placed in the Muscowequan School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
September 27, 1944.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, the Department feels that William Pavel should be placed in the Muscowequan Residential School. If the information given in your letter of September 21 had been contained in your letter of July 13 the Department would not have approved the admission of William Pavel to the Gordon's School. It is quite evident from your letter that Albert Mahingen had no authority to sign an application for the admission of this boy to any Indian residential school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Ottawa, October 14, 1944.

Rev. O. Robidoux, O.M.I., Principal, Muscowequan Res. School,
Lestock, Saskatchewan.

The Department approves the discharge of
the following pupils from the Muscowequan Indian
Residential School:

No. 0247 Waban, Therese,
0262 Doreen Assapace,
0277 R. Alma Desjarlais,
0280 Edna Waban,
0320 Sally Smoke,
0321 Jean Sabat,
220 Leonard Leret,
249 Kay Mike.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Reference to the above, in p.m., of the fifth instant Punkichy Detachment contacted this Office per Long Distance Telephone and advised that three Indian boys had run away from the above named Indian School and would probably return to their homes on the Fishing Lake Indian School. The three boys were Daniel and Mathew Smoke and Willard Thomas.

This Detachment immediately contacted A.F. Fair, farm instructor, at the Fishing Lake Reserve and asked him to advise us immediately if he learned of the arrival of the three boys.

6-10-44.

In a.m., this date Fair advised this Office that the three boys had returned to the Reserve. He stated that the two Smoke boys were at their home but the Thomas boy was with his parents who were harvesting at the farm of Leonard Hagloff of the South Wadena District.

This p.m., the writer, in the company of Cpl. F.G. Woodman, patrolled per Police Auto Code 2755 to the Fishing Lake Reserve and the South Wadena District in the above regard.

The two Smoke boys were located at their home and were readily handed over by their parents to be returned to the school. The Thomas boy could not be located at this time as he had accompanied his parents to Elfros where they were shopping. The patrol returned to Wadena same p.m.

The Cst. 1/c Punkichy Det., was contacted and arrangements made to drive the runaway boys per Wadena Det. Transport as far as Dafoe, Sask., where he would contact it and drive them the remainder of the way to Lestock.

Enroute to Elfros from Wadena the Thomas boy was located driving in a horse and wagon with his mother. She was against his returning to the School but finally the boy got in the car and the patrol continued.

Cst. Playford was contacted at Dafoe and the three boys handed over to him. A receipt was obtained and is on file at this Detachment.

Extra copy attached.

EXPENSES - £93, Oct. 1/16, 1944.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 657-10, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Willard THOMAS et al - Run-away Indian Boys,
Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask.,

4-10-44.

1. Adverting to the above, in the P.M. of this date, the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian School, Rev. Fr. De'Verennes, notified this Detachment office that five Indian boys were missing and requested assistance of this Detachment in locating same. John KAY aged 12 yrs., and William DESJARLAIS, aged 12 years, were from the Poorman Indian Reserve, Quinton Dist., Sask., Willard THOMAS, Daniel SMOKE and Matthew SMOKE were from Fishing Lake, Indian Reserve, and these boys had been missing since Sunday October 1st, 1944 and all efforts of the Principal to locate them were unsuccessful.

2. Information concerning the boys from the Fishing Lake Indian Reserve was telephoned to Wadena Detachment this same P.M. and the writer patrolled via Pol/Car Code #3357 to the Quinton district to the Poorman's Indian Reserve where a search was conducted, no trace of John KAY or William DESJARLAIS could be found and their parents were advised that they were to return the boys to the Muscowequan Indian Reserve as soon as they appeared on the Reserve.

6-10-44.

3. In the late P.M. this date the N.C.O. I/c Wadena Detachment advised that he had located Willard THOMAS, Daniel SMOKE and Matthew SMOKE, this information was given to the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian School, who requested that the writer transport the boys to the school, as he was temporarily without transport, this same P.M. the writer patrolled to Dafoe, Sask., where a patrol from Wadena was met and the boys taken over from the N.C.O. I/c Wadena Detachment and transported to the Muscowequan Indian School, at Lestock, Sask., where they were handed over to the Principal.

7-10-44.

4. This date the Rev. Fr. De'Verennes notified the writer that John KAY and William DESJARLAIS had been returned to the School by their parents.

H.C.D.G.
Expenses shown on P.M.
Rep.Oct.1st-15th.1944.

(T.H.Playford) Reg.No.12040.
I/c Punnichy Detachment.

Mr. R. S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Sask.

With reference to the December quarter return of the Muscowequan Residential School, you may inform the Principal that the admission of Luke Nanakowewitang is approved.

The discharge of pupils numbered as follows is also approved:

Numbers 231; 279; 0266.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
January 9, 1945

The Secretary  
Dept. of Mines & Resources  
Indian Affairs Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir:

Last Sunday, the 7th of January 1945, Joseph Wolfe asked me to discharge his boy No. 211 Mathew because he was 16 years old the next day, and that I had no right to keep him in School after his birthday. Again, Monday afternoon he came and made the same request, and I answered like on Sunday that I wanted to keep the boy till the end of June and that I would talk to the Agent about it. Joe did not want to wait that long apparently, took the boy from the Barn to his home.

I never thought of asking the Dept. permission to keep Mathew till the end of the School year in order to not break the morale of other Pupils and our organizations as Cadets, training etc..

Would the Department tell me if my move was right or not, and if it is possible to have Mathew come back to School?

May I ask for the same reason as above the permission to keep till the end of June the following pupils:

#216 Desjarlais Albert 21-3-29 Birthday  
0274 Pelletier Doris 17-2-29  

I remain, Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal
Ottawa, January 27, 1945.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, the Department approves the under-mentioned pupils remaining in the Muscowequan Residential School until June 30, 1945:

No. 216 - Albert Desjarlais,
0274 - Doris Pelletier.

If you desire to retain these pupils after that date, you should make further application, stating your reasons for desiring them to remain in the school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. V. de Varennes, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Muscowequan Residential School,
Lestock, Sask.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Departmental letter No. 1-1-10 dated June 15, 1934 quotes Section 10, 1 of the "Indian Act" that a pupil reaching the age of sixteen should remain in school until the end of the school year, which would be some time in June.

Rev. de Verennes, Principal of the Muscowequan school advises me that Mathew Wolf, son of Joe Wolf, Muscowequan Band, has just reached the age of 16 and the father has taken his son from the school without permission from the Rev. Father.

Joe Wolf has consulted a lawyer and has been advised that the boy does not have to remain in school after he reaches the age of 16.

Please advise me if the lawyer is correct or not. I have not an up to date Indian Act and there may be some amendments to the section of the act as quoted above.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, January 13, 1945.

Mr. R. S. Davis, Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

I have your letter of the 8th instant,
with reference to Mathew Wolf removing his son from
the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

It is regretted that the Principal of the
Muscowequan School allowed the father to take the boy;
but, as this has now been done, we cannot see any
reason for returning him to the school. If such
action were taken, it would simply be the cause of
trouble to all parties concerned.

However, the Principal of the Muscowequan
School should be very definitely informed that pupils
should not be allowed to leave school simply because
they have reached the age of 16. You will note that
Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act mentions "the full
age of 16". This has always been interpreted to mean
until the child reaches his 17th birthday. In any
case, we have not authorized discharge of any pupil
simply because he or she has reached the 16th birth-
day during the academic year. In all such cases we
feel that the child should complete the academic year,
both in his own interests and in the conduct of any
residential school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
David Gordon (Treaty Indian) Indian Act (10)
Gordons Indian Reserve, Saskatchewan.

29-12-44.

1. Adverting to the above, in the A.K. of this date R.S. Davis, Indian Agent of Touchwood agency notified this detachment office that the above named had taken his son David Gordon Jr., aged 15 years away from the Muscowequan Indian School at Lestock, Sask., without authority to do so, Mr. Davis requested that the father of this Indian boy be served with Notice under the provisions of Section 10 para 4 of the Indian Act.

2. This same date while in the district on other Police Duties an attempt was made to contact David Gordon Jr., but it was found that he had not returned to his home and his whereabouts were unknown.

2-1-45.

In the P.M. of this date the writer patrolled via Pol/Car Ford Code #6494 accompanied by Sgt. M.G. Crawford to the Gordon Indian Reserve where David Gordon Sr. was located and interviewed, when it was ascertained that the father of this boy was in error as to the correct age of David Gordon Jr. The writer pointed out to Gordon that his son would not reach the full age of 16 years until December 27th, 1945 and in compliance with the provisions of the Indian Act he must attend school until that date, whereupon Gordon stated he would return the boy to the school. Notice to return the boy was served at this time to return David Gordon Jr. to the school.

5-1-45

4. This P.M. Father Z.de'Verennes, Principal of the Muscowequan Indian School at Lestock, Sask., advised the writer that the boy had been returned to the School by his father David Gordon Sr. in view of which no further action is contemplated herein.

(T.H.Playford) Reg.No.12040
I/c Punichy Detachment.

I enclose herewith Quarterly School Return of the Muscowequan Indian Residential school for the quarter ending March 31, 1945, together with form I.A.411, Admission and Discharge of pupils.

The Reverend Principal states that pupil #268, Freddy Joseph of Fishing Lake Reserve, Carlton Agency is quite lame and weaker than when he was first put in the school. The Principal suggests that he be transferred to some institution like St Hubert's Home and I would request that authority be given to make this transfer.

In a report dated April 10, 1945, the
R. C. M. Police Detachment at Punnichy, Sask., advised
this office as follows:

"Re: William Desjarlais & Joseph Asapage (Treaty
Indians) Run-a-way Boys - Muscowequan
Indian School, Lestock, Saskatchewan.

6-4-45

1. Adverting to the above, in the late P.M. this
date the captionally noted boys were found in the village
of Punnichy in the act of begging bread and upon interrogation
it was ascertained that they had run away this same
P.M. from the Muscowequan Indian School. The boys in
question were wet through and the Telephone office was
closed, in view of which they were taken to Punnichy
Detachment and put to bed.

7-4-45

2. In the A.M. of this date the Principal of
Muscowequan Indian School was advised of the boys' whereabouts,
who in turn sent transportation to return them
to the school."

I would appreciate having a report from you
regarding the action taken by these boys. Before replying,
you should consult the Principal and make certain that the
pupils at this school are receiving an adequate quantity
of food.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
With reference to Department letter #121-5-10 dated April 27 last regarding report of R.C.M.P. Detachment at Punnichy, dated April 10, 1945, the boys mentioned just had the urge to run away, with spring in the air.

They left the school shortly before supper and walked about twenty miles and were hungry after the long walk. I had investigated this matter before the receipt of your letter.

All the children in the school are and have been, well fed.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

Dept, Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

re Freddy Joseph
Fishing Lake Band.

I wrote you on April 6 last regarding the abovenamed pupil of Muscowequan Indian Residential school suggesting that he be transferred to some institution such as St Hubert's Home but to date have not had a reply to my letter.

I would be glad to be advised the Department's wishes in regard to this child.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent,
Ottawa, Ontario
June 12, 1945

re: Freddy Joseph,
Fishing Lake Bend, Your file
G-11 R.C.

The School Branch have referred your letter of June 8, requesting that this boy be transferred to St. Hubert's Home, to this Branch.

It is noted that on his admission to the Residential School in 1942 that he was diagnosed as having a congenital hip and that for some time he was in Fort Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital. There is no information here as to what treatment he had received.

I think this boy should be admitted to Fort Qu'Appelle Hospital again and investigated. It may be that surgery would improve his condition. In any case before being sent to a home a report on his physical condition should be forwarded here.

If it is found after investigation that treatment will be of no use, it will be in order to arrange his admission to an institution such as St. Hubert's Home.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.
Acting Assistant Supt. of Medical Services

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

AIRMAIL

Ottawa, August 3, 1945.

R.S. Davis, Esq., Indian Agent, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

I have to refer to your letter of July 27 and previous correspondence with regard to the case of Private Alex Poorman, L-19878.

According to the Branch records the only child by the surname of Poorman at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School is Henry, aged 10, son of Robert Poorman, - with notation that his mother is dead.

This apparently is not the same child. Please clarify this point by return airmail.

(Sgd.) H.A.H.
Director.
PUNNICHY, Sask.,
August 6, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

re: Pte. Poorman Alex L-19878

With reference to your letter #452-6-121 dated August 3, re the son of Alex Poorman attending the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I would state that the Henry you refer to must be the son of Alex, not Robert.

Alex lost his first wife and married again on March 24, 1938. His present wife is a daughter of Edward Worm, #79 Poorman's Band.

Henry is a child by his first wife, the other two children are by his present wife, Florence.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Dear Sir,

I do not know whether I should write to the direct head quarters of Indian Affairs branch but I do not know who to go to, to tell my troubles to. However first of all I wish to draw your attention closely to my story, namely, I am always sick at the present time I am suffering with diabetes.

And in conclusion Mr. R.C. Davis, A.A. of Touchwood agency gave his advice to send my children to school and one of them was under school age at the time. He told me to send my children to Muscowequan Residential School however I carried out his instructions with respectful manner and when time came to take my two boys to school Nicholas 10 and Ronald 6. I proceeded with my family to Muscowequan Residential School to where I tried my best to enter my two boys into that school. Rev. Father Principal would not accept the young one although I explain the instructions I have received from the Indian agent to Rev. Father principal and I wanted the boys to go to school together but I made no effort of putting the two boys in the said school so I took them to Gordon's Residential School and I explain my situation to Mr. Fleming Principal of Gordon's School at that time so he accepted my both boys in the school.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 657-10, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Later Mr. Davis, Indian Agent, told me with rough manner that he got a circular with instructions from Indian Dept. of Ottawa that my boys to be delivered to Macdonald's Residential school but I absolutely refused that, as I already entered my two boys in Gordon's Residential school and I made an sworn statement under oath by virtue of the Canada evidence act that I declared before Mr. E.J. Simson commissioner for oaths in and for the province of Saskatchewan. A solicitor Raymond said that my two sons be admitted in to the faith of Anglican communion &c. etc., and lately I was told by the present principal of Gordon school, Mr. Donce, that he had received a letter from Ottawa to deliver my two boys at the office indian agent, and the Indian Dept. has not yet given permission for them to be admitted and the school is receiving no grant in respect to my two boys and I also wish to state that I was brought up at Gordon school, but I married a catholic girl and I be come catholic but now I and my family join the Anglican faith and it should be distinctly understood that we are no Roman Catholic.

I hope that dept. will respect my application under as herein stated matter and oblige yours truly

Luke Evans
In the matter of the Indian Act and in the matter of an application to the Indian Department for the approval of the admission of Nicholas Sylvester Ewenin and Ronald Lee Ewenin to the Gordon's Anglican Indian Residential School of Punnichy, Sask.

CANADA
PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN
TO WIT:

I, Luke Ewenin of the Post Office of Raymore in the Province of Saskatchewan, Indian, do solemnly declare:

1. That I am a full blooded Indian and a treaty Indian residing on Poor Man's Reserve in the Postal District of Raymore in the Province of Saskatchewan.

2. That I am the father of the above named Nicholas Sylvester Ewenin and Ronald Lee Ewenin of the age of 11 years and seven years respectively both of whom were in attendance at the said Gordon's Anglican Indian Residential School from the month of September, 1944 to the end of the month of June, 1945.

3. That prior to being married, I was a communicant of the Church of England, and my wife was then a Roman Catholic and both of my said boys were baptised as Roman Catholics.

4. That both myself and my wife have renounced the Roman Catholic faith and we have both applied to be admitted into the Faith of the Anglican Communion and to have our said boys admitted into that Faith.

5. That neither myself or my wife have been influenced in any way by anyone whatsoever in making this choice for ourselves and our sons, but have done so entirely of our own free will and choice.

6. That for the reasons as above stated I desire my said sons be admitted to the said Gordon's Anglican Indian Residential School.

And I make this solemn declaration conscientiously believing it to be true and knowing that it is of the same force effect as if made under oath by virtue of the Canada Evidence Act.
Declared before me at the village of Raymore in the Province of Saskatchewan this 4th day of September, 1945.

(SGD) C.J. Samson.

A Commissioner for Oaths in and for the Province of Saskatchewan. A Solicitor.

Luke Ewenin.
Ottawa, 24th September, 1945.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Sask.

I have your letter of the 11th instant with reference to the children of Luke Ewenin. I am also in receipt of a letter from C.J. Samsom, Barrister, Raymore, Sask., in which he enclosed a statutory declaration signed by Luke Ewenin and I enclose a copy of this for your information.

I would like to know if you feel the statements made in this declaration are according to fact.

Luke Ewenin has also written to the Department and in one part of his letter he states that acting on your instructions he took his two boys to the Muscowequan School some time during the year 1944 and the Principal of that institution refused to accept the younger one and consequently Ewenin took both boys to the Gordon School where, he states, the Principal accepted them.

I would appreciate your making some further enquiries in ascertaining if this statement is correct.

Even though Ewenin's statement is correct, the Gordon School had no right to accept them.

I note the statement made in the third paragraph of your letter and while we have never made any definite ruling regarding the length of time, it has never been our practice to recognize sudden changes in religion insofar as such action affects the welfare of the children.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Alex WOLFE - The Indian Act (10-4)

(PUNNICHY DETACHMENT CASE.)

26-9-45

1. Advertising to the above, in the A.M. of this date R.S. DAVIS, Indian Agent of Touchwood Indian Agency notified this Detachment office to the effect that one Irene WOLFE, daughter of Alex WOLFE of Muscowequan Indian Reserve was absent from School without permission and requested that this Detachment serve a notice in writing under section 10 of the Indian Act upon Alex WOLFE.

2. Pursuant to the above in the A.M. of this date the writer patrolled via Pol/Cer Ford Code #8494 to the Lestock District where enquiries revealed that Alex WOLFE was absent from his home and no one could be found who knew of his whereabouts, it being alleged that he was at some point threshing.

27-9-45

3. On this date while in the Krasne and Wishart districts on other Police duties WOLFE was located and notice under section 10 of the Indian Act was served upon him. WOLFE advised that it was his intention of taking his daughter to the Muscowequan Indian School on Sunday September 30th, 1945.

1-10-45

4. In the P.M. of this date the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian School advised the writer that the exceptionally noted had returned his child to the school.

RE: Daniel SMOKE
Nancy SMOKE
Lawrence SILVERQUILL
Fred DESJARLAIS

(T.I.C.) - Runaway Children -
Mustowegan Indian School - Lestock, Sask.

12-10-45.

1. With reference to the above, it is advised that this P.M., the writer was telephoned by the Principal of the above school, and advised that the captionally-noted children had run away from the school, and were believed to be at or en route to their homes at the Fishing Lake Indian Reserve. It was requested that the writer endeavour to locate these children and advise the principal of the school, when arrangements would be made for conveyal of same back to the school.

13-10-45.

2. This P.M., the writer patrolled per Pol.Car Code § 8306 to the Fishing Lake Indian Reserve, where it was found that Daniel and Nancy SMOKE had been taken back to the school by their parents. Lawrence SILVERQUILL and Fred DESJARLAIS were located and brought per Pol.Car to Wadena, from which point the Principal of the Indian School was telephoned, and it was arranged that the writer convey the children to Elfros, where they would be met by Indian School transport and taken over.

3. Following the above arrangement, patrol continued to Elfros, where Mr. R. PICHETTE, of the Mustowegan Indian School took over the children, following which patrol returned to Wadena at 7:00 P.M.

I beg to advise that William Desjarlais, pupil #244 Muscowequan Indian Residential School, recently ran away once more from the school and this time took a team of horses and sleigh and drove back to his home on Poorman's reserve.

I understand the Reverend Principal has already written you about this boy as this is not the first time he has played truant.

It is suggested that this boy be transferred to the Residential school at Onion Lake where he will be much further from home. He is a bad influence on the other pupils at Muscowequan School and encourages them to play truant also.

I would be glad if the Department would advise me in this regard.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent,

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

DIVISION FILE No. 45R-117
SUB-DIVISION YORKTON
DETACHMENT FUNNICHY
DATE NOVEMBER 17TH, 1945

RE: WILLIAM DESJARLAIS & JOSEPH ASSAPACE (T.I.)
RUNAWAY INDIAN BOYS - MUSCOOQUEN INDIAN SCHOOL, LESTOCK, SASKATCHEWAN.

12-11-45.

1. Advertising to the above, at 9:00 A.M. this date, Rev. Fr. de BERNARD, Principal of Muscooquen Indian School, Lestock, Sask., called at this Detachment and advised that the two exceptionally noted boys had run away from the School on the P.M. of the 10th instant, and due to the attitude of DESJARLAIS parents requested that members of this Detachment assist him in locating and returning the boys to the school.

2. At 9:45 A.M. the writer and Cst. Douglas accompanied the Principal via Pte Auto Gretis to the Poorman Indian Reserve, where it was ascertained that the above noted boys had left by team for Raymore, Sask., after confirming this information the patrol continued to Raymore where the boys were located and handed over to the Principal for transportation to the School.

3. When located these two boys were in possession of a sleigh and team, and upon being interrogated it was ascertained that they had stolen the team and sleigh from an Indian in the village of Lestock on the late P.M. of the 10th instant, the boys did not know who owned the team etc., the services of another Indian were obtained who took the Team to the Farm Instructor on the Poorman Reserve.

13-11-45.

4. This date while in the Lestock district on other Police duties further investigation revealed that the Team and sleigh were the property of Alfred MANITOPIYES, of Muscooquen Indian Reserve, Lestock Dist., Sask. MANITOPIYES was located and advised of the location of his team and sleigh when he advised that he did not wish to take any action against the boys in question, the parents of DESJARLAIS and ASSAPACE were advised and Harry ASSAPACE, Father of the exceptionally noted returned the team to MANITOPIYES at Lestock, Sask.

5. In view of MANITOPIYES's attitude in this regard no action is being taken regarding the theft of the Team and sleigh, and this file will be considered closed.

Cst. (T.H. Playford) 12040
I/c Funnichy Detachment

Muscowequan School:

With reference to Department letter #121-5-10 dated February 28, 1946 enclosing letter from Chief Desjarlais and certificate given him by Dr. Golfman regarding Marian Hunter, daughter of Andrew Hunter of Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I would advise that both the Reverend Principal and myself are of the opinion that the child should stay on the rolls of the school, but remain at home, until I can take her to the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle for examination.

Ottawa, August 27, 1946.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

Enclosed for your information is a letter dated August 19, 1946 from Mr. Lucien Bruce, Spokesman for the Muscowequan Band.

Our records agree with the statement in the letter to the effect that Daniel Bigsby No. 241 will be sixteen years of age on March 22, 1947.

It appears, also from our records that pupil No. 0241 is sixteen years of age this month and pupil No. 0214 and 0260 are each sixteen years of age. Pupil No. 0269 will not be sixteen years of age until October.

You should consult the Principal and let me have a report regarding the advisability of discharging these pupils. However, it is not our general practice to discharge a pupil immediately on attaining the age of sixteen. Such pupils are retained in the school until the close of the academic year. For instance, as shown above pupil No. 0241 will not be sixteen until March, 1947 and the Department feels that unless some very strong reason is given for his discharge he should be retained in the school until June 30th, 1947. When children are discharged immediately on attaining sixteen it not only disrupts the pupils own work but it disrupts all the pupils in the school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to Department letter 121-5-10 (WT1) dated August 27, 1946 regarding letter from Lucien Bruce, Muscowequan Band, requesting the discharge of Daniel Big Sky No. 241, from the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I would advise that I took this matter up with the Principal, and his reply is as follows:

"Re the discharge of Pupils No. 0214, 0260 and 0269 you may know that I have recommended their discharge in June and they have been discharged in the course of August, on the 22d I believe (ref. G-11 R.C.)

I do not see any reason to discharge Pupil No. 241 Daniel Bigsky who is going to be 16 only in March 1947. It is true that last year a boy was discharged by Doctor's recommendation, his father being ill. If we discharge Daniel now, it will not help his father to work at home, because he has no farm; it may be to help him to make more home-brew as he is suspected.

Later on I shall submit a list of pupils who are going to be 16 years during this Academic Year 1946-1947.

For my own part, I do not favor the discharge of pupils under 16 years of age, unless for some special reason, and pupils attaining the age of sixteen should be retained in school until the close of the academic year.

Authority for the discharge of pupils No. 0214, 0260 & 0269 was given by Department letter #121-5-10 (WT1) dated August 22, 1946.

Letter from L.Bruce returned herewith.

R.S.Davis,
Indian Agent

Dear Hon. Mr. Glen,

I am in a request of Mr. Jim Bigley member of the Muscowequans Band, to write direct to your Department and to ask a discharge of his boy who will be 16 yrs old only March next yr.

He claims that some of his boy's school mates were discharged before 16 yrs old. I note that this should have been dealt with locally. But unfortunately this request would be fruitless if it was taken locally.

Wishing you to give us your information promptly at an earliest possible date.

Hoping to from you,

Respectfully Yours,

Lucien Bruce,

Pupils attaining the age of 16 should be retained in the school until the close of the academic year.

Philip Phelan,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Duck Lake, Sask.
September 17, 1946.

Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Enclosed herewith please find Application for Admission forms duly completed covering admissions into Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Sask. of the following Indian children, who are members of Kinistino Band No. 91.

Mabel Smokyday, age 14 years, Treaty No. 152, Female
Moses Nippi, age 10 years, Treaty No. 166, Male
Miscabetamek Nippi, age 9 years, Treaty No. 168, Female
Colin Smokyday, age 11 years, Treaty No. 164, Male
Kookoes Thomas, age 14 years, Treaty No. 158, Female

I recommend that admission of the above named Indian children into Muscowequan Indian Residential School be approved for the reason that they do not attend Indian Day School regularly, also the fact that conditions in the homes of their parents is of a very low moral standard and is contributing to immorality and improper living conditions.

To date very little progress has been made by any of our Missionaries in regards to teaching the Indians of Kinistino Band along lines of Christianity and I feel we should lend our support to any particular creed who will attempt to carry out this necessary work among these Indians, who while showing progress in regards to their material welfare are not showing progress in regard to their spiritual welfare, with the results that the Indian home life is becoming highly unsatisfactory and they are not adhering to Pagan Indian customs and are reaching a stage of indecent living, debauchery, bigamy, etc., which is entirely foreign to either pagan Indian customs or our Christian way of life and this evil can only be corrected by their conversion to Christianity.

[Signature]
N.J. McLeod
INDIAN AGENT.

Sir,

Here I am writing this letter going to tell you about Principal of Moosequan P.R. School he holding a girl name Marian Dandy Horn. Pen Man Reserve is still attending School she is sixteen years old now, but the Principal says the girl is 15 years old on his books but on account my Treaty statement she is 16 yrs old this girl born October 28th 1929 her brother was discharged from the same School 2 yrs ago the boy name William Dandy Horn he is 2 yrs older than Marian Dandy Horn I think the Principal just holding a few girls in that School just to get money from Dept. I work I am look over these School's what they doing, Day School are we needed bad.

Yours Truly,
Pen Man Chief

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 657-10, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to Department letter #121-5-10 (W.T.l.) dated September 21, 1946, enclosing letter from Chief Ed. Peerman, Peerman reserve, re Mary Ann Dustyhorn, I would advise that this girl is a daughter of Joseph Dustyhorn #68 Peerman Band.

This man had two girls, one named Margaret, born September 20, 1929 and another girl, Mary Ann, born December 12, 1931.

The girl Margaret subsequently died but Dustyhorn has the two confused and says it is the younger girl who died and claims that the girl in school is over 16 years of age.

The Agency records are not very clear, as at the time of these births the names of the children were not shown, but Muscewsquan School has a record of the baptism of the children with dates of birth etc., and are sure that the girl Mary Ann is the child born December 12, 1931.

I might say that this has been explained several times to Dustyhorn, but he seems very anxious to get the girl discharged from school, regardless.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 657-10, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, 8 October 1946.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent,
PUNNICHY, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant regarding the request of Chief Ed. Poorman for the discharge of Mary Ann Dustyhorn from the Muscowequan School, it is noted that this girl is not yet 16 years of age and we have not been supplied with any definite reason why she should be discharged.

Under the circumstances, it is considered she should remain in the school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Muscowequan Indian Reserve,
Lestock, Sask., Oct. 15th

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Very Dear Mr. Hoey,

I beg to request that whether or not an indian withdraws & holds his son or girl upon reaching the age of sixteen, or who has only 3 to 4 months more till school before he or she is sixteen.

Hoping to hear from you in the near future.

Yours Very Respectfully,

Lucien Bruce,
Spokesman Muscowequan Band.
Ottawa, 21 October 1946.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent,
PUNNICHY, Sask.

Enclosed is a copy of a letter received from Lucien Bruce.

You should inform him that we have received his letter and in reply you should advise him that we do not allow children to leave a residential school simply because they reach the age of 16 during the academic year. It has always been the practice to have such children remain in school until the close of the academic year on June 30th.

Children who have not reached the age of 16 by Sept. 1st, the date of opening residential schools, should be returned to the school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
October 4 1946

The Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa Ont.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

The enclosed letter has just been received from Lucien Bruce. Please let me have a report regarding the matter mentioned in the letter. When replying you should return the latter.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital  
Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.  
November 30th, 1946.

Dear Sir:  
re: Robert Bruce - Touchwood Agency

Your letter G-12B of November 28th, enclosing Dr. Golfman's report on the above named is hereby acknowledged.

If this boy is a school age, I see no reason from Dr. Golfman's report, why this indian boy should not be in school. His small build and under nourished look is no doubt the result of insufficient food. If he was in school he is assured of good food and plenty of it, which should overcome these defects. One could not expect his I.Q. to be very high seeing his Father is such a bright and Intelligent Gentleman. You might explain to the parents that by sending him to school we hope to improve his I.Q., but he will never be as smart a man as his father.

Providing no more snow arrives it is expected that the Xray Outfit will be visiting Gordons and Muscowequan School this coming week, in which case it should be seen that this boy is x-rayed.

Knowing Mr. Bruce from past experience, the only thing to do providing Father De Varrenes will accept him as a pupil, is to give him 24 hours to place this child in school, and if he does not do so take the necessary procedure laid down by the Indian Act.

Yours truly,

sgd A.B.Simes  
M.D.  
Medical Superintendent  
Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit.

Mr. R.S.Davis,  
Indian Agent,  
PUNNICHY, Sask.
Aug. 24th, 1946.

To whom it may concern,

I have personally examined Robert Bruce in will of his parents, desiring to keep him home from school. He is small build and undernourished looking—sullen and a low I.Q. There nothing untoward in his general condition.

Signed,
Sidney Goldman.

P.S. The original (copy) letter of this copy was given to Mr. R.S. Davis.
Muscowequan Indian Res.,
Lestock Sask., Jan 23/47.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Director Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Ont.

Very Dear Sir,

Please find enclosed a copy from Dr. Goffman Punnichy, Sask., who personally examined my son Robert Bruce, who will be 15 yrs. ago March 1947. I resolve that my boy be discharged from school & desire to keep him home on conditions mentioned and am low Indian Act, Sect. 10.(5)(c)

Hoping to hear with results soon as possible.

Yours Respectfully,

Lucien Bruce.
PUNNICHY, Sask,
Feb 6, 1947.

With reference to Department letter #121-5-10 (WT1)
dated January 29, 1947 enclosing letter received from
Lucien Bruce, Muscowequan Band regarding his son Robert,
I beg to advise that this boy is still in school on the
recommendation of Dr. Simes.

I am returning letter from Lucien Bruce herewith,
together with a copy of letter from Dr. Simes.

R.S.Davis,
Indian Agent.

Dept. Mines & Resources,

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

DIVISION FILE No. 125-470
SUB-DIVISION DETACHMENT
PROVINCE: Yorkton
DATE: March 33rd, 1947

Amoie WOLF (T.L.) Indian Act (10)
Moosequon Indian Reserve, Sask.

HEADQUARTERS
Sub-Division
DEPARTMENT
P.C.R.
Furnichy

Advertising to the above, in the late P.M., this date R.S. DAVIS, Indian Agent of Touchwood Agency notified this Department office that the optionally noted had been taken from the Moosequon Indian School by his father Joseph WOLF and that members of the staff from the school went to get the boy but the father had refused to return him to the school. Mr. DAVIS requested that Joseph WOLF be served with a notice under section 10 of the Indian Act.

In the A.M. of this date the writer patrolled via Bay-Freight from Furnichy to Lestock, continued patrol via hired team livery to the house of Joseph WOLF where a notice under section 10 of the Indian Act instructing him to return the boy to the Moosequon Indian School with three clear days was served. The writer remained at Lestock overnight, other duties being attended to. In the late P.M., this same date the writer was advised by the Principal of the Moosequon Indian School that the optionally noted had returned to the school.

At 4:10 A.M., this date the writer patrolled via C.H. Bay from Lestock to Furnichy, continued on to Lestock on other duties.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, July 16, 1947.

Rev. V. de Varennes, O.M.I., Principal, Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Saskatchewan.

With reference to the June Quarter Return of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, pupil No. 0310 Annie Favel was shown in hospital yet sixty days grant was requested. In order to complete our records, it is requested that you forward the dates of her hospitalization.

It is noted that pupil No. 0360 Veronique M. Hunter has been absent for three quarters. If this pupil is not expected to return to school, it would be just as well to apply for her discharge.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

121-5-10 (WT.7)

300 Shetch Sam

CANADA
Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.,
Sept. 15th, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Pupils No. 0275 Bertha Pelletier and No. 0342 Doris Sparvier who have been attending the Muscowequan Indian Residential School at Lestock, Sask. have reached the age of discharge (16 years). These girls wish to continue their studies of grade 8 and it is the wishes of their parents that they continue.

Rev. V. de Varennes, Principal of the above school, is willing to take these girls back to complete their grade 8 and he reports that they are well applied to their work and progressing favorably. I would recommend that they be allowed to continue their studies.

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 4th, 1947.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 15th ultimo, the Department approves the following pupils of the Muscowequan Residential School remaining in the school for another year:

0275 Bertha Pelletier
0342 Doris Sparvier.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I wrote you on the 15th inst regarding the children of Ernest Bird, #145 Gordon Band, but to date have received no reply to my letter.

I am enclosing herewith application for admission to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School for Leona and Etheline, former pupils of Gordon's Indian Residential School, together with applications for admission to Muscowequan School from Glen Arnold and Pearl Vera, younger children of Ernest Bird who are starting school.

These applications are forwarded for your consideration.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 9, 1947.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Sask.,

With reference to your letter of September 30th, the Department approves the admission of the under-mentioned children to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School provided there is accommodation for them in the school and that their admission will not exceed the number for which grant is approved:

Francis-Xavier Akan, Norah Pambrun,
Wilfrid Bigsky, Victoria Manitopies,
Batiste Pambrun, Edna Akan,
Sihi Quill Charlie, Margaret O'choo,
Martin Longman Rose Mary Wolfe
Joseph Wolf

With reference to the second letter of the 30th ultimo enclosing application forms for the admission of four children of Ernest Bird, it is noted that two of them had previously attended the Gordon's Residential School. Is Ernest Bird recognized as a Catholic? If so why were two of the children in the Gordon's School. Please let me have a report regarding the religious affiliations of this family.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

PP/HM.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I enclose herewith application for admission to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School as under:

Stuart Dustyhorn          Thomas Kay
Thomas Leslie Desjarlais   Fred Young
Gabriel Manitopyes.

I would recommend the admission of these children to the school.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

KB/HM.
Saskatchewan

To Wit.

I., Ernest Bird, of Gordon's Indian Reserve in the Touchwood Agency, state that I have now changed my Religion from Protestant to Roman Catholic Faith, 1 year ago, and I wish for my children to be now brought up in the Roman Catholic Faith, and for them to now receive their schooling in the Muscowequon Indian Mission School at Lestock, Sask, and not at Gordon's Indian Mission School at Punnichy, as heretofore.

My wife's name is Virginia Bird, and she is a Roman Catholic Member by Baptism, and is now of the Catholic Faith.

And I make this solemn declaration conscientiously believing it to be true and knowing that it is of the same force and effect as if made under oath and by virtue of The Canada Evidence Act.

Date at Lestock in the Province of Saskatchewan this 9th day of September A.D. 1947.

Sworn before me at the Village of Lestock in the Province of Saskatchewan, this 9th day of September A.D. 1947.

A Notary Public in and for the Province of Saskatchewan by Commission Expires Dec 31st 1948.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to Department letters 121-5-10 WTL, dated September 30 and October 9, 1947 regarding the children of Ernest Bird, I would state that I took this matter up with the Reverend Principal of Muscowequan School and he has given me a copy of a letter he has written to Mr. Phelan under date of October 14, 1947, in which he states that Ernest Bird has been under instruction to become Catholic since over a year and a half. That he is not yet a baptized Catholic but that he is definitely a Catholic catechumen and at heart.

Mrs Bird was baptized a R.C. and copy of her baptismal certificate is enclosed, together with copies of baptismal certificates of the children Leona and Ethelene.

Affidavit by Ernest Bird is also enclosed.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 17, 1947.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of the 20th ultimo, regarding the children of Ernest Bird, it appears from the information contained in your letter that they are eligible for admission as grant earning pupils of the Muscowequan Residential School and their admission to that school is approved. The Birth Certificates which you forwarded are returned.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Encl:
PP/HH.

Ottawa, December 2, 1947.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 18th ultimo, the Department approves the transfer of Joseph Lee Smith from the Kenora Residential School to the Muscowequan Residential School.

Philip Phelan

PP/MGD
