December 3rd, 1947

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

James Gordon of Gordon's reserve, Touchwood Agency has attended Muscowequan Residential School for four years, but this year his mother married S. Asham of Pasqua Band, Qu'Appelle Agency, therefore they wish to have the boy admitted to the Qu'Appelle Residential School.

I would recommend the transfer as now Qu'Appelle school is very much closer to his home.

Frank Booth.
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 11, 1947.

Mr. Frank Booth, Indian Agent,
Muscow, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, the Department has no objection to the transfer of James Gordon from the Muscowequan Residential School to the Qu'Appelle Residential School, provided both principals are agreeable to the transfer.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I enclose herewith Application for admission to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School from Rosa Akan daughter of John Akan, Muscowequan Band.

I also enclose application from Charles Maynard McNab, son of Mrs John McNab, Gordon Band, for admission to the school. I would point out that this is a Protestant family and if the Gordon school had been opened, no doubt it would have been put into that school.

I understand that a child of Thomas Bird, Gordon Band is also in the school but to date I have not received an application. The parents of this child are also protestants.

I have signed the application for Charles Maynard McNab for your consideration, but it would be as well to consider this thoroughly before accepting the application as this may lead to religious complications.

R.D.Savis,
Indian Agent.
February 11, 1948.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your recent letter, the Department approves the admission of Rosa Akan to the Muscowequan Residential School.

In view of the statement contained in your letter that the parents of Thomas Bird are recognized as Protestants, the boy is not eligible for admission as a grant earning pupil to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. If he is in that school at present he should be returned to his parents.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

IN THE MATTER OF Merwin Bitternose aged 25, Verna Bitternose aged 12 and Gena Bitternose aged 8 years, all infant children of John and Isabella Bitternose of Gordon's Indian Reserve, Punnichy, Sask.

AFFIDAVIT

So, John Bitternose and Isabella Bitternose, residents of Gordon's Indian Reserve, severally make oath and say:

1. That we are the parents of the above named infant children and as such we have personal knowledge of the facts and matters herein deposed to except where stated by us to be an information and belief.

2. That we desire that the said, above named, infant children should attend Muscowequan Indian Residential School in order that they may be brought up in the Catholic faith.

3. That this deponent Isabella Bitternose is of the catholic faith and wishes her children above named to be brought up in the Catholic Church.

4. That this deponent John Bitternose is now taking lessons in the catholic faith preliminary to and with the intention of being admitted into the Catholic Church and wishes said children also to be brought up in the Catholic Church.

5. That it is not our desire to have these children brought up in the Protestant faith and that this affidavit is made for the purpose of inducing the department to give its permission for the transfer of these children to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School and their bringing up in the Catholic faith.

Severally sworn before me this 14th day of October A.D. 1946 at Punnichy, Saskatchewan, the contents having first been read over to and explained to the male deponent who then made his mark in my presence.

CANADA
October 27, 1948.

Mr. S.H. Simpson,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.

We are in receipt of an affidavit signed by John Bitternose and his wife, indicating that they wish to be recognized in future as Roman Catholics and accordingly desire their children, Mervin Bitternose, Verna Bitternose and Cora Bitternose admitted to the Muscowequan School.

Please submit the usual application forms for the admission of the children to that school. However, it should be understood that they should not enter the Muscowequan School until we have had an opportunity of reviewing the applications and we will then advise you.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division.

PP/MGD
On the above date, Father Dorge of the Lestock Indian Residential School called at this office in the late evening and reported that the captionally noted girl, who was 15 years of age, refused to go to school. Father Dorge advised that this was his third trip to this district to try and get Marjorie TON to return to the school but that he was unable to do anything with her. Father Dorge requested assistance from this force in compelling Marjorie TON to attend school. He advised that her home was on the Nut Lake Indian Reserve east of Rose Valley, but that she had been living at the Chagonees I.R., all summer and practically running wild.

On the above date, accompanied by Mr. M. Gervais, Agency Assistant at the Nut Lake I.R., patrolled to the Chagonees Reserve via No. 3859. After considerable inquiries had been made about the reserve Marjorie TON was found in company of Maurice Lumberjack. Marjorie was advised that she was to return with me and then be taken to the Lestock Residential School by Father Dorge who would come for her.

On arrival at Rose Valley, the writer contacted Father Dorge and he was advised that I had Marjorie at Rose Valley. Due to other business he was unable to make the trip this evening and requested that I take Marjorie to her mother's home on the Nut Lake Indian Reserve, which I did. Mrs. TON was most anxious for Marjorie to return to the school this term and advised that she would keep Marjorie at home until Father Dorge came for her.

On the above date, Mr. Gervais, Indian Agency Assistant at the Nut Lake Indian Reserve, advised the writer that Father Dorge had taken Marjorie TON back to the Lestock school this date.

December 28, 1948.

Mr. S.H. Simpson,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.,

We have your letter of the 21st instant enclosing application for the admission of Mervin, Verna and Cora Bitternose.

Before considering these applications, we would like to know if this family are recorded in your office as members of the Roman Catholic Church. If so, we would appreciate knowing why they attended the Gordon's Residential School for four years as shown on the application forms.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

PP/HHM.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I am in receipt of Departmental letter 657-10(EI) dated December 28th; pertaining to Application for Admission of Mervin, Verna and Cora Bitternose.

These Applications were submitted by request of Departmental letter 121-5-10(EI), in which it was advised that the Department was in receipt of an affidavit signed by John Bitternose and his wife, to the effect they were to be recognized in future as Roman Catholics.

The records of this office show that this family are members of the Church of England, and that their children were in attendance at the Gordon Residential School until June 30th, 1947, which has since been closed, and is expected to reopen some time this year.

Since writing letter 881-G-11RC dated Dec. 21st; I have been informed by the Principal of the Muscowequan Residential School that the three children in question have been attending his school since September 10th, 1948.

S.H. Simpson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency

Dear Father Robidoux:

Your June Quarterly Return for the school has been received.

On checking it, it is found that you state that pupil No. 311 was in residence for forty-seven days and the balance at Fort Qu'Appelle Hospital. You, however, omit to say when this pupil was admitted to the hospital. The Audit Branch and the Treasury Branch insist that dates be shown when pupils leave residence and when they return for any reason.

I might add that the school is allowed thirty days of grant after the pupil is admitted to hospital. Therefore, it is very important that the date the pupil left school and the reason be shown.

Please advise the date in this case and please make it a point to show all necessary date markings on future returns.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Rev. O. Robidoux, O.M.I.,
Muscowequan Indian Res., School,
Lestock, Sask.,

MPT/HM
Dear Father Robidoux:

Your June Quarterly Return for the school has been received.

On checking it, it is found that you state that pupil No. 311 was in residence for forty-seven days and the balance at Fort Qu'Appelle Hospital. You, however, omit to say when this pupil was admitted to the hospital. The Audit Branch and the Treasury Branch insist that dates be shown when pupils leave residence and when they return for any reason.

I might add that the school is allowed thirty days of grant after the pupil is admitted to hospital. Therefore, it is very important that the date the pupil left school and the reason be shown.

Please advise the date in this case and please make it a point to show all necessary date markings on future returns.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Mr. A.R. Nixon,
A/Supt., Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

Re: Discharge of Children from Muscowequan Residential School For Enrolment at Poorman's Day School

Reference is to your letter of August 15th in which you list 15 children for the purpose noted above.

Before these discharges are authorized, it is desired to know what the enrolment at the new day school will be when these pupils are included.

It is assumed also that the principal factors in selecting these children for discharge are the convenient location of their homes, and satisfactory home conditions. As the 15 children come from 11 different homes, it is desired to be assured concerning the basis for selection.

Bernard J. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

RE: Discharge of children from Muscowequan Residential School
For Enrolment at Poorman's Day School

If transfers are authorized as requested from both Muscowequan and Gordon Residential Schools, there will be thirty-eight pupils for enrolment at the Day School on Poorman's Reserve. When making up this list, I took the principals of both of the above mentioned schools, on Poorman's Reserve and visited the homes and interviewed the parents, and in that way made up the list of pupils which should go to Poorman's Day School and those that should go to Muscowequan and Gordon's Residential Schools.

I regret this information was not included in my letter of August 15th.

A. R. Nixon,
Acting Superintendent.
September 2nd, 1949.

Mr. A.R. Nixon,
A/Supt., Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.

Re: Muscowequan Indian Residential School
Your File 908-G11RC-121

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 29th ultimo, the Department approves the discharge from the above school of the pupils whose names were included in your letter of August 15th. It is noted that these 15 children being discharged will attend the new Poorman's Indian Day School.

It is understood from your letter that these children were selected along the lines of the last paragraph of official letter of August 25th.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
Dear Mr. Nixon,

Frances Ochocoo-Muscogeean Residential School

Your letter 1100-G-11 RG 121 of 1 November '49 has been referred to Indian Health Services for advice concerning Frances Ochocoo who appears to be suffering from a mild degree of trachoma.

It is our opinion that this girl should remain at the school under treatment of our medical officer until such time as her condition has been rendered non-infectious.

As you are aware, trachoma is an infectious disease which can readily spread and we believe that it would not be in the interest of the residents of the reserve to allow this girl to voluntarily return home while still suffering from trachoma.

Yours very truly,

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Director,
Indian Health Services.

Mr. A. R. Nixon,
A/Sept., Indian Agency,
Punichi, Sask.

c.c. to Dr. Hall and Col. Neary

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
December 14th, 1949.

Memorandum:

MAJOR D.M. MACKAY

Re: Muscowequan Indian Residential School

I attach for your information a copy of a letter which Dr. Moore has forwarded to us with regard to Frances Oochoo, a pupil of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

This is the first intimation we have received regarding this girl's illness, and it is considered unfair that she should be allowed to remain in the school.

No doubt she requires treatment, and I feel that the girl should be placed in the hospital or some institution where she can receive the treatment she requires at the expense of Indian Health Services.

You will note that Dr. Moore points out that returning her to the reserve might be the cause of infection among the other Indians. There is the same possibility if she remains in the school.

I feel you will agree with me that it is simply impossible to operate educational institutions properly if the Medical Services, without consulting us, turn them into semi-hospitals.

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST
Supt. of Indian Education

Attach.

January 24th, 1950.

Rev. O. Robidoux, O.M.I.,
Muscovequian Indian Res., School,
Lestock, Sask.,

Your December 1949 Quarterly Return has been received and checked.

It is noted that a number of names appearing on the September return have been omitted on the December return and are not shown on the Admission and Discharge Form I.A. 411.

This practice is most irregular as no name can be omitted from the return unless the name is included on the Admission and Discharge Form. Similarly no new names can be added to the return unless they are shown on the Admission and Discharge Form under the proper heading. It is admitted that sometimes the Principal cannot have the application for admission completed when the return is due to be completed. However, the pupil may be included on the return and shown on the Admission and Discharge Form and grant will be paid. When the application for admission has been completed it should be forwarded to Ottawa at once.

Please bear in mind this information when completing future returns.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

October 17, 1950.

Rev. O. Robidoux, O.M.I.,
Muscowequan Indian Res. School,
Lestock, Sask.,

Dear Father Robidoux:

The September Quarterly Return for your school has been received and put through for payment.

As this Return was checked against the admission and discharge form, it is noted that twenty-seven children have been admitted to residence without Departmental authority. As you are aware, before a pupil can be admitted to residence the Indian Superintendent concerned is obliged to forward an application of admission to Ottawa where a decision is reached by the Department as to whether a pupil should be admitted to school or not.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would contact the respective Indian Superintendents to have these applications forwarded as soon as possible.

The discharge of the following is also approved:

| No. | No. | No. |
|-----|-----|-----|
| 255 | 0293 | 0315 |
| 271 | 0297 | 0379 |
| 307 | 0300 | 0376 |
| 327 | 0305 | 0383 |
| 0348 | 0395 | 0385 |
| 0398 | 0401 | 0395 |

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
MUSCOWEQUAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
LESTOCK, SASK.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,

yours truly,

U. Robidoux

October 18, 1950.

Rev. O. Robidoux, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Muscowequan Residential School,
Lestock, Sask.

Dear Father Robidoux:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, the Department approves the re-admission of Irene Agecouty, No. 0376, to the Muscowequan Residential School.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
November 28, 1950.

Rev. O. Robidoux, O.M.I.,
Muscowequan Indian Res. School,
Lestock, Sask.,

Dear Father Robidoux:

On October 17 we wrote you to the effect that applications for the admission of pupils to your school had not been received for some pupils while they were admitted to the school for institutional care.

As these returns are reviewed by Treasury and the Auditor we must have full information regarding each pupil; therefore, we require the application forms before the Quarterly Return reaches us.

We have made some exceptions in the past but the general procedure as mentioned above must be followed in the future. We will be obliged to withhold payment of per capita allowance until the application forms are received.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Principal,
Muscowequan Indian Res. School,
Lestock, Sask.,

Dear Father Tetrault:

This refers to the September Quarterly Return for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

The Department approves the discharge of pupils:

| No. | No. |
|-----|-----|
| 0318 | 0427 |
| 0325 | 0428 |
| 0335 | 266 |
| 357  | 354 |

With reference to pupils 271, 376, 377, 378, 0471, 0472, 0473 and 0460 no applications for admission for these pupils have been received and it would be appreciated if you would contact the respective Indian Superintendents to have these applications cleared up.

With reference to pupils 0470, 0461 and 0462, although we have the applications for these children, the Department has not approved their admission for religious reasons. As there is some doubt on this matter you should not have admitted these children as grant-earning pupils until a definite decision has been reached.
As the September Return has already been paid these children were not taken off the Return. However, it may be necessary to take them off the December Return.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
November 6th, 1951.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
c/o The Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Canada.

Dear Sir,

Last week on a tour of my Diocese I visited our Gordon's Indian Reserve and spent two days with our people.

One family, Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin McNab, asked for an interview, during which they informed me that a year ago they had sent their son, Charles Maynard McNab, to the Roman Catholic Residential School at Lestock, since Gordon's Residential School was not operating. Later, as you will know, we opened Gordon's as a two-room day school and it still continues to function as such, until such time as your Department discovers water in sufficient quantity for the Residential School to open fully. Mr. and Mrs. McNab are members of our Anglican Church and expressed their distress to our lay missionary, Mr. Robert Hicks, that their boy has been baptized into the Roman Church at Lestock. They now request me, in writing, to ask for his transfer to Gordon's Reserve so that he may attend our day school now in operation. Mr. McNab informs me that when he sent his boy to the Roman Catholic Residential School at Lestock, it was with the distinct understanding that he should not be baptized into the Roman Church.

I attach a copy of the request I have received and should be glad to hear from you at your earliest convenience.

I have spoken to Mr. Nixon, your agent at Punnichy, who informs me that the boy can be brought back at the parent's request.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Bishop of Qu'Appelle.

MEC/gbp
Att.
Gordon's Reserve,
PUNNICHY, Sask.
November 1, 1951.

My Lord,

During the period that there was no school here, I sent my boy to the Roman Catholic Mission School at Lestock with the understanding that he should not be baptized Roman Catholic.

I understand that he has been baptized by an Roman Catholic priest against my wishes. I would like my boy taken out of the school and sent to the Gordon's Day School and baptized in our Anglican Church if this is possible. The boy's name is:

Charles Maynard McNab.

Father's name: John Edwin McNab.

Yours truly,

Signed "John Edwin McNab".
November 16, 1951.

The Right Reverend M.E. Coleman, D.D.,
Bishop of Qu'Appelle,
Bishop's Court,
College Avenue,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Dear Bishop Coleman:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant regarding Charles Maynard McNab, who is at present enrolled at the Muscowequan Residential School.

I am communicating with Superintendent Nixon and on receipt of his reply I will write to you again.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
November 16, 1951.

Mr. A. R. Nixon,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.

I enclose copy of a letter received from Right Reverend M. E. Coleman, Bishop of Qu'Appelle, with reference to Charles Maynard McNab. The application form for the admission of this boy to the Muscowequan School was forwarded to the Department in February, 1948.

It would be appreciated if you would interview the Principal of the Muscowequan School and also Mr. and Mrs. McNab and let us have your recommendation in the matter.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Enc.

I have interviewed the Principal of Muscowequan Indian Residential School and Mr. and Mrs. McNab regarding the contents of your letter of November 16, File 657-10 (E), and we have decided to leave Charlie Maynard McNab in Muscowequan Residential School until Christmas holidays when he will return to his home on Gordon Reserve. The decision will be entirely with the parents themselves whether they send him back to Muscowequan School for the balance of the school year or send him to Gordon Indian Day School.

A. R. Nixon,
Superintendent.

Mr. A.R. Nixon,

Your file 950-121/25-2-657

With reference to your letter of December 5th regarding Charles Maynard McNab who is presently at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, we have informed Bishop Coleman of your comments.

It would be appreciated if you would inform us after the New Year, whether this boy is at the Muscowequan or the Gordon's Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
December 11, 1951

The Right Reverend M.E. Coleman, D.D.,
Bishop of Qu'Appelle,
Bishop's Court,
College Avenue,
Regina, Sask.,

Dear Bishop Coleman:

With reference to your letter of November 6th regarding Charles Maynard McNab who was formerly at the Gordon's Indian Residential School and now is at the Muscowequan School, we now have a reply from Mr. A.R. Nixon regarding this boy.

We are arranging to send this boy home for his Christmas holidays and are leaving the matter for the decision of the parents who will either send him back to the Muscowequan school for the balance of the school year or send him to the Gordon's Indian Day School.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
December 27, 1951.

Mr. A.H. Nixon,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.,

With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, the following children have been shown on the Return yet we have not yet received the necessary application for admission forms:

O471 Whitecap Darlene
O472 Poorman, Sadie
271 Floyd Whitecap

Kindly arrange to have these applications completed and forwarded to this office for consideration as soon as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
April 7, 1952.

Mr. A.R. Nixon,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.,

With reference to the December Quarterly Return for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, it is noted that the Principal is recommending the discharge of Margaret Manitopies and Harriet Chikinew who are sixteen years of age. Margaret Manitopies is in Grade 8 and Harriet Chikinew is in Grade 2.

It is presumed that these children are not at the school at present, consequently the Department approves their discharge as it is felt that it would not be possible to bring them back to school.

It would be appreciated if you would point out to the Principal that the Department is not in favour of discharging pupils during the academic year as it disrupts their education. It is felt that these children should have been kept in the school until the end of the present academic year. The girl in Grade 8 could have completed her Grade 8 education and would be in a better position to secure a suitable position. In the case of the latter, it would have been to her advantage also to complete the academic year.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

a/encls.
Muscoweguan Indian Residential School
Lestock - Sash. aug 9 - 52.

Dear Sir,

I have on hand your circular letter on the Admission of Indian children to Residential School. You state therein that: "Before accepting any child in a residential school for the first time, the principal must have the regular application and certificate of health properly completed, signed by the Indian Superintendent and approved by the department." - end of quote.

May I point out that this practice will involve a great deal of difficulties, and hardship as far as we are concerned. The practice here has been to round up the children at a set date, and have Parents sign a sheet for new pupils at the same time. Now if we cannot bring along these new pupils immediately, who will see to it that the parents have their child examined by a doctor? the health certificate completed? and so on...
We have 3 reservations, North of our school one at 8 miles
the others at 100 miles from school. So these Indians are
still very much attached to their Indian ways, very little in
favor of education, this new way of doing will mean, that
new pupils will not come in on time, there will be
delays of months before they will show up. This will mean
extra work in the class room, this will be very much detri-
mental to the school and pupils in general.

If you can tell us how to go about their new way of
doing, it would be very please to read your

Sincerely,

P.E. Petranet

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 657-10, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
August 18, 1952.

Mr. G.A. Havens,
I/C Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.,

I have a letter from Father P.E. Tetrault, O.M.I., Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School referring to our circular regarding the admission of Indian children to residential school.

In his letter the Principal states that there is considerable difficulty in having the physical examination completed prior to sending the children to residential school. The Department realizes these difficulties, however, it is felt that the principals and local Indian Superintendents can make suitable arrangements to have the face of the applications completed and signed by the parents and the Indian Superintendent. When the children are brought to the residential school, arrangements should be made to have the local Medical Superintendent visit the school and perform the necessary physical examinations to have the back of the application form completed.

It is realized that it is not always possible to have this carried out before September 1st when the children are usually placed in a residential school consequently in such instances, it will be in order to have the physical examinations performed during the month of September or at least
prior to the Principal forwarding the Quarterly Return for payment. By following this procedure the Principal will be in a position to forward his Quarterly Return together with the applications for admission. When these are received the applications will be considered and if admission is approved, the school will be entitled to full grant claimed.

It would be appreciated if you would give this information to Father Tetrault.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

February 14, 1952

Mr. A.R. Nixon,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.,

Your file 106-121/25-2-657

With reference to your letter of February 2nd regarding the admission of the Matachuck and Bird Families to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, it is noted that Irene Rose Bird is no longer at the Muscowequan school and is now attending the Gordon's Day School. In view of this information, no further action is taken on her application for admission to the Muscowequan school.

With reference to Olive Matachuck, it is noted that this girl has been in the Muscowequan school and will now be discharged. In view of this information no action is taken on her application for admission to the Muscowequan school. As the Principal saw fit to admit this girl to the school without first having her admission approved, the Department is not prepared to allow any Per Capita grant for the period this girl was in the Muscowequan school.

With reference to Helen Matachuck, in your letter it is noted you state that it is not possible to place this girl in the Poorman's school as there is no room there. We have checked our records and find the present enrolment at the school is between 37 and 39 and one non-Indian child. In 1950 the enrolment was between 40 and 41. The present average of attendance is 36. In view of the decreased enrolment from last year...
we do not see any reason why this girl can not be placed in the Poorman's school. Please advise.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa.

Upon receipt of your letter of February 14 File 657-10 150-7 (E6), the Muscovequian Residential School was contacted by phone and Helen will not be taken on as a grant earning pupil. They will either leave her in the school for the rest of the year without the grant or take her back to the reserve where she can attend Day School.

A. R. Nixon,
Superintendent.

8. **Matechuck Family** - This family is from the Touchwood Agency in the Province of Saskatchewan and both parents are living. The father has signed an application requesting admission of his children Helen age 8 and Olive age 15 to the Muscovequan (R.C.) Indian residential school.

On the application he has indicated that the religious denomination is Anglican. The Indian Superintendent has recommended the admission of these children to the school.

Except if the mother is of R.C. faith, children who I assume are same religion as of their father should attend Protestant schools. (Sgd) L.F.

Original on 150-7.
January 31, 1952.

Mr. A.R. Nixon,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.,

Re: Matachuck and Bird Families

With reference to the applications for the admission of Olive and Helen Matachuck to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, the applications show the religious denomination as Anglican.

It would be appreciated if you would advise the religious denomination of the mother of these children.

The application form for Irene Rose Bird reads Protestant (Anglican) as the religious denomination.

Please advise the religious denomination of the mother in this case also.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa.

In reply to your letter of January 31, File 657-10, 150-7(E), Father Tetraulx, the principal of Muscovequian Indian Residential School did not intend to take Olive and Helen Mutechuck back to school after Christmas holidays because they were from Protestant parents, and for that reason he had not received the Department Grant for them during the first half of the term when they had been in his school.

There was no room to take these two girls into the Poorman Day School, so I told Mr. Kitella to tell them that I would be going to Prince Albert where the closest Protestant residential school is, on January 20 and would take them with me at that time. As soon as Mr. Kitella told them this they got in their sleigh and drove 25 miles to Lestock, and asked to have their religion changed from Protestant to Catholic so that their children would not have to attend a school so far from home. This I believe has been done and the girls are back in Muscovequian Residential School.

Irene Rose Bird, has not gone back to Muscovequian Residential School, but is attending at Gordon Day School.

Application is herewith attached for Helen Mutechuck. Olive was 16 years on January 28, and will be discharged.

A. R. Nixon
Superintendent.

Onion Lake 19th December 1393

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 631 of the 23rd November.

In reference to halfbreeds attending Onion Lake Protestant School: In conversation with Mr. Matheson last Summer, he asked me if he might take two or three halfbreed children into his school. I recommended that he had better not do so as he had no accommodation for them. He then asked me if the Department had any objections to taking halfbreeds into the school. My answer was that I did not know that they objected providing it did not interfere with the tuition of Indian children.

I do not consider I gave Mr. Matheson authority to take them.

I have &c

(Signed) Geo. G. Mann
Indian Agent

The Indian Commissioner
Regina
Bishop's Point,
Calgary,
Nov. 23, 1854.

My dear Mr. Reed,

How can you send me the last general statement of the plan for our district school?

In a letter recently received from Mr. R. Maclean, O'Brien Lake, he says in reply to questions from me:

Six of our pupils are Indians' treaty children, but none of them although we have had them nearly a year is not allowed to be shown on the Register; nor are we allowed any thing better in rations or clothes for them as they are not of school age. Also you know it is a great advantage to all concerned that the children should be taken from the influence of their own filthy homes at an early age as possible.

Since the S.D., we get as follows: $300 per ann. for teaching, and in the way of rations, one pound of flour per day for each child whose age is shown on register. Also since the first day of last May we received 99½ lbs fresh beef, or as near as possible, one pound of beef for the total number of these children on an average during that time.

Indian Affairs, (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
We also get an allowance of 4 ozs of biscuit every school day, the chief attendants (nothing for Sundays) in the way of clothing we get our little, after 2 yards of cloth (I think) for pants & coat, also 30 yards of ginghams, and 1/2 a cowhide for mocamis, etc all I know, we might have got more in the way of clothes if we begged for it, but I am a poor beggar.

Mr. Matheson is a most excellent and devoted man, he is carrying on the school with great self sacrifice. He does not complain - can any thing more be done for him? If so will you come in direction to that effect?

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 1)

SCHOOL BRANCH.

THIS LETTER HAS BEEN SENT OTTAWA 26th November 1894

My Lord,

I have the honor to inform you that our Agent at Onion Lake, who visited the Day School at Seeskaskootch Reserve on the 25th ultimo reports that he found five children present, that there seemed to be no improvement and that he asked several simple questions in English and could get no reply. The school-room is also reported to be untidy. The average attendance at this school for the past year has been very small (only 6) while little if any progress appears to have been made.

Your obedient servant,

Deputy Supt:Genl:
of Indian Affairs.

His Lordship
The Bishop of Saskatchewan and Calgary
Bishop's Court
Calgary, N.W.T.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 631 of the 22nd ult., referring to the Church of England School in the Onion Lake Agency and in reply to inform you that efforts are being made to obtain sufficient assistance for carrying on the school work in the meantime.

I am informed that a woman has been hired to relieve the teacher in household matters from January 17th, 1895, and give her time to devote to school duties.

Yours obediently,
Signed J. A. MacKay

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
My dear Mr. Head,

On receipt of yours of 26 ult., will therefore return school at Okanagan. I wrote at once to Rev. J.R. Matheson, the missionary in charge and sent him a copy of it. His replies are now before me.

I shall not trouble you by detailing you every detail he says, but shall content myself with giving the substance of it. Apparently, the Agent visited the school on Nov. 26. His first question was put to the young chief as to what was taught there. The boy answered, "We learn English." The Agent then asked, "Well, what's it doing now?" This question was answered by the chief. The Agent then turned to a little boy who had been attending the school for a short time. Asked him what kind of day it is. The answer was "It's cold," said Mr. Matheson, ended the scene of the school.
I make no comment on the matter. I am aware that every since the rebellion it has been a hard struggle to keep the school going and that Mr. Macdonald's efforts all along have not made it easier to carry it on. He has been greatly helped by our late and present missionary if he is, or he should be, most impartial. Mr. Macdonald says "we have not got our last quarter paid yet owing to a mistake. Believe in the return—a mistake forced upon us by the agent who would not take them till the mistake was remedied."

Mayor Mr. Cotton is, I am sure quite fair; if his report is at all like the one then I feel assured there is ground for complaint. Mayor Mr. Cotton knows very well what the great difficulties we have experienced in keeping the school going. We have no right to look for favors from the Dept—but I feel you will want justice done. While I have myself no sympathy with an effort which I feel must under the circumstances fail, I do wish Mr. Macdonald's work were not so much neglected. (He is a sufficient teacher qualified in Manitoba)
to receive justice. And, I understand you have wrote this letter. Mr. Smith wrote Nov. 23rd.

Yours sincerely,

Cynthia Saskatchewan Valley

Harper Reed Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent
Indian Dep't.
Onion Lake Park, Feb. 18

Deputy Dept. Chief of Indians Affairs

Ottawa

Sir,

In this part of the country there is no school for the half-breed or white children, some of them the children of employees of the Indian Dept., and it is impossible for us protestants to form ourselves into a school district, and the parents are too poor to build a school or hire a teacher. Under these circumstances would you kindly give me permission to teach them in the mission buildings on this reserve. I will promise that they will in no way interfere with the work of teaching the Indians' children and you agree here would be able at any time to see that the Indians were not in any way put to a disadvantage by our being allowed this privilege by your Department.

Your obedient servant,

J.R. Matheson

have so this to do I know

1st The great need of a chimney

The mission has already spent $500.00 and I personally have spent $208.00 more, besides my own labor and I am willing to furnish all labor for building a chimney and furnishing a building if your dept will furnish the material & allow me a grant of money and I will buy these things myself.

I would also ask that I be allowed to place the names of those two little children, Sarah Theresa aged 4/12 and Samuel Henry aged 6/12 on the school register and be allowed either the usual grant for them or else be given rations from the agency for them. The boy is not paid treaty money, but she is the daughter of a stone blind squaw & her mother lives at our treaty Indians.
We have kept both these children for two years without a thank (or any help) and would urge your kind consideration of the matter.

It is for the advantage of the children that they should be taken at early age separate from their old association and especially in the case of these two children whose mothers are both unmarried women and one of them perfectly helpless and now the mother of another child.

I will not trouble you about the third matter but would earnestly ask your help in these two cases I have brought to your notice.

Yours obediently,

J.M. MacKenzie
Sir,

Referring to a letter addressed to Superintendent General by Rev. Mr. Matheson asking for certain help in his school, he begs to enclose us to purchase sufficient bricks to build chimneys and paint the buildings. He further agrees to furnish all labour.

Mr. Matheson requests also that chimney be built in which he asks assistance in making bricks. We are hereby authorized to make an issue of one pound of flour and one pound of beef to each.

Kindly advise Rev. Mr. Matheson of action taken.

My Lord,

In reply to your private letter of the 10th ultimo written at Ottawa, I would say that I am instructing our Agent not to ask for the money which was expected to be returned by Mr. Atherton but to write it in his books as having been transferred to the Institution.

MEMORANDUM

Re application of Rev. J.R. Matheson for increased appropriation for Church of England Boarding school at Onion Lake:

Mr Matheson is correct in stating that the Department provides for 50 pupils at the Roman Catholic Boarding school at Onion Lake.

Reports show that there has been considerable jealousy between the two schools and it is a pity that different religious denominations have been permitted to take up mission work on the same reserve.

Apart from the trouble likely to follow from having different religious denominations occupying the same field, there is no reason why Mr Matheson's request should not be complied with.

I wish to ask permission from your department to enrol on register our school, the names of the two children William & Letel Hilton, and that they may be counted as Treaty Indian children in the per capita grant for children attending a boarding school.

These children have been kept these children and given them all the advantages of the home school, as prior to other children in the reserve. Their mother is a Treaty Indian and lives on the reserve with her parents, as her husband has deserted her for more than a year, and is hardly likely ever to return, and why should these poor children be refused the privileges accorded to illegitimate or Treaty Indian women outside men, because their mother had the misfortune to be casually married to a white man?

To my own knowledge the woman was refused permission by the department to abandon her Treaty & to count as a half breed or white woman, although she applied for it more than three years ago.
And the grounds on which her request was refused (and very wisely refused) was that at some future time her husband might desert her, and then she would be in a bad plight and would be outside all help from the department.

Things have turned out as they predicted, and for the simple reason that her children have been born in lawful wedlock. She has hesitated about enrolling them as pupils earning the per capita grant until I had communicated with your department.

Hoping for a favorable answer,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

OTTAWA 6th September, 1898.

The Secretary:

I beg to submit herewith an application from the Rev. J.R. Matheson, Principal of the Church of England Boarding school at Onion Lake, that he be allowed to draw the per capita grant for two half-breed children at present attending the school at Mr Matheson's own expense.

Mr Matheson explains that the parents of the children are William and Ethel Dillon, the father being a white man and the mother a treaty Indian living on the Onion Lake Reserve. The couple were lawfully married, but the husband deserted his wife over a year ago and is not likely ever to return.

Mrs Dillon was refused permission to abandon her treaty relationship and be counted a half-breed or white woman, although she applied for it more than three years ago, her two children are, perhaps, entitled to special consideration.

The per capita allowance for this Protestant school is limited to 15 pupils, and at present there are only 12 children earning the grant; whereas at the Roman Catholic boarding school on the same Reserve, 50 pupils are provided for and 45 are earning the grant.

Sir,

The Rev. J.R. Matheson, Principal of the Church of England Boarding School at Onion Lake, has applied to the Department for authority to enroll on the school register the names of the two children of William and Ethel Dillon and to include them among the earners of the per capita grant.

CANADA
Dear Sir,

I have written Mr. Laird, Indian Commissioner, today regarding a grave difficulty which faces every Indian school teacher or principal in North-West Canada. That is, the impossibility to persuade a copy of the Indian parents' heads their children to school.

On this reserve & Agency I can easily find about eighty (80) children of school age. (Perhaps one hundred would be much nearer the truth.) In some cases the parents of these children get their weekly rations from the department stores. The teacher or missionary is utterly powerless in the matter of persuading or forcing the parents to send their children to school. The Indians either simply laugh, or point blank refuse; or in some instances take the children away, a copy their own.
away after they have been in school for some time and all efforts to get them back are utterly futile. The teacher or principal here is simply at the mercy of any Squaw or Indian who wishes to take a child away.

It has happened often in this school, and either the authorities are afraid to enforce the law or there is no law for them to enforce. Which is it? Our schools are languishing for want of scholars, there are bands of children running all over the reserve, 3 school age. Parents or others can beat a boy away a child from school & refuse to bring it back, and without a request for assistance from the authorities, having the child back is either refused outright, or only grudgingly thereafter performed. In fact they tell us plainly to go to magistrate sooner or a warrant and take all responsibility yourself. Providing a Dominion Police man or other party after the child, and in every way show that they do not want to take any steps in the matter. Have we no authority in the matter? Is the Act Regulations relating to the Education of Indian Children
as passed by the Governor General and Council Nov 18th 1894, & especially Clause 12 so substituted or enacted April 1st 1895, copies which were sent me by the Indian Department at that time, a dead letter or are we supposed, or allowed to put them in force?

Surely if compulsory education is good for the white race it ought also for the Indians; and if it is necessary to compel white people, by law, send their children to work it is much more as well regard Indians, who cannot be supposed to judge for their selves, and whose whole upbringing for generations has been wholly without educational advantage.

The Indians know full well we are unable, from some cause or another, to compel them send their children to school and they take very good care to show us that we cannot do so. I plead not only in my own name but in the name of every man who has anything to do with the education of Indian children, that something definite be done in this matter.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

With regard to the case of children who have been placed in your school and desert, I beg to refer you to the amendment to the regulations relating to the education of Indian children, a copy of which is enclosed herewith, from which you will see that if any child in an industrial or boarding school leaves without authorized permission or any child who has been allowed out fails to return, the Principal or any officer of such school may apply to an Agent or Justice of the Peace for the issue of a warrant authorising such child to be taken back and replaced in the school. Sir,

Last August I made application to your Commission in Winnipeg, for permission to take as pupils of this school, drawing the per capita grant from the Indian Department, certain non-Indian children. I name the names of ten children, some of whom I got from among the Indians, and nearly all of whom are children of Indian mothers, and have been left orphans, or were twin orphans, by the death of their mother by their father, after living with the woman for years. Their case is really pitiful. They are waifs & outcasts among the Indians and have none to care for or provide for them.

They are in most cases illegitimate, and unless some institution takes them up to care for them, they will undoubtedly form part of our criminal class in the near future.

There, at anyone's expense, as is well known, care for and education there for where admission has been refused, for some years, but the load is getting very heavy for me. Mr. Laird has definitely refused to admit any one of the ten names submitted to him to be enrolled as pupils drawing any grant from the Department.

I readily grant he is perfectly justified in doing so, on the ground that your department is only responsible for the education & care of Indian children, and have nothing to do with illegitimate waifs, or half breed children.

March 19th

I do not claim that these children have any legal claim on your department. I ask it only, and entirely, as an act of mercy or charity on your part. They are to turn up there who are, to all intents and purposes, Indian children and needing the protection; but through no fault of their own are cast among the Indians, without any of the privileges and advantages given to Indians.

Now what I ask is this, that I be permitted by your department to place on the school register, as Indian children drawing the annual grant allowed to our Boarding School, five of the number at present in this school. I am allowed to draw the grant for twenty pupils, but find it impossible at present to obtain near that number of Indian children.

Promise that as soon as I can get an Indian child proper to put in the place of any one of them, that I will immediately take the name of the non-Indian child off the register and replace it with that of the Indian child, so this is first for me an Indian child, and in all cases preference must be given to Indian children.

I do not often trouble your department for favors or help, and I do assure you that this case is one of great necessity, and if you can by any means make an exception in this case, it will be not only a help tome in this work, but a blessing and help to the children as deeply concerned. At another time I send the names and history, as near as I can, of some of the children.

Yours respectfully,

History: The Cotrell children's mother was an Indian woman belonging to the Bear Hill Indians, who lived with a white man named McDaniel, a tailor, who deserted her vacant to the United States, after which another white man named Cotrell, lived with her till she died, on or near the reserve about four years ago. Cotrell had the children baptized, hence the names, but he actively deserted them, as they were not his, and the mother had died. I do not know where Cotrell is now but think he has left the country entirely. Joseph and Maria Gladien were put by myself among the Moore lake Indians. Their mother was a woman belonging to the pasteur band, but she is dead, and the half breed father lives with the Indians and has another wife. I understand that Joseph Gladien's father was a full blood Indian but can find no trace of him.
History of non-Indian children

Horrie Anderson, father and mother both dead. Her father was an Indian belonging to the Saddle Lake or Victoria Indians, and her mother was a half breed woman who used to live in Victoria Park.

William Fuller, father a renegade half breed who lives out south somewhere, mother unknown, now dead, but who belonged to Pakans or Kâkîs band.

Ottawa, February 31, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to the removal of children from boarding or industrial schools by their parents at any time, I beg to say that Indian children once admitted, either under the regulations passed by His Excellency the Governor General in Council by virtue of Sections 137 and 138, 57 and 58 Vic., or with the consent of their parents, cannot be removed without the permission of the Superintendent General, as by an amendment to the regulations, dated April 1, 1896, Sec. 12 was repealed and the following sub-section substituted therefor—(Regulations and amendment herewith).

This amendment provides that, should any child in an industrial or boarding school leave such school without permission of the Superintendent General, the Assistant Indian Commissioner, or of the Principal of the school, or should any child who has been allowed out fail to return at the stipulated time, an Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace shall, on information made to that effect by any Officer of the school, issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein to search for and take such child back to and again place it in the school in which it had been placed as aforesaid. But notwithstanding anything in this section, it shall be competent for any employee of the Indian Department, or any constable to arrest any child found in the act of escaping from any industrial or boarding school and to convey such child to the school from which it escaped.
I consider that this amended clause would justify any Principal in refusing to allow a Parent to remove his child without permission.

P. S. There is nothing on file to show that Mr. Agent Sibbald had any authority for making the statement attributed to him by the Rev. Mr. Matheson, Principal of the Onion Lake Boarding School, that Indian children could be taken from school at any time by their parents. In fact the correspondence shows that the Agent was to be instructed to withhold rations from the Parents of children at home who are fit to attend school but are not sent. These instructions were sent to the Indian Commissioner on April 30, last, and I think it would be well to ask him for a copy of his letter to Mr. Agent Sibbald on this subject. As I have pointed out above, the regulations prohibit the removal of a child without permission from an industrial or boarding school.
Ottawa, April 6, 1906.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Rev. Mr. Matheson, Principal of the Onion Lake school, applies for permission to enroll six or eight non-treaty children. This school is allowed 20 pupils, but his last return shows that he had only 13 Indian children on the roll. He has a large number of half-breeds and non-treaty children that he has kept at his own expense, and as he is experiencing difficulty in filling up his school with Indian children he wishes to draw the grant for the children named in the list he has forwarded. These are all illegitimate half-breeds, who have been living on the reserve and brought up as Indians. They are not, under the Commissioner's ruling, entitled to be considered grant-earners at the school.

The case of these children is peculiarly hard, as most of them are orphans, children of Indian mothers by white or half-breed fathers, who deserted them. Mr. Matheson says they are waifs and outcasts among the Indians and have none to care or provide for them, and unless some institution takes them up they will undoubtedly form part of our criminal class in the near future.

While the action of the Commissioner in refusing to place them on the roll as grant-earners appears to be justified from his standpoint, it is a question whether the broad ruling of the late Minister in his memorandum of October 18, 1899, would not permit of an exception being made in favour of children of this par-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
ticular class. His memorandum is as follows:

"The Indian Commissioner is to be informed, in reply to his letter of the 18th ult., that I have given the subject referred to therein careful consideration, and that I cannot approve of the absolute rule which he has laid down that none but treaty children are to be admitted to Indian schools. A well defined line can be drawn between Halfbreeds, properly speaking, and Indians. While I do not consider that the children of the Halfbreeds proper of Manitoba and the Territories should be admitted into Indian schools and paid for by the Department, I am decidedly of the opinion that all children, even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not, who live upon an Indian reserve and whose parents on either side live as Indians upon a Reserve, even if they are not annuitants, should be eligible for admission to the schools. It must be remembered that boarding and industrial schools were not established for the purpose of carrying out the terms of the treaty or complying with any provision of the law, but were instituted in the public interest, so that there should not grow up upon reserves an uneducated and barbarous class. The North West Government cannot provide for the education of non-annuitants upon reserves; and if we exclude them from our schools, they will practically be barred from all means of education."

Since the date of that memorandum, the new provincial governments have been established, and although they have no institutions for the care of
orphans and neglected children in operation as yet, I think that the Rev. Mr. Matheson might make application to the local government of the province to which these children belong for a grant to assist them in maintaining them at the school, notwithstanding the memorandum above quoted it would appear to be a bad policy on the part of this Department to in any way put a premium on illegitimacy.

Sir,

It has been reported to the Department that the Agent recently stated to the Indians of the Onion Lake agency that they had a right to take their children from school whenever they so desired. No letter has been sent to Agent Sibbald from this Department which would justify any such statement; in fact the correspondence shows that he was to be instructed to withhold rations from the parents of children at home who are fit to attend school but are not sent, as you will see by reference to a letter addressed to you on April 30, last.

The Department would like to have a copy of the instructions sent Agent Sibbald by you. The amendment to Sec. 13 of the regulations would justify any principal in refusing to allow a parent to remove his child without permission, and the Department does not wish the Indians to think otherwise.

Ottawa, February 28, 1907.

Sir,

It has been reported to the Department that you recently stated to the Indians of the Onion Lake agency that they had a right to take their children from school whenever they so desired.

I have to request you to be good enough to send in to the Department a copy of any letter received by you which would justify you in making such a statement, if this report is correct, as there is nothing on file here to show that any such authority was ever given you. In fact, the correspondence shows the contrary.

The amendment to clause 13 of the regulations would justify any principal in refusing to allow a parent to remove his child from any boarding or industrial school without permission, and the Department does not wish the Indians to become possessed of the idea that they can remove their children when they please, as it is contrary to the purpose for which these schools were established and subversive of all discipline.

Your obedient Servant,

M.D. McLean,
Secretary.

W. Sibbald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.
Sir,

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo re information received by the Department to the effect that the Agent recently stated to the Indians of the Onion Lake Agency that they had a right to take their children from school whenever they so desired. I cannot from correspondence here make out what this refers to, but I feel fairly sure that the Indian Agent did not convey such information, or at least cannot quote my authority therefor. Such instructions would be against the Department's policy, and I never meant to convey any such meaning.

However, a misconception may have been created among the Indians by the conduct of one of them. This one has been having too much his own way, and I gave instructions to the Indian Agent, copy of which letter of the 28th of November last is enclosed. The case referred to was about some pupils retained home by parents without permission and as such considered as deserters.

I may also quote an extract from a letter dated the 21st, Feb. 1906 from myself to the Principal of the Onion Lake C.E. School in a similar case. "As regards deserters the regulations devolve it upon you to put the law in motion". This refers to section 12 of the School Regulations, where some officer of the school must lay the information necessary for the issue of a warrant to take back an absentee without leave from the school.

Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
While an Indian Agent can issue a warrant if such information is made to him by an officer of the school, I do not consider he can be called upon to employ constables to take back deserters to school, unless they are in the very act of escaping, without the proper information has been made and a warrant issued.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.
Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant respecting the Badger children. I very much regret the trouble that has arisen about their attendance at the R.C. School. In my letter of the 16th October expressing a trust that they would soon be returned to school, I scarcely meant that you were to use the Police; but only your best influence.

From the notes of statements made by the Indians before you on the 8th instant I feel that, if true, they have some reason to complain of the treatment the pupils receive in school. Not only putting the boys to help at washing, overworking young girls when nearing maturity, but the ear-twisting for punishment should be dropped, the latter absolutely. When the children have sore necks or are tender about the throat, this sort of punishment is cruel.

I think it would be well to call the meeting of Indians you propose, speak to them in a persuasive manner, assure them the overwork and ear-twisting will be discontinued, and tell them the Indian Commissioner and the Department are most anxious that they should send their children to school.

Section 7 of the School Regulations does not apply to Boarding Schools. Sections 9, 12, and 13 principally apply to taking and keeping Indian children of school age in Boarding Schools. We do not wish to apply force, if we can avoid it; yet we urge them to send their healthy children to be educated. The Government has helped the Indians a good deal, and they ought to listen to its advice, and give their children a chance not only to speak, read, and write English, but also the girls to cook and sew, and the boys to garden and tend cattle.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent,
Onion Lake Agency.

Indian Commissioner.

(Signed) D. Laird,

Ref. Your Letter 24 Feb. 1906, No. I22/63

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter quoted, and in reply to inform you that it is true in many cases both the Principals of the two schools here and myself fail to get the parents to send their children to school, while in other cases the children are readily given.

You are however misinformed if you are led to believe that many of the parents who do not send their children to school receive regular rations from the Department. There are 12 heads of families altogether who have children fit to be admitted to school, of whom 3 receive rations regularly, a widow, an aged man, and a man becoming blind, 3 receive rations frequently and 6 very seldom, only when really in want.

There are a number of Indians at Island Lake who draw treaty, but receive no help from the Department, they live by hunting and fishing and have a good many children of school age, and again at Long Lake there are a few children of school age, but the parents are self-supporting.

Since your letter was written, two applications for admission to the R.C. School have been sent you and today I have had the promise of another.

It would be well I think if you would instruct me not to give assistance in the way of food or clothing to any who have children of school age, not attending school, leaving me some discretionary power where circumstances are pressing.

Hon. David Laird,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,
(signed) W. Sibbald, Indian Agent.

Sir,

The Boarding Schools in your Agency experience great difficulty in securing recruits among the Indians on the Reserves, although, as I am informed, there are many Treaty children of school age on the reserves, who are receiving no education because their parents neglect to send them to school.

Many of these Indians who are neglectful about the education of their children are, I understand, in receipt of rations supplied by the Department. In your opinion, would it be judicious for pressure to be brought upon these Indians, to induce them to do their duty in the above respect, by informing them that as the Department is anxious that their healthy children of school age should be in school, that unless such children, for whose support at home rations are in part supplied, are sent to some school of their own choice, the rations to such families will be cut down or entirely withheld?

Be good enough to answer at an early date according to your best judgment.

Yours truly,

(signed) D. Laird,
Indian Commissioner.

Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 20th February last instructing me to inquire of the Indian Agent at Onion Lake if something might be done to induce Indians of that Agency who have children fit to attend school, and receive rations, to send their children to school, I beg to enclose copy of a letter I addressed to the said Agent and of his reply thereto.

You will observe from the Agent's letter that only twelve heads of families receiving rations have children fit to be admitted to school.

It appears to me that the Department might properly instruct the Agent to withhold rations from such parents for the children at home who are fit to attend school, but are not sent thereto. This is a hardship of which they could relieve themselves by complying with the wish of the Department and sending their children to the school of their choice where they would be fed and clothed.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, April 9, 1907.

Rev. Sirs—

With reference to your verbal statement, made in February, last, to the Deputy Superintendent General of this Department, that the Agent at Onion Lake had said at a meeting of the Indians that they had the right to take their children from school whenever they so desired, I beg to say that both the Agent and the Indian Commissioner, who were written in reference to this matter, state positively that they never conveyed any such idea to the Indians.

The regulations relating to the education of Indian children are very plain in regard to this, and any Principal would be justified in refusing a parent to remove his child from any boarding or industrial school without permission, and the Department has been careful not to allow the Indians to become possessed of the idea that they can remove their children when they please, as it is contrary to the purpose for which these schools were established and subversive of all discipline.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Rev. J. R. Matheson,
Principal,
Onion Lake (C.E.) Boarding School,
Onion Lake, Sask.
Dear Sir,

April 9th, 1877

I am indeed glad to hear that you have made a strong impression in regard to the matter of the Indians having rights to move their children from school when they please. I certainly understand distinctly that that was the gist of what you said at their meeting. It was just simply told that at their meeting, it was just simply told that the interpreter, Mr. Wilson, did not understand what Mr. Wilson said, or he deliberately misconstrued the interpreter's words.

I believe that interpreter was quite capable of making such "mistakes," and the fact that he is no longer interpreter for your agent, gives great satisfaction to all of us here.

The Indians spoke their minds, and wished me interpreter for them because they said they "knew their words were not rightly interpreted."

There is very little danger of any mistakes being made with the present interpreter.

Sincerely thanking you for the trouble you took in this matter, and knowing now our real position we stand in regard to the children.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Sir,

Referring to my letter of March 8th, ult.

I have the honour to inform you that I have learned from the Principal of the Church of England school, that he is the person who reported to the Department, that I had told the Indians, that they had a right to take their children from school, whenever they so desired; and that he has recently received a letter from the Department on the subject, and that he has replied to same.

It appears to me that the Rev. Principal is inclined to lead the Department to believe, that a misunderstanding may have arisen thro' misinterpreting, either accidently or purposely. However in duty to the interpreter and myself, it is right to inform you, that such in my opinion, is not the case, and the Rev. Father Cunningham, who was present at the meeting - when I spoke to the Indians on the subject - states that I did not say anything that would lead the Indians to have any such impression.

Father Cunningham, who speaks Cree perfectly, also states that nothing was interpreted incorrectly, and that if any serious mistake, such as the one implied had been made, he would not have let it pass without some remark. I may add that Mr. Matheson was not present at that meeting.

I have the honour to be

Principal of the C.of E Boarding School and Mission on this Onion Lake reserve has entered into some arrangement with a man named Leyde to take charge of the Mission stables and make a regular charge for feed and stabling for the public. Dear Mr. Lean,

The management of the East School has been recently disturbed by the illness of the Rev. Principal, Mr. Matheson. The circumstances are such that I think it better to report unofficially.

Mr. Matheson left here about Aug. 14th, as I understand, for Edmonton, suffering in his usual health, at least so far as those outside the mission could judge. I heard nothing more about him until Saturday, 26th Aug., when I learned that Dr. Matheson, his wife, had received a telegram from him, from Winnipeg, saying that he had to undergo an operation on the eye. Dr. Matheson consequently started, in short notice, for Lloydminster to take train for Winnipeg. Enquiries made by wire from here revealed that Matheson had left Winnipeg for Rochester Hospital, Minnesota, and had started before Dr. Matheson reached Winnipeg. That is the last I have heard of Dr. Matheson and it is surmised that she has followed her husband to the hospital; he evidently does not know that his wife has followed him because the last mail received here in 2nd Inst. brought a post card from the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
hospital, addressed by him to his wife to the effect that he would shortly undergo the operation.

I am somewhat in the dark as to the actual position but his having had to go on from Winnipeg to Red River hospital makes things look serious.

With regard to the school and mission Mr. Matheson (35) has left a trustworthy woman in charge, Mrs. Broubridge, the wife of a settler in the neighborhood, and a new teacher has been engaged for the school, Joseph Chamberlain by name, an ex-pupil of the Battleford Industrial School. The pupils had hardly all reassembled after the summer holidays, when Mr. Matheson seems to have realized his condition. Now there are only 3 Indian children attending, besides these there are 11 non-Indian children attending. I trust however that Mr. Matheson's condition is not so serious as it would seem to be and that in his case Dr. Maclean's return matters will be in better order.

I have had no information except what I have gathered by inquiring at the mission and of others.

W. H. Gibbald

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 30th September, 1912, addressed to Mr. H. Sir,

His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan has recommended the closing of the Onion Lake (C.E.) school and the substitution therefor of an improved day school where a teacher and a field matron would be employed, as is done in a number of other instances.

The Department would like to have your opinion as to the probability of the success of a day school at this point. You should report on the number of children of school age, the distances they reside from the school and give such other information as you can regarding the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Onion Lake, Sask.
Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of Aug. 26th, No. 1175557 regarding the question of substituting an improved day school for the present Church of England Boarding School.

Before expressing a positive opinion on the matter, I would like to be clear upon the manner in which the improved day schools are conducted. The only information I have regarding them is that contained in your letter of Oct. 19th, No. 304033 but in that letter nothing is said about a "field test." I have not until today had a prospect of speaking with Mr. Maclean, the Principal of the existing boarding school, about this proposed change in schools, he also is ignorant as to the management of these and is unable to express an opinion. I would be glad if you would kindly advise me with regard to the manner in which they are conducted.

You will remember that the
Indians of Keku were recommended Long Lake have frequently petitioned for a day school but have not received any encouragement of late towards getting one. Not long ago I met His Lordship Bishop Lefebvre in conversation with whom he spoke unfavourable of the day schools and as you know he encouraged the opening of one at Keku Reserve. Often it must not be forgotten that a fairly successful R.C. Boarding school exists at Onion Lake which would not be benefited by the opening of a day school at Keku.

It does not follow however that an improved day school at Onion Lake would not be better for the reserve than the existing R.C. Boarding School. Though it behooves us to take any steps in the best interest of the Indians with the best intentions now I can speak with the Indians whose feeling in the case favor. I think should be recognized but before doing so would like to understand the nature of the proposed day school.

I am

Your obedient servant,

W.O. Baldwin
Indian Agent

P.S. Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Oct.

Ottawa, September 24, 1913.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant in reference to the proposed substitution of an improved day school for the boarding school at Onion Lake.

In reply I beg to say that in most cases the principle of the improved day school embodies the engagement of a teacher and a field matron, preferably, if obtainable, a married couple, the teacher to confine his duties to the class-room work and the field matron to the teaching of the principles of domestic science, simple rules of health, home management, etc., to the pupils and in the homes of the Indians on the reserve. In the diocese of the Bishop of Saskatchewan there are several schools conducted in this way and they have proved quite successful. I might mention John Smiths, James Smiths, Sturgeon Lake and Ahtahkakoops and in the near future Red Pheasants and Little Pines. At the reserves just mentioned the Department has provided or is providing residences for the teachers as well as suitable class-room accommodation and in some instances where it is absolutely necessary transport of the children to school, particularly during inclement weather.

Your obedient servant,

W. Sibbald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

meet the views of the department. It is my impression that these improved day schools are not conducted in close connection with an established mission; that is, the mission has nothing to do with the management of the school beyond taking a natural interest in an institution under the auspices of the church it represents.

I enclose a list of children who may be looked upon as likely pupils for a day school, but would point out that the distance, in many instances, from their homes to the present boarding school, is considerable; some six, some five miles; for instance, the first four are 6 miles in one direction; two of the Roman Catholics are 5 miles in another, and the four referred to in third paragraph - two 78/119 and two 72/119 - are each family 6 miles distant in different directions. It would mean at least the engaging of three teams daily, unless some would supply their own conveyance.

A most important phase in the whole matter that must not be overlooked, is that frequently many of these families are away from the reserve, hunting and on other pursuits taking their families with them; so that a very regular attendance could not be looked for. Under the circumstances I think it is very questionable if a day school would be as successful as a boarding school properly conducted.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 24th ultimo, No.117555/1, and to report as follows:

I arranged for a meeting of the Protestant Indians of Onion Lake reserve on Saturday the 18th instant for the purpose of speaking about the establishment of an improved day school on the reserve, to take the place of the present boarding school. Very few, however, attended and some of the information I have gathered from conversing separately with those that did not attend.

I have had the promise of 10 boys and 3 girls - Protestant children - and 1 boy and 3 girls, Roman Catholic children; besides these 2 Protestant (Meeseehow 78/119) and 2 Roman Catholic (Pahtaykan 72/119) children that very probably would attend. There are also three children, Alice Faithful, Agnes Waskahat and Annie Mathias, from Frog Lake, now at the boarding school, which the principal would be willing to arrange still to clothe and board at the C. of E. Right Reverend Sir,

In Your Lordship's letter of the 4th of August, 1913, you recommended the closing the Onion Lake (C.E.) Boarding School and opening it as an improved day school.

The Department is now in receipt of a report from Mr. Inspector Chisholm in which he says that, owing to his advancing years and failing health, Mr. Matheson, the Principal, is anxious to be relieved of the care of the institution. The Inspector states that, in view of the difficulty in obtaining another competent man to carry on this institution, it would probably be best that it should be conducted as a day school.
