PRINCE ALBERT, SASK.

July 22nd, 1914

Dear Sir,

In reply to your question as to closing Clear Lake Boarding School and opening it as an improved day-school:

1. Mr. Matheson is quite incapable of work, and the school is almost a farce. He should be retired as soon as possible, but he is a worthy man, sensitive, and has done long and arduous work so that he should be dealt kindly with.

2. The school should be closed, and an improved day-school opened.

3. All the property—trees, buildings, stock, etc., is valuable, belonging to Mr. Matheson or Bishop Church of England.

Yours truly,

J. A. Saskatchewan Bishop

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am sorry that I forgot one matter which I wished to mention to you when I was with you the other day. It is about the closing of the Onion Lake Boarding School and the opening of a day school instead. When the I.D. spoke of doing this both Archdeacon Mackay and myself agreed that it might well be done, because the school was not sufficiently staffed and had a very small list of pupils. The I.D. has not notified myself or Rev. J. R. Matheson as to an indefinite date of closing. The I.D. wished me to call on Mr. Matheson to resign. I have not done so, and I took ground that it is not my duty to do so. When the I.D. finally closes the school, that will naturally do away with any need for resignation. Considering Mr. Matheson's age, and the faithful work he has done for many years, I did not feel that I could ask him to resign. I have had the school and mission visited and inspected lately, with the result that I would ask for further consideration, or delay, in closing the boarding school, for the following reasons:

1. Mr. Matheson is in very bad health and cannot possibly continue to hold the position very long; meanwhile it would break his heart, and probably really kill him to close the school.

2. There are now seventeen pupils on the roll, and more expected. The Indians are beginning to value the school more than they did.

3. The staff is now ample for that number of pupils, and more efficient than for some years past. Miss Cunningham, the teacher, did very good work for us formerly at Lac la Rouge school. She also takes some of the supervision of the school. There is also a trained nurse there, assisting in the work of the school. There are also a man and his wife, the man looking after the out of doors or farm work, and his wife taking charge of the laundry. In addition they have the services of Mr. Matheson's eldest daughter, who has had experience in various branches of school work for some years.

I would ask you to recommend to the I.D. that the closing of the boarding school be dropped for the present. It is the only residential school in all that portion of Saskatchewan, and if the present rate of teachers and pupils be kept up, the I.D. might wait at least until they see what is being done next summer.

Commending this to your kindest consideration, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

J. A. Saskatchewan

Bishop.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the suggestion contained in the letter from His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan that the Onion Lake (O.E.) Boarding School should not be closed for the present I beg to say that, for the reasons stated in His Lordship's letter, I consider the Department would be quite justified in acceding to his request.

Rev. Mr. Matheson, the Principal of the school, has devoted the best portion of his life to Indian work and is deserving of consideration. Mr. Inspector Chisholm's last report on this school shows that there were eighteen pupils present, which is the number now enrolled. Although Mr. Matheson is not by any means as energetic in his management as he once was fair work is being done and Mr. Chisholm's reason for recommending the conversion of this school into a day school was that it is doubtful whether another competent man to replace Mr. Matheson could be found to take it. Mr. Agent Sibbald in his report on the proposed change, made a year ago, points out the difficulty in securing a regular attendance at the day school.
school on account of the distance the children live from the school. He says that it would mean at least the engagement of three teams daily, unless the pupils supplied their own conveyances, and also that many families are away from the reserve, hunting among other pursuits, taking their children with them, so that a very irregular attendance would have to be looked for.

In view of these conditions I think the boarding school might be continued, as they have a competent staff and the school is economically managed.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I had hoped to visit Ottawa & have a talk with you, the most satisfactory way; but as I can not do so I must write. It is about the future of the Union Lake School.

Rev. J.R. Matheson is helpless upon his bed, will never again be able to do any work. His wife & Miss Cunningham with the staff are carrying on the school. The school is full & they could take nine children if allowed, but the grant is only for 30. But Miss carrying on the work by women only & without a responsible head is not satisfactory. I am just waiting to see if Mr. Matheson is taken to his long & last home, as I do not wish to spoil the peace of his last days by turning him out, or letting him know that others must take his place. But I am looking about & inquiring as to a suitable sub-

But before I can take any action I must know what the S.D. intends to do. Are you willing to keep the school on as a Residential school, or do you intend to keep only a day school? I have had occasion to change my mind as to the need, after my last visit to the school & the Indians of the surrounding Reserves.

CANADA
Frog Lake is the only one of the large group that has a day-school & many of the children there live too far to attend it. The Indians of Frog Lake, Island Lake, etc., begged me to have the Residential School maintained. We have some children from Thunder Child's could get more. I am not very keen about Residential schools but it would seem advisable at Onim Lake unless the S.D. will multiply the Day-schools, & give more encouragement & help for the children to attend.

2. If you keep it on as a Residential School there must be certain new conditions before I can accept the charge. (a) All these years the S.D. has had the use of our Bldgs. without any Charge— I believe the S.D. spent a little, a very little on them. (b) Then Mr. Matheson has always maintained that the grant of $100 per head, for only 30 children was quite insufficient, that he has every year spent a lot of his own money on the work, besides all the money that the Church spent.

(a) I think that the S.D. should either buy the bldgs. or pay a liberal rent. Best to buy them, then alter & add to them to bring them up to the standard you want. I am told that your Inspector said that they were almost what was needed, that it would not take much to make them quite so. (b) I think that there should be a more liberal treatment in per Cap. grant, more pupils allowed & the grant $120.
You doubtless know that Rev. J. R. Matheson has always been hard to handle, so that it was impossible to get full accurate financial statements. But at any rate he did the work, kept the school going out of debt, claims were partly with his own money. In the same way he & his wife claim that they found nearly all the money for the various buildings, so that in consequence nearly all the property is theirs. We on our side, though we may object somewhat to this claim have nothing to say against it. I do not think they intend to claim eventually much of the property, but to make it over to the Church Board; but they state that they can claim it. This will perhaps somewhat mix things if we keep on the school, & the S.D. does not buy the property. The kernel of the matter is that the Church settled down there long ago, so that they had a claim on the land has been virtually allowed. That the S.D. has spent little or nothing all these years beyond the per Cap. grant. That the Church has carried on the work, & desires now to be relieved of the part of the burden that it ought not to have to carry. I should like as full an answer as possible, as to what the S.D. will do.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,
J. A. Saskatchewan

March 14th, 1916.

Dear Bishop Newnham -

I beg to refer to your Lordship's communication of January 27th, last, regarding the Onion Lake Church of England Boarding School. I was very sorry to learn of Mr. Matheson's precarious condition.

I have given careful consideration to the suggestions made by your Lordship and would state at the outset that I consider it would be well to continue this institution as a residential school.

I find upon reference to our files that the land on which the buildings are situated and that used in connection with the school belong to the reserve. No surrender was ever made and consequently no transfer to the church, which has only the usual right of occupancy.

It would not be possible for the Department to purchase the buildings or pay a rental for them; this school is in exactly the same relation to the Department as many other schools in the west, managed under the auspices of one or other of the religious Denominations.

Right Rev. J. A. Newnham, D.D.,
Prince Albert, Sask.
We are prepared, however, to continue the grant at the present rate for the full number of pupils for which there is accommodation, namely, 30. Under existing conditions the school cannot be graded otherwise than in Class C, for which the grant limit is $100.00 per capita per annum.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Report of Inspector Crombie on the Onion Lake C.E.Bdg. School.

MANAGEMENT,

It will be noted that there has been increased enrolment during the past year. The management and supervision owing to the continued sickness of Rev. Mr. Matheson is entirely looked after by Mrs. Matheson, who also acts as doctor at Onion Lake reserve. MEMO re ONION LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL

We are met with an immense financial problem at the very start of this school under new auspices.

(1) This school has been erected and maintained for 15 years without, (I believe) any grant from the I.D. towards erection, maintenance in repair, purchase of live stock for farmland gardenland equipment for ditto. The I.D. has had the use of this without any rent being paid. The amount received per capita grant was for many years very small, and only this year reached 30 pupils or $3,000.

It is plain then that the Church, or someone acting for the Church, has for 15 years carried a load which belonged to the I.D.

(2) The Church as a Corporation could do, and did, comparatively little for these buildings and stock. Various Churchmembers may have contributed at times; but Rev. J.R. Matheson was responsible for the revenue and expenditure, he never once called on the I.D. to pay his deficit or overdraft, but put his own personal income and earnings into the School property for the time being. Neither the Church nor the I.D. had a right to expect him to do this. We owe a debt to his family.

(3) On the death of the Rev. J.R. Matheson, the widow consented to carry on the school till I could find a successor. I have only lately done so, a Mr. and Mrs. Ellis, with some little previous experience in Alberta Indian School, and Mrs. Matheson has resigned, and is handing over the premises and management to us.

The School will henceforth be managed in a more orthodox manner according to I.D. rules and regulations. Previously, in view of the fact that Mr. Matheson was finding the finances, and that no one else could have run the school without greater aid from the I.D. and Church, he was allowed a pretty free hand by us.

Now Mr. Ellis is responsible to the I.D., and also to myself and my committee, and the usual returns must be kept and rendered.

I believe Indian Agent Sibbald and his Assist. Mr. Turner are inclined to have confidence that Mr. Ellis will make good, if he has half
The buildings are

(a) the original house, for Principal, some of staff, dining rooms and kitchen and girl's dormitory.

(b) the new building, class rooms, boys' dormitory, and the rest of the staff.

(c) a neat little hospital, where Mrs. (Dr.) Matheson attended sick pupils, or sick Indians.

(d) Two (I think) stovesheds; woodsheds &c; stables and barn &c.

Mrs. Matheson desires for herself and family some reasonable compensation for b, c, d, (above) and for live stock. I think we must admit this to some extent, as I have said above.

Further, while I believe that your Inspector approved of the buildings, in many respects, as complying with I.D. regulations, yet the following are absolutely required at once:

entire new floors (on ground floor)

furnace for big building and

storm-sashes (double windows) throughout.

You will note that all this expected outlay coming now is really an accumulation of what should have been done or paid for during past years.

I am prepared to take a good deal of risk and responsibility in reopening this school along the lines I have mentioned. I could not bear to think of closing a school which is so much needed.

Our Indians beg me not to let it be closed. I believe we can fill it up to the 56 pupils allowed. Of course our Roman Catholic neighbours who have lots of money, are waiting to pounce on our children if we step out. I am prepared to make a stiff effort to keep the school open at the $110 per capita grant, calling on the Church to do what the I.D. grant fails to do. Mr. and Mrs. Ellis are prepared to take hold cautiously, to begin slowly and self-denyingly, and to risk their reputation as managers and workers. And the Church and the Indians look to me to do this. But I have not, and the Diocese of

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Saskatchewan has not the money (about $5,000 perhaps) required to recoup the Matheson family, to carry out the alterations and repairs, and to provide stock of groceries, &c., to begin work with. I am appealing strenuously and persistently to friends and Churches in Eastern Canada, and may get some relief perhaps.

But I do feel it is up to the I.D. to stand by us, and to take a share in the load. And, I ask you, my dear Sir, to advise me how I can best put this before the Authorities with a view to winning them to make a grant. I know what you're "up against"; but you see what I'm up against. Tell me

(1) what to ask for,
(2) of whom to ask if, and
(3) how best to set forth the above need.

But further than that, I want to ask you, Mr. Scott,

(1) Will you authorise (and instruct the new Principal accordingly) a payment of a certain proportion of the per capita grant each month as you have done to other schools. I believe that you have sometime paid per cap. $10 first month, $10 second month, and $5 for third (final) month each quarter ($25 per quarter for $100 per cap.)

If you will do this for us it will help a little.

(2) Will you kindly inform me whether the I.D. has really consented to allow Onion Lake the $116 per cap. grant up to 55 pupils? I am told it is so, but can't find any formal notification.

(3) Is it absolutely impossible for us to get a title to the 35 or 40 acres we occupy? About two or three years ago I understood that the I.D. and the Land Department had agreed that we could have Title, and I remember well the Land Department telling me that it would instruct its surveyors to survey and mark out our piece. The Indians would willingly give us Title. It is difficult to get Church people to heartily build and support bldgs. on land not our own.

(4) Can you without much worry or labour find out how Mr. J.R. Matheson obtained Title to a Ranch he used for the school (for stock)? I can't give you sec. R.Tp. &c., but it was only a few miles outside of the Reserve, and I believe he could tell you whether...
he bought it from the Government, or obtained it as a grant.

These four pages of Memo on Onion Lake School are earnestly commended to your consideration, and your advice is awaited.

J.A. [Signature]

Dear Mr. Scott,

I bring the following under your notice hoping that the S.D. may see their way to some action which will prevent such miscarriage of justice, & assist in the moral reform of our First pupils.

Mr. Ellis, Principal of Qu'Appelle Boarding School, writes that last Oct. he had to be absent for 3 or 4 days, leaving the school in the charge of Miss Cunningham, experienced & faithful. During his absence a young R.C. Indian tried seven 3 girl pupils, for immoral purposes. The police were informed & brought the girls back after they had been away two nights. Mr. Ellis informed your Agent, Mr. Seibald, who said that he could not do anything because it was a Criminal Case. So Mr. Ellis left the police, who had it in hand, to finish it. In due time he was summoned to attend the Court at Battleford. The case was dismissed!! because the girl particularly in question in the charge, against whom the offence was committed had previously misbehaved with the same man, & was therefore of uncleanly character!! How can we hope to teach our Indian pupils chastity when the law administration thus encourage immorality? The young Indians have very lax ideas on the subject. It seems to me that the previous
misconduct "with the same man" did not excuse him but rather increased his guilt. I am not attempting to teach a judge law. Possibly he was technically justified. But that the result is a blow to morality & decency, & hinders our work, is very evident.

Was Mr. Libbald right in refusing to interfere? Did not the police & the Judge grossly mismanage the case? I fear such a case is mismanaged something by the police purposely. What can your department do to rectify this wrong?

Believe me

Yours faithfully,

J. A. Saskatchewan

[Signature]

William P. H.

5/2
Ottawa, 20th February, 1939.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant with reference to the girl pupils from the Onion Lake Boarding School, and note your observations with respect to the proceedings and your enquiry as to whether the Department can do anything in the matter.

In reply I beg to say that the charge was evidently laid under the provisions of Section 211 of the Criminal Code but failed because it was established that the girl was not of previously chaste character. If action were to be taken against the offender for the first of such offence, it would have to be brought within one year according to Section 1140 of the Criminal Code.

With respect to the question as to whether Agent Sibbald could have done anything in the matter, I beg to say that he has magisterial jurisdiction to take the preliminary hearing in such a case but he would have been compelled to dismiss the case if it had been established to his satisfaction that the girl was not of previously chaste character.

This occurrence is greatly to be regretted, but apparently the only legal action that could be was taken. It does not appear from the facts set forth in your letter that there was any irregularity in the legal proceedings. The Department is not aware of any action which could be taken in respect to this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J.A. Newnham, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert,
Sask.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

In your letter of the 13th ultimo you reported that there were a few cases of smallpox at the Onion Lake (O.S.) Boarding School, stating at that time there were four children whom the doctor pronounced to be suffering with a mild type of the disease.

I have to request that you will be good enough to state whether the epidemic at this school is now over and whether the children are fully recovered. Kindly furnish a full report regarding this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

For Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, No. 117555/1, with reference to the outbreak of smallpox at the Onion Lake (C.B.) Boarding School; and, in reply, to inform you that this outbreak was discovered on November 1st, and Dr. Macrett, of Lloydminster, immediately telegraphed for. The doctor arrived at Onion Lake next morning, and pronounced the complaint from which 4 of the Indian pupils were suffering, as a mild type of smallpox.

The names of the 4 children first attacked are:

- Robert Chief, Onion Lake band
- Arthur Montana, " Frog Lake band
- George Pechowe, " Frog Lake band
- Sam Abraham, "

The doctor superintended the quarantining of these children, and left instructions as to treatment for these and any subsequent cases that might develop. He also vaccinated every unvaccinated child at the school.

The children were quarantined on the upper floor of the school building, and were kept strictly isolated. Three other Indian children later developed the disease, and were quarantined with those first attacked. Miss Cunningham, a member of the school staff (who has had considerable experience in nursing) nursed all the sick Indian children, and they have now all fully recovered.

About the same time as the last three Indian children...
Children were attacked, the two small children of the principal, Mr. H. Ellis, also developed the disease; these were nursed by their mother who isolated herself with them, in one of their own bedrooms.

The names of the 3 Indian children last attacked are:-
John Chief, Onion Lake band
Mathias, Frog Lake band
Eva Abraham,

It will be seen from the foregoing that, including the principal's two children, 9 children at this school contracted the disease. These have all now fully recovered, and the rooms occupied by them thoroughly fumigated with formalin on December 19th. The clothing and bedding was well washed and disinfected.

I am pleased to state that the disease was confined to the C. of E. school, and did not make its appearance elsewhere on the reserve. Every precaution was taken to prevent it spreading, and, judging by results so far, with complete success.

I have the honour to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I regret to have to report that for sometime past the Indians have been complaining with respect to the food supplied to the pupils at the Onion Lake Church of England Boarding School.

In this connection I would refer you to my school report for January past, in which mention is made of a complaint that the food supplied the pupils at this school was insufficient. At the time of my January visit the pupils had a good meal with white bread, but I spoke to the principal, Mr. Ellis, about giving the children something to drink with their mid-day meal, and he promised to give them some tea. The practice they had been following was for the children to drink from the well either before or after eating.

Mr. Sibbald inspected the school on Feb. 25th. and was not satisfied with the food. He told me that the bread was very dark and that the only utensil the children had to eat their dinner with was a spoon, there being no knives or forks, and they had only water to drink.

Yesterday, just before noon, Joseph Quinney, one of the Onion Lake Councillors, asked me if he could be allowed to visit the school and see the children at their dinner. After he had gone I thought it better to do myself also, so as to be able to judge the correctness of any complaints Quinney might make. The children had a fair meal consisting of beef stew, potatoes, and carrots, followed by rice pudding. There was nothing to drink upon the tables and no knives and forks. The bread was very dark and on my speaking to Mr. Ellis about it, he informed me that it was made from shorts. I may say there was not a sufficiency of bread upon the tables, but on my mentioning it more was supplied.

During the afternoon the Chief and Councillor (Jos. Quinney) came to the office and told me that they were going to circulate a petition to the Bishop of Saskatchewan, asking that Mr. Ellis be removed and a new principal put in his place.

I thought it better to inform the Department of these happenings and would respectfully suggest that a letter be written Mr. Ellis informing him that these conditions must be improved.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Canon Gould,

I beg to enclose herewith for your information a copy of a letter which has been received from our Agent at Onion Lake with respect to the food supplied the pupils of the Onion Lake (C.E.) Boarding School.

I shall be pleased if you will inquire into the complaints made by the Indians through the Agent as to the food furnished the pupils of this school. The Principal should be informed that it is expected that the children will be provided with good, substantial and well cooked food. The bread should be made from a good quality of flour and the children should be given tea, cocoa or milk at their meals, also the necessary table utensils, including knives and forks, should be supplied. I shall be pleased, when you have had an opportunity to make inquiry, to have a report from you as to the food provided.

Dear Mr. Scott,

(5) The Onion Lake boarding school and the complaint "that the food supplied the pupils at this school is insufficient."

It is a matter of great regret to both Archdeacon Snowdon and myself that the state of the trails prevented us, on our recent visit to the West, from carrying out our intentions to pay a visit to this school. I am sending your letter, together with the inclosed copy of communication from Mr. Lang Turner, Acting Indian Agent, to Dr. Westgate, requesting him at the earliest available opportunity to pay a personal visit to the Onion Lake school, and to take up the matter indicated, together with any other urgent matters concerning the school, and also to submit a requisition for the necessary table utensils, etc., etc., concerning the supply of which by the Missionary Society, if the complaint is well grounded, there will be no question. As far as my information goes I think that the Principal, Mr. Ellis, is a satisfactory man; he has been under the very great difficulty of trying to make ends meet with insufficient means.

Believe me,

MEMORANDUM OF THE FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C., ON HIS VISIT TO THE ST. BARBARA INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL ON THE ONION LAKE RESERVE IN THE DIOCESE OF SASKATCHEWAN IN MAY 1921.

1. THE OBJECT OF THE VISIT.

This visit, which partook of the nature of an investigation, was undertaken at the request of the General Secretary M.S.C.C. (See his letter Apr.5th) who had been informed by the Indian Department that Indians on the Onion Lake Reserve had forwarded to them through the Onion Lake Agency, a complaint against the insufficiency and inferiority of the food and dishes provided for the children in the Church of England Boarding School.

2. DATE AND ARRANGEMENTS

As the transfer of the School in question from Diocesan control to that of the Society was still incomplete, the Field Secretary felt that the investigation should not take place without the approval of the Bishop of the Diocese. This approval the Bishop very cordially gave and appointed the Ven. Archdeacon Mackay to represent the Diocese in the investigation.

The Field Secretary left Winnipeg on Saturday evening, May 7th, and spent Sunday May 8th, at Dauphin where he assisted the Rector at the early morning celebration of Holy Communion, preached at the 11 A.M. and 7 P.M. services. Leaving Dauphin at 4:30 A.M. on Monday, May 9th, he arrived at Lloydminster at 1:30 A.M. on Tuesday, May 10th, and here he was joined by Archdeacon Mackay who had journeyed all the way from the Pas in Manitoba right across the Province of Saskatchewan.

3. FROM LLOYDMINSTER TO THE SCHOOL

The shortest route from Lloydminster to the Onion Lake School, lies along the meridian which forms the inter-provincial boundary line of Saskatchewan and Alberta, and covers a distance of about 35 miles. The Rev. Henry Ellis, Principal of the School, sent his assistant, Mr. Parker with a span of horses.
and a democrat to meet the visitors and travelling together in this manner on Wednesday, May 11th, and along the route referred to, they accomplished the journey in twelve hours, ten of which were spent in actual travelling, and the other two in resting. About two-thirds of the way, namely as far as the North Saskatchewan River, which is crossed by ferry, progress was exceedingly difficult and toilsome owing to the heavy condition of the roads. From the River to the School, travelling was easier, but speed was out of the question partly owing to the darkness of the night and partly to the weariness of the horses. All supplies for the School are carried along this route at a cost of 65¢ per 100 lbs.

4. THE SCHOOL BUILDINGS AND PROPERTY.

On Thursday morning, May 12th, a careful examination was made of the School buildings, and these were found to be as follows:

(1) THE BOYS' HOUSE. This is a rectangular, frame building, about fifty feet to the side, three stories high, and beneath which the soil has been excavated and a furnace installed. As the bottom and sides of the excavations were unprotected by brick, stone or cement, or even wood of any kind, water had soaked in and flooded the whole area to a depth of fully two feet, completely obscuring the ash-pit of the furnace, and reaching nearly half-way up the fire-box. A small, hand worked suction pump was being used by some of the older boys in an endeavour to draw the water out.

The ground floor of the building is divided into two class rooms with a hall between them. Two classes were under instruction, one in each room, the more advanced being conducted by Mrs. Benjamin, and the elementary by Miss Halkett, a young Cree Indian woman who has been transferred from the staff at Lac la Ronge when the buildings there were destroyed by fire.

The equipment of the class rooms, while not of the best, was not, so far as was observed or ascertained, seriously lacking in many respects. The text books in use were those prescribed for use in the Province by the Provincial Authorities, and evidence was not lacking that effectual work was being done.

The atmosphere, at the time of the visit was so cold,
and a fire being impossible, the Archdeacon asked the Principal to suspend instruction for the day.

The ascent from the ground floor to the second storey is made by an outside stairway, more picturesque than secure, placed at right angles to the west side of the building, the upper end resting against a verandah which encompasses two sides of the house. This storey is divided into a number of small rooms, two of which are, or may be used by members of the staff, and these, along with a room for clothing are separated by a hall in which a box-stove is placed, from two other rooms, one of which is used as a day room for the boys.

The top storey which is reached by a narrow inside stairway is used as a dormitory.

(2) THE GIRLS' HOUSE.

Like the Boys' House this also is a wooden structure, and although it is only two storeys high it covers a larger area, possesses a small tower at one corner, has a cellar underneath, and was apparently built in sections. An examination of the cellar revealed it to be a dismal and dangerous place, where it was not possible to remain any length of time with a feeling of security. The beams have so far decayed that quantities of their outside parts could easily be broken off with the fingers, and numerous wooden posts had to be inserted to support them.

The space on the ground floor is cut up into so many rooms that it is not easy to describe them, but the following more important ones may be mentioned,—a dining room for the children, a dining room and sitting room for the staff, a kitchen, a pantry, a large hall used as a printing room with a printing press installed and working, and the Principal's office which also serves as a dispensary. These rooms are heated by wood-burning stoves, the wood, mostly poplar, being purchased on the Reserve, and cut into short lengths in the School yard by a circular saw run by a gasoline engine. The floors are greatly worn and in one place, namely, between the kitchen and the staff's refectory, so uneven owing to decay and subsidence that a difference of about twelve inches was noticeable in the altitude of the surface.
MEMORANDUM ON ONION LAKE SCHOOL.

An inside stairway leads to the upper storey which has a balcony running along the south side of it, and is divided into dormitories for the girls and rooms for the lady workers on the staff.

(3) THE PRINCIPAL'S RESIDENCE.

The Principal and his wife with their four children reside in a small frame cottage situated on the north side of the School compound, close to another small building, part of which is used as a store room for supplies and the remainder as an open shed.

(4) THE CHURCH.

At the eastern end of the compound stands a neat little frame Church with a square tower, carefully kept and in good repair. Most, if not all of the furnishings, were provided by local contributions, and at the time of the visit a large number of new seats arrived, which when put together and placed, would complete the seating accommodation.

Close to the Church is the graveyard with tombstones marking the resting places of Whitesman and Redmen alike who have finished their journey and are waiting the great day when the elect number shall be perfect and God shall be all in all. Notable among these was the grave of J.R. Matheson who lived so long and laboured so indefatigably as a good shepherd seeking the lost and wandering sheep in this remote part.

(5) THE BARN.

Apart from the latrines which stood in different parts of the School grounds and were quite unworthy of an Institution of this kind, only one other building remains to be mentioned and that is the barn and stable, the original part of which was made of logs with a number of framed additions.

5. THE MEETING TO INVESTIGATE THE COMPLAINT.

On Thursday, May 12th, the Principal was requested to ask the Chief and Councillors who had lodged the complaint with the Department, to come to the School, and this request was responded to at 1:30 P.M. by the arrival of Chief Robert, Councillors Joseph Quinney and Josiah Calling Bull, and another Indian.
MEMORANDUM ON ONION LAKE SCHOOL.

During the Meeting two other Indians arrived, but as it was determined that they had no children in the School, and were, themselves members of the Roman Catholic church, they were courteously asked to retire.

During the whole of the proceedings the Ven. Archdeacon MacKay was present and presided, and with him were the Field Secretary M.S.C.C., the Rev. Henry Ellis, Principal of the School, and for part of the time the Rev. Edward Ahenakew who has just returned from Edmonton University where he had completed his second year in Medicine. The retiring Indian Agent, Mr. Sibbald was ill, and acting Indian Agent, Mr. Turner, was absent from the Agency, and consequently neither were able to attend.

The Chief was asked his reasons for complaining, and these may be briefly be summarized as follows:-

(1) WITH REGARD TO TABLE EQUIPMENT.

He stated that he occasionally visited the Roman Catholic School, which is only about three hundred yards away, and observed that the children there were provided at meals with knives, forks, napkins, and other table equipment which he found were wanting when he visited the Church of England School.

(2) WITH REGARD TO THE FOOD.

When asked if the complaint was only about dishes and table equipment generally, he replied that the children in the Roman Catholic School were better fed, being given butter, or a substitute for butter, but that this commodity was not in evidence on the occasion of his visit to the Church of England School.

With regard to the first of these complaints, namely, The Table Equipment, while it has regrettably to be admitted that the Church of England School was not as completely equipped as it should have been, it should be stated that the responsibility in this respect did not rest so much with the Principal as with those who were responsible for the equipment and maintenance of the School.

It is also but fair to state that before the Chief and his colleagues visited the Roman Catholic School, they gave the Head of that School two

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
weeks' notice of their intention, whereas their visit to the Church of England School was made without any previous intimation, whatever.

Steps have already been taken to supply the School with the cutlery, dishes, &c., which were required by despatching nearly $100.00 worth of household equipment and further cause for complaint along this line need not be anticipated.

With regard to the second complaint namely, The Food, a glance at the children themselves furnished ample proof that they had not greatly suffered, and the Chief appeared somewhat confused when the healthy and flourishing condition of his own daughter Sophie, a pupil in the School, was alluded to in this connection.

An examination of the School Ledger showed that lard compound as a supplement to, or a substitute for butter had been used to the extent of 150 lbs. per quarter, and that in 1919 the sum of $2055.28 had been expended on the item of food alone, and in 1920 no less than $3168.26 had been spent for the same purpose. This was for a staff of six Europeans and forty Indian children.

With regard to the care taken and the general state of the children, the Chief was asked how he accounted for the fact that during the severe epidemic of influenza which visited that district some time ago, no less than nine children died in the Roman Catholic School whereas none died in that of the Church of England, but to this he could give no satisfactory answer.

6. LAND AREAS.

The total amount of land set apart as the Onion Lake Reserve comprises 190,432 acres. Of this, about 104 acres have been set apart for the two Schools, or an area of 52 acres each. Of the area set apart for the Church of England School, only about 8 acres are under cultivation, the greater part of the remainder being unsuitable for cultivation on account of forests and sloughs.

7. AREAS SERVED BY THE CHURCH OF ENGLAND SCHOOL.

Children have attended this School in the past, or are at present attending it, from the following Indian Communities:

(1) The Onion Lake Reserve.
(2) Frog Lake, where the Indian Charles Quinney is the Teacher.
MEMORANDUM ON ONION LAKE SCHOOL.

(3) Rig Island Lake

(4) Island Lake

(5) Thunderchild's Reserve, where Mrs. Brown is Field Matron.

(6) Little Pines.

(7) Sweet Grass

(8) Red Pheasant, where Mr. Bird (European) is the Teacher.

(9) Moosomin.

(10) Sandy Lake, where Mr. Hutchinson is the Teacher.

(11) Snake Plain, where Mrs. Le Clair is the Teacher.

Inspected school Dec. 1st. Teacher Rev. H. Ellis.
Attendance 38; Temp. of school 68; Ventilation very poor;
Fire drill once weekly; School clean; Building extremely
poor, floors being worn through in places; Cellar stairs
unsafe. This building I consider very unsafe for children.

Ottawa, January 5, 1922.

Sir:

I have to draw your attention to a matter arising out of the report of the travelling nurse on the Onion Lake C. K. Indian Boarding School.

Miss Johnston has reported that the ventilation was very poor and that, while the girls were kept quite clean, more attention should be paid to the condition of the boys. It was also reported that the school was very short of milk, as but two cows were milking at the time of her inspection (December first). You might draw the attention of the Principal to these facts and the extreme desirability of remedying conditions as soon as possible.

When you are talking with the Reverend Mr. Ellis, you might point out that the Department is aware of the extreme difficulty under which he is labouring, due to the condition of the building, and that this communication is not in the nature of a complaint, but is to urge him to do the best that is possible for our Indian wards under his care.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a letter received from Rev. H. Ellis, principal of the Onion Lake C. of E. Boarding School, with reference to the Department increasing the pupilage at that school from 36 to 42.

At present the grant allowed this school is for 36 pupils, and there are 26 boys and 14 girls on the roll, a total of 40. There are two boys dormitories measuring 35' x 25' x 10' 4" and 17' x 14'6" x 9'6" a capacity of, roughly, 11400 cubit feet. The two girls dormitories measure 31' 4" x 23' x 7'6" and 19x10x8, a capacity of, roughly, 6600 cubit feet. However, the last mentioned dormitory can be more than doubled in size by the taking down of a partition and using the space occupied by the cook, Miss Marshall, as a girl's dormitory. Mr. Ellis informed me that he intended to apply for admission to do this, and to remove Miss Marshall's quarters to another part of the building.

If the Department can see its way to increase the pupilage at this school, it would have my recommendation.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

During the interview which the Rev. Canon Gould, General Secretary of our Society, held with Mr. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General, on Friday, the 15th instant, the question of increasing the pupilage of the Onion Lake School from 36 to 41, and that of the Pelican School from 35 to 40, was placed on the list of items to be considered. As the memorandum which I had prepared for the General Secretary in this connection did not make it sufficiently clear as to whether it was expected that the buildings in question should be enlarged so as to accommodate the larger number of pupils, or whether it was intended that authority should be given, with the present accommodation, to admit the larger number if they could be secured, I now beg to state that the latter object was the one in view. I have taken this matter up with the Principal and the Agents at these two Schools, during personal visits, and as they were in favour of the increased pupilage suggested I shall be obliged if you will furnish me with an authorization to that effect.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, with reference to increasing the pupilage of the Onion Lake C. of E. Boarding School.

I have to inform you that we have had some correspondence with the Indian agent in this connection, and it has been decided to increase the pupilage at this school to 41, on the condition that the girls' dormitory is enlarged by tearing down the partitions. EXPLANATORY NOTES ON REQUIREMENT

1. OCHON LAKE. NEW AND ENLARGED MAIN SCHOOL BUILDING, WITH OUT-BUILDINGS, LAND, ETC., ON ANOTHER SITE, TO TAKE THE PLACE OF THOSE OCCUPIED AT PRESENT.

Part I.

(a) The present buildings are old, unsatisfactory, antiquated in design, and incapable in every way of accommodating the number of children awaiting admission.

(b) The site which they occupy on the seepage side of a slough renders the basement of both buildings liable to flooding, a condition which has already existed, and is, in consequence, unhealthy.

(c) The land attached to the School at present is inadequate and unsuitable for extensive farming operations.

(d) No out-buildings of any consequence such as a stock-barn, granary, poultry-house, pigery, implement-shed, etc., have ever existed at this School.

Part II.

It is suggested

(a) That a new site be selected during the winter or early in the spring, by representatives of the Department and the Society.

(b) That the new main school building should have a capacity of enrolling not less than 100 pupils.

(c) That the out-buildings mentioned under sub-section (d) above should be provided.

(d) That not less than one section of land should be attached to the new institution.

(e) That provision be made in the estimates for 1924 for providing the school with a good strain of milking cows, not less than fifteen in number, 100 hens, and a couple of pigs.

(f) That these requirements be given precedence over all others included in the list on page 2 of this docket.

Dec. 14th, 1923,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Parents,

We are going to tell you how we are treated. I am always hungry. We only get two slices of bread and one plate porridge. Seven children ran away because there are hungry, two from Saddle and one from Frog Lake, and two from Snake Plain, 3 girls and 4 boys because are always hungry too. I sold all my clothes away because I am hungry too. Try and send me some money, $2.50, please to buy something to eat and send me picture those I left in the wagon.

I am not sick. I hope you the same too. I am going to hit the teacher if she is cruel to me again. We are treated like pigs, some of the boys always eat oats and wheat. I never ask anyone to give me anything to eat. Some of the boys cried because they are hungry. Once I cry too because I was very hungry. If you have no money try to get from somebody or chief or instruction.

Try and send me soon because I am always hungry. I near ran away too because I was very hungry that time. I want $2.50 please. I am always very lonely and hungry, but still I will say Happy Christmas to all and Happy New Year to all.

So good by to all of you
from Edward B.
January 11, 1924.

Dear Mr. Mears,-

With reference to the attached letter from the Indian boy, presumably at one of our schools, I have to inform you that we cannot trace any Edward B. on the roster of our two schools at Onion Lake. I am sending a copy of the letter to the Indian Agent there and am asking him to look into it. There is a plentiful supply of food at both of these schools, and I am sure there is no cause for complaint. The whole point of the letter as I see it is an attempt to work up sympathy from his parents in order to get $2.50 in cash for some purpose or other. I see no reason whatever for publishing the letter, and I will advise you immediately of the answer that I receive from our Agent. If I knew who sent the letter I would communicate direct with him. Ninety-nine per cent of the Indian children at these schools are too fat.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

P.C. Mears, Esq.,
Press Gallery,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.
January 12, 1924.

I am inclosing herewith copy of a letter which has been forwarded to the Department written by an Indian boy, presumably at one of our schools at Onion Lake. I am quite certain that there is a plentiful supply of food at both of these schools and I think the object of the letter is to work up sympathy from his parents in order to get $2.50 in cash for some purpose or other.

Yours very truly,

Records to file

Please return to Mr. Scott as soon as Agent Turner heard from.
Dear Sir,

A copy of letter written to you by your son Edward, a pupil at the Church Of England School here, has been forwarded to me. In it he complains of being always hungry and that he is not given enough to eat. This is not true, your boy is well fed and clothed. I visit the school frequently and it is one of my duties to see that the children are well looked after.

I hope this will re-assure you with respect to Edward.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

K. A. Baptiste,
Paynton, Saskatchewan.
At first the boy stoutly maintained that the $2.50 which he asked his parents to send him was for the purpose of buying food, but admitted that he had fixed upon that amount as it was half of his treaty money, and that many of the children at the school, whose parents live on the Onion Lake reserves, are given half of their treaty money at treaty time, by their parents, and there is no doubt in my mind but that Edward was actuated to write the letter with the idea of being on a par with most of the other boys in this respect.

With respect to the teacher being cruel I would say that she is one of the gentlest little ladies one could possibly meet. On my questioning Edward on this point, he could only say "she gives me too hard lessons".

Edward is, I think rather a small boy for his age, 15½ years, but his body is well nourished. To ascertain this I had him partly strip in the office and afterwards took his weight which is 118 lbs.

The only statement with an element of truth in his letter is that seven children ran away from the school. This was at last harvest time, when the Indians were all in tents. The children were away only a few hours; it is no unusual thing for Indian school children to run away at that time of year. Edward's letter is the first intimation that I have ever had that the children ran away because they were hungry.

Concurrent with your letter I received one from the Toronto Star, enclosing another copy of Edward's letter and in reply am sending it a copy of this.

In conclusion I would say that the Onion Lake C. of E. Boarding School is conducted in a very satisfactory manner. The children are well fed, well clothed and good discipline is maintained.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.
Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, enclosing copy of a letter written by an Indian boy, Edward B., to his parents.

The boy's proper name is Edward Kemakawtay; he belongs to Little Pines reserve, Battleford Agency, and is pupil No. 74 at the Onion Lake (C. of E.) Boarding School. I have made enquiries respecting the complaint in his letter and so far as underfeeding is concerned, can state emphatically that there is no truth in the charge. I visit this school frequently, at least once a week - it is situated only about 200 yards from the Agency - and often go into the dining room and see the children at dinner or supper and always find them with an ample meal. I made a point of visiting the children at dinner-time today and found that they each had a plateful of beef and potato stew, followed by apple pudding. There was also a large kettle half full of the stew for those who required a second helping, a good supply of bread upon every table, and a cup of hot tea for every child. The cook informed me that there was, almost invariably, a large quantity of scraps left over from each meal which went to feed the pigs.

Before leaving the institution I asked that Edward be sent across to the Agency Office as I wished to see him alone. On his arrival I questioned him in respect to the letter he had written. He maintained that the children did not get enough to eat for breakfast, but admitted that they did get plenty at dinner and supper. I asked him what he had been given for breakfast this morning and he replied "a plate of porridge and two slices of bread and jam." I received the impression that he complained of the breakfast as he knew that that was a meal which I had never attended.
January 26th, 1924.

Dear Parents:

We are going to tell you how we are treated. I am always hungry. We only get two slices of bread and one plate porridge. Seven children ran away because there are hungry—two from Saddle and one from Frog Lake and two from Snake River. Three girls and four boys because they are always hungry too.

I sold all my clothes away because I am hungry too. Try and send me some money, $2.50 please to buy something to eat, and send me picture of those I lost in the water.

I am not sick. I hope you the same too. I am going to hit the teacher if she is cruel to me again. We are treated like pigs. Some of the boys always eat oats and wheat. I never ask anyone to give me something to eat. Some of the boys cried because they were hungry. Once I cry too because I was very hungry. If you have no money try to get from some body or chief or Instruction.

Try and send me soon because I am always hungry. I hear run away too, because I was very hungry that time. I want $2.50 please. I am always very lonely and hungry, but still I will say... Happy Christmas to all and Happy New Year to all.

So good by to all of you.

From Howard B.

Sir,

I have the honour to refer to the quarterly return for the Onion Lake (C. of E.) Residential School which goes forward by this mail; in which it will be seen that there is a larger number on the roll than is authorized.

I paid a visit to this school this morning to see what arrangements had been made for sleeping quarters for the extra pupils and found that, so far as accommodation for the boys is concerned, there was no overcrowding. With regard to the girls, however, I found that ten of the smaller children were occupying five beds, two in each.

In this connection I should report that the Rev. H. Ellis, the principal, has never yet complied with the condition upon which the Department increased the pupilage from 36 to 41 - Vide Department letter dated July 13th, 1923, No. 135-1-1 - which was that a partition be set down at once between the boys' dormitories. On receipt of the above quoted letter I sent Mr. Ellis a copy of it, and have spoken to him on the subject several times since, but the work has not yet been done.

I should add that Mr. Ellis has informed me that the Rev. Canon Westgate, D.D., is writing the Department on the subject of the extra pupils, who are being recruited in readiness to occupy the new school when it is built.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, reporting on your visit to the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School and enquiring as to what arrangements had been made by the Principal to provide dormitory accommodation for the extra pupils.

In this connection it is noted that there is no overcrowding in the space provided for the boys, but that the Principal has not complied with the conditions upon which the Department increased the pupilage from 36 to 41 - that a partition in the girls' dormitory be torn down. If this partition can be removed without undue expense, the Principal should have the work done at an early date. In view of the fact that a new building is being erected, we do not desire the Principal to be put to any undue expense in making alterations in the old building. However, it is considered that he should have carried out the conditions upon which the increased pupilage was granted. We note that you have drawn the Principal's attention to this matter on several occasions. You will be good enough to again inform him of the conditions imposed when the pupilage was increased. It is considered in view of the present accommodation that no pupils should be recruited until the new school is ready for occupation.

Your obedient servant,

REPORT

Henry Ellis - Onion Lake, Sask.

Prairie Fire, Onion Lake Indian Reserve.

On May 19th 1926, while on patrol at Onion Lake Indian Reserve I was requested by the Indian Agent, Mr. L. Turner to investigate a case of an infraction of the regulations governing the setting of Prairie Fires, which fire had apparently started from the Onion Lake Indian Mission School on the Reserve.

I accordingly patrolled with Police Team 1602-1603 to the Reserve and found that several Townships had been burned over, quite evidently from the fire which had started from near the School, and several of the Indians had lost granaries and other small outbuildings containing grain for seed purposes by the fire.

I interviewed several of the pupils of the School, one of whom was working in a field close by when the fire started, and none of them saw the fire actually started, but Mr. Mitchell, the Instructor to the boys gave me a statement, as follows:

"On April 27th 1926, I was out fixing fence near the main trail inside the School fence. About 10 Mr. Ellis came out to me. He helped me with the fence for a while and then we started for home. When past a slough I said I would like to burn the foot tall grass when we should get a suitable day for the purpose."

Mr. Ellis said "Stop the Car and we will light now." I did so and Mr. Ellis got out and went across the slough and lit it. It burnt steadily until it was soon out of hand so I came to the School House fighting the fire. In spite of our united efforts it got out of control and burned in an eastern direction.

"After the fire had been started by lighting a backfire to prevent running against the School - under Mr. Ellis' suggestion. The fire burned for several days and nearly all the rain fell on it all day unsuccessfully."

I interviewed Mr. Ellis, who is the teacher at the School, and he denied having set fire to the School, and he denied having seen anyone that he had first seen the fire from the School and had hurried to put it out. He stated that he knew who had started the fire but that he had passed through a woman, but that he had been unable in finding out who they were.

I informed Mr. Ellis that he had started the fire, but he denied any knowledge of it, so on stating the case to the Indian Agent I asked him to take the necessary action to...
On May 25th 1926 I laid an information against the Reverend H. Ellis of Onion Lake Mission School, before J.Groner Esq., J.P., of Lloydminster, Sask., that he did intentionally or carelessly commit a felony by same from his own land to the injury of the property of another person, contrary to Sec 3 Sub/Sec C of the Prairie Wild Forest Fires Act, Chapter XVI of the Revised Statutes of Saskatchewan, 1926.

On May 26th 1926, I accompanied Constable Fielder of the Saskatchewan P.Police to Onion Lake and Ranch to serve the necessary summons on Mr. L. Turner, Indian Agent, who was then in residence, and approached him with an acknowledgment of his liability for the damage done to the Indian property, and that he would personally like to have the Information withdrawn.

This being impossible under the circumstances the case was called for May 28th at two o'clock when the Accused appeared before J.Groner Esq., J.P., at Lloydminster and was charged as above.

The Accused pleaded "Guilty" to the charge as laid and was fined $25.00 and the costs.

No R.C.M.Police costs charged. S.P.Police prosecuted.

Mr. Ellis asked the Court for two weeks time in which to pay the fine and costs, stating as his reason that he wished to write the Attorney General for a remission of the fine and costs imposed. This was granted.

A moiety of the fine was applied for and will be forwarded to the O.S. "F" Division if paid into Court.

A further report will be submitted when the case is completed.

[Signature]

Teach Young Indian Idea to Shoot

FORTY YEARS WORK BY ANGLICAN CHURCH HAS BROUGHT BIG RESULTS

Record of Achievement Since 1885 at Onion Lake on Border Between Alberta and Saskatchewan—School Has Fitted Many for Better Life Work

OUTSTANDING among the Indian schools of the west is that at Onion Lake, on the border line between the provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan. It is undenominational, Protestant in its character in Canada and had its commencement more than 40 years ago at the invitation of Mr. Robert Wilson, missionary of the Churches of England in India. For a quarter of a century the school was well and truly laid for the work of the present time by the influence exercised by this man of God among the Indians. Much devotion to missionary labor among the western redmen. He was elevated to the episcopate while still engaged in the labors of his mission. The famous old mission school has been in use for many years. The article which follows is from the pen of a traveller who has recently made a visit to the Onion Lake district.

By WILLIAM BLEADELL CAMERON

I WAS walking along the trail flanked by the north by the building shining above the school for Indian children conducted by the Church of England at Onion Lake, on the border line between Alberta and Saskatchewan. From stable and corrals across the trail a stove belched steam glassed the clairvoyant clink clink rimmed glasses and a clerical collar was approaching.

"I stopped."

"You connected with the institution here?"

"Yes," he nodded. "Yes." He came near. I halted at twelve feet.

"Who are you?" I asked.

The man had turned gray face, "I know you," he said. His broad head bent only looking out on the westward road. After a moment, I knew that this man was one whom I knew.

This was my introduction to Rev. H. E. Ellis, the first missionary sent to the new Onion Lake Indian residential school. He had been working among the Cree Indians south of both the Rocky Mountains and the lake he named after himself. As I held out my hand, the young man seized it. I had heard much about this missionary.

At the missionary dinner to which he had been invited. This evening, if I was told, was an evening of great importance to him. An opportunity offered to meet members of the St. Chad's family or members of the congregation since the school opened was more than a opportunity to renew acquaintance or make a visit.

To welcome him in the name of his fellow parishioners, the committee had arranged. H. E., a young man who impressed himself upon me, stood before this missionary and his wife fell as they walked at our side.

Success Centered on Parents

But after all this should be given an education equivalent to that afforded by the best provident schools. It was a privilege during the afternoon to watch children doing their work there, undertaking the duties of a real home, doing their best against parents who have treated them unfairly. It was easy to see how this work fitted into the needs of the country, but a school like this is not easy to maintain. It costs money to keep the school running, and the parents have no idea or thought what a good opportunity this school offers. How good are these parents? What is wrong with them? Is it the lack of interest?

From Seven to Eighteen

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM DR. WESTGATE, Winnipeg,
dated May 7, 1927.

In preparing their estimates for next year, they find that even with a slight increase in the per capita grant they will still have a heavy cash expenditure to make over and above all cash receipts including the per capita earnings. In endeavouring to discover a way whereby this condition of things could be remedied, they concluded that the best, if not the only course to pursue, was to have the enrolment increased from 80 to 100 pupils, and I was directed by them to refer this matter to you and ask that an enrolment of this number of pupils be sanctioned immediately. The building has a capacity of 100 pupils and the principal is of the opinion that he will have no difficulty in securing this number. I respectfully beg to request, therefore, that you give this matter your most careful and favourable consideration, and furnish me with the authorization requested at your earliest convenience.
Ottawa, May 17, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the heavy expenses incurred by your Society at the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School. I note that you are in need of financial assistance in this connection. I regret that your proposal to relieve the situation cannot be approved, as the dormitories can accommodate not more than 80 pupils. If you have any suggestion as to how the Department can assist at this time, I should be pleased if you would let me have a recommendation.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. G. C.,
39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
I presented your letter of May 17th (115-1-5) to our Commission at a meeting held on the 14th inst. and was instructed to inform you that in their opinion the only satisfactory way in which our Society could be provided with the financial assistance required to operate their Onion Lake School, without embarrassing overdrafts, is through an increase in the capacity of the main school building. It stands at present at 80 pupils and if increased to 125 pupils, the annual increase in the per capita earnings would furnish the necessary financial relief. Our Commission realize that such increase may not be possible during the current fiscal year, but they can see no possibility of a satisfactory and permanent solution of the problem until such action has been taken. Our Society has been made well aware of the fact that residential schools with an enrolment of 100 pupils or less are practically incapable of being properly staffed and operated without a deficit, on the present per capita basis, and it is for this reason that they desire schools with a capacity of not less than 125 pupils to be built in preference to any others. It is recommended and requested, therefore, that as a measure towards securing the permanent financial relief required for our Onion Lake School, the capacity of this school be increased, not later than during the next fiscal year, from 80 to 125 pupils.

Our dear Principal Mr. Ellis:

We are here where the prisoners kept for two or three days in little rooms. This afternoon we went to the court at South Battleford. We sure are having a good luck about this business. The Head Man of the Court say to us. If we were to go to Prince Albert Court or to finish right now. We said right now. He told us we are sure in good luck because we are young and we are Indian boys too that's why. Well we are going to Prince Albert Jail only for five months. We think we will be there about at August. But we are to be reported to the Mounted Police every two months when we get out of jail for a year. We are hoping you come out and see us very soon. Please Mr. Ellis tell the boys not to get silly about all the things. It's very hard once a boy is in jail can't get out again because irons are all around the prisoner. Every time we go to bed we kneel down and pray to God that's is in heaven - since we left our dear school. Oh my we are very very sorry for it, but it is our own trouble anyhow can't help it. We are very glad that we are not in jail for live, or so many years. We think we can't very well talk once when we get there at the school again, because we are always talking english now. Our time will come yet when we will be out of jail again. It will never happen again such a foolish thing we been doing. Can you sent us some stamps and writing paper too please. Please tell the boys and girls to come and write to us some letters. And tell the staff to come and write to us too, please.

With very best love to you all who are in that school. So we must close now its time for supper now. So good-bye, our Principal.

To Mr. Rev. Henry Ellis, from your school boys Mr. Gilbert Saskamoose and George Peechow. Please try to Ans.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

Dear Mr. Scott:

During your recent visit to Winnipeg I directed your attention to the fact that the capacity of our Society's new School at Onion Lake was limited to 80 pupils, and you desired me to furnish you with a brief statement in this connection. I have, therefore, carefully examined our office records, and find the following data bearing on the subject:

(1) Letter from Mr. Ellis, the Principal, to Mr. Indian Agent Turner dated August 20th, 1926, of which a copy is enclosed herewith.

(2) Letter from Mr. Indian Agent Turner to Mr. Ellis, dated September, 1926, copy of same being enclosed herewith.

(3) Letter from Mr. Ellis to me, dated September 27th, 1926, copy of same being enclosed herewith.

You will note from Letter No. 1 that the Principal states there were 90 pupils in residence in the June Quarter. The grant for that Quarter, however, was only paid on an average attendance of 80 pupils, as you will see from the Departmental letter No. 129-2-3 written by Mr. Ferrier on October 20th, 1926 to Mr. Williams, our Society's accountant in Toronto.
The School has accommodation for 100 pupils, and as the Principal had recruited considerably over the capacity allowed and was then obliged to discharge them, our Society has lost in revenue accordingly.

I trust that you may be able to reconsider this matter, and increase the pupilage from 60 to 100 not later than the beginning of the next fiscal year, and at an earlier date, if at all possible.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir:-

I am in receipt of a letter from our Auditor, in which he informs me that no books are kept at the Onion Lake Indian Residential School (C.E.), and that all figures in connection with the finances are kept in Winnipeg.

It seems to me that this is a most unsatisfactory state of affairs. However, if the Department does not wish a record kept at the schools there is no necessity for an Auditor visiting these institutions. My idea of having the Auditor visit the schools is to see that the public money that is received as a grant is properly accounted for and that it is spent in connection with the work at the schools. At a school where no record is kept we have no way of finding out if the entire amount of the grant is spent on the children. For instance, the children might be poorly fed or clothed, and if there was a surplus of money it might be diverted to other branches of the church work and we have no way of checking up on this. I believe that the money earned at the schools should be spent there, and we should be in a position to say that it is if the question were asked. As it is now we have no record of what money is spent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

As you are, no doubt, aware all residential schools that are administered by the Missionary Society of the Church of England have a central system of financing - Dr. Westgate's office doing the buying. All per capita grants are paid to the Treasurer in Toronto. From time to time the Department receives chartered accountants' reports concerning the expenditures made by the Society. It would, therefore, appear unnecessary to have Mr. Rayner visit the schools that are administered by the M.S.C.O.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:—

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th instant No. 115-1-1 with reference to the Auditor's report on the Onion Lake C.of E. Indian Residential School.

I note that all per capita grants are paid to the Treasurer of the M.S.C.C., in Toronto and that from time to time the Department receives Chartered Accountants' reports concerning the expenditures made by the Society. I was aware that the cheques covering grants earned by the various schools were handed over to the Missionary Society of the Church of England, and that the finances were not controlled by the schools. Might I ask the Department if it has been reported to them that at certain schools where grants are earned, the amount of the grant so earned is not spent exclusively on that particular school? This seems to me entirely unfair; the grant is only sufficient to finance the school at which it is earned, and if there is a surplus in any one term, such surplus should be at the disposal of that school. No school should be called upon to help out with their grant money the finances of another school where the management is inefficient, at the expense of the children. There is no reason why a school earning a certain grant should not get the full amount of it back from the central financing system, and this is one reason why I feel that an Auditor visiting the schools would be able to give the Department valuable information.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

LIFE IN INDIAN SCHOOL WELL PORTRAYED

Miss Margaret Armitage Described Her Work as Teacher In Northern Saskatchewan

A RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

That crops are good in Northern Saskatchewan in the district north of Lloydminster was a statement made by a young lady speaking at the opening meeting for the Autumn season of the Young Women's Auxiliary in Trinity Hall on Tuesday evening, and her talk about that great country was extremely interesting. The world Lloydminster has a particular significance for Cobourg citizens as the town was named for Bishop Lloyd, father of Dr. F. P. Lloyd.

The graphic description of a residential Indian School of some one hundred and twenty or thirty pupils, as given by Miss Margaret Armitage, a member of the staff for three years, conveyed a vivid word picture of everyday life there. Miss Armitage is a daughter of Canon Armitage and Mrs. Daisy Reyna.

Sir:

I beg to report that I visited the above named school on January 21st and made an inspection of the school and a general enquiry into conditions.

I found the school building clean and tidy throughout and kept in excellent condition. Although the day was very cold, about 40 degrees below zero, the school was warm and comfortable. The unit for supplying water and light at the school was working in a very satisfactory way.

There were 106 pupils in residence on the day of my visit, 55 girls and 51 boys. I visited the classrooms and noted the appearance of the children. They looked clean and healthy.

There are two qualified teachers engaged, Miss Dunn and Miss Buxton. They appear to be doing very satisfactory work. It may be interesting to note that 10 of the pupils passed the Grade 8 examinations last year.

The Reverend H. E. Ellis, Principal, has proven to be a good business man and a strict disciplinarian. I am of the opinion that this school is being very well managed.

Fire protection is provided by stand pipe and hose on each floor, connected with pressure tanks in the basement. There are fire extinguishers placed at easily accessible points throughout the building.

A farm is operated in connection with the school. In the 1934 season their crop consisted of 25 acres of wheat which yielded 592 bushels, 80 acres of oats yielded 1,927 bushels, 15 acres of barley yielded 300 bushels, and they obtained 16,461 sheaves of green feed from 30 acres. In addition to this they put up 50 tons of hay. Nine acres of potatoes yielded 392 bushels, sufficient for their requirements.

Their livestock consists of 51 cattle, 8 horses, 27 hogs, and 150 poultry. Nineteen cows are being milked regularly. The children are given all the milk they care to drink.

The affairs at this school appeared to be running quite smoothly and harmoniously at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
