MEMORANDUM OF AN INTERVIEW BETWEEN MEMBERS OF THE INDIAN & ESKIMO RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL COMMISSION, M.S.C.C., AND THE HON. T.A. CRERRAR, MINISTER OF MINES & RESOURCES.

Acting on the suggestion made in a letter dated Ottawa, April 6th, by Dr. Harold V. McGill, Director of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines & Resources, that an effort be made by our Commission to interview the Minister during his visits to Western Canada, arrangements were made for him to receive as many members as were able to attend, in his office in the Federal Building, Winnipeg, on Monday April 18th, 1938, at four o'clock in the afternoon.

The members present were as follows:

His Grace, the Archbishop of Rupert's Land
Rev. Canon H.D. Martin
Rev. C. Carruthers
Rev. H. Sherstone
Mrs. R.O. Taylor
Mrs. A.J. Thorne
J.W.E. Armstrong, Esq., K.C.
H.B. Smith, Esq.,
E.J. Brownlee, Esq.,
Col. E.W. Hermagen
and Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, Secretary.

Prior to proceeding to the Federal Building the members assembled in their Board Room in the Bible House, and agreed that the subjects to be discussed with the Minister be as follows:

(a) The situation at Fort George where the Roman Catholic School had taken 25 Anglican Indian children into residence,

(b) White Fish Lake School where children who were still enrolled as pupils at our Society's School were admitted to the R.C. School at Grouard,

(c) The injustice of limiting the Church of England in the Province of Saskatchewan to three Residential Schools for 3004 Anglican Indians while nine Schools were provided for 5637 Roman Catholic Indians.

While it was the unanimous opinion of the members that these subjects should be brought to the attention of the Minister, it was agreed that special emphasis should be laid upon the need of an increased enrolment on a per capita grant earning basis, at the Fort George School.

After His Grace, the Archbishop of Rupert's Land had offered prayer, the members proceeded to the Federal Building where they were very kindly received by the Minister shortly after four o'clock.

The Secretary, acting as spokesman for the Commission thanked the Minister for the opportunity of discussing some of their problems with him in person. He conveyed to him the regrets of the other members who were unable to attend, namely, His Grace, Archbishop Matheson, Dr. R. Fletcher, Hugh Phillips, Esq., K.C., Chancellor J. Preudhomme, K.C., Osborne Scott, Esq., and Mrs. T.A. Gray.

Before proceeding to deal specifically with the subjects previously agreed upon, the Secretary referred to the personnel of the Commission, making special reference to the representatives of the Dominion Board of the W.A., whose Dorcas Department alone contributes between forty and fifty thousand dollars a year to the Indian Residential School work.
He also briefly outlined the unified system of administration, as vested in the Commission and which superseded the system of Diocesan control.

1. FORT GEORGE

In dealing with the situation at this centre, the Secretary mentioned that the Anglican Church had been at work at Fort George and other places along the Eastern shores of James Bay for over three-quarters of a century, while the Roman Catholic Church did not appear in Fort George until about 15 years ago. As the Government had made it a rule of policy not to erect school buildings in unorganized territories, the Bishop of the Arctic, working in collaboration with the Executive Committee, M.S.C.C., decided to build a School at Fort George with Church money, fully expecting that the ruling given in the following Departmental letter from the Deputy Superintendent General, would afford protection against competition from the Roman Catholic Church:

OTTAWA, Ont.
December 26, 1927.

"Dear Dr. Westgate:-

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that the expense of education for the native population is upon the increase, and while the Department desires to provide a reasonably adequate system, it is essential that the outlay should be controlled. It is thought that the denominations should respect the zones of interest which have been established and not encroach upon them by the extension of missionary effort upon which a demand for separate educational institutions might be afterwards based. This view seems to me truly reasonable, and in future the Department will not recognize requests for new educational institutions unless by pre-arrangement and assistance must not be expected for institutions which encroach by the extension of missionary effort upon territory already provided for.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) Duncan C. Scott.

Deputy Superintendent General."

While the School built by the Bishop of the Arctic has a capacity of 60 children, the Commission were amazed to find, after it had been transferred to them for administration, that the Department would not allow a grant for more than 35 children. Despite earnest requests that they reconsider the matter, the Department did not grant the increase on the grounds that no funds were available. On purely humanitarian grounds fifteen children were taken into the School over and above the 35 for whom the Department had agreed to pay the grant, the cost of maintenance and tuition of these being met by the Executive Committee, M.S.C.C.

After the Department had refused to increase the pupilage at our Society's School beyond 35, the members of the Commission learned, not without consternation, that several Anglican Indian children had been taken into the Roman Catholic School at Fort George, and were informed that this action had been taken with the approval of the Department and that the per capita grants which should have been available for the additional fifteen children in the Society's School were being paid for Anglican Indian children to be maintained and educated in a Roman Catholic School.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Full details of the children in residence in the Roman Catholic School reached the Commission on March 19th of this year in a letter from the Rev. B.S. Greene, B.A., Principal of our Society's School at Fort George, and dated Jan. 25th, 1938. In this letter Mr. Greene gives the names of 28 children in the School. Although he was able to give the dates of the admission of 18 only, as some of them came from Rupert's House and East Main, he emphatically declares that "ALL THE CHILDREN ON THE LIST ARE ANGLICAN CHILDREN".

To further prove that the children admitted to the Roman Catholic School must have been Anglican Indian children, the Secretary quoted from an article written by the Roman Catholic missionary at Fort George (Père Gilles Marchand, O.M.I., Provincial Oblate) which appeared in the magazine "Le Mauricien" under the title "Fort George, Mission de Peine". The article stated, in part, as follows:

"Our Missionaries have been up against a lot of calumnies, sarcasm and fanaticism on the part of the minister of error; the Powerful Company, whose full control has been established upon these rich fur regions, has certainly not helped us in any way in showing its favoritism in the error which is being committed of maintaining the suspicion of the Indians towards our priests and so much so that after fifteen years of hard work our mission does not as yet count one single Catholic".

They mention that although none of the children are as yet Catholic, nevertheless, several of them are hoping to become converts very soon and quote:

"They are looking forward to the day when they may be able to join our Church and bring with them their parents who are still under the control by the prestige of the Powerful Company and of the riches of the Country."

After reading the above quotation, the Secretary stated the Commission did not feel that our Society had been fairly treated in this matter, and that they considered the Department should immediately arrange for an increase in the pupilage at our Society's School at this centre from 35 to at least 60.

The Minister asked if he might have a copy of the article written by the Roman Catholic priest at Fort George, and the Secretary promised to furnish him with the same. Mr. Crerar promised to look into the situation when he returned to Ottawa and to take up with his colleagues the question of granting an increased amount of money in order to the difficulty of having supplementary estimates passed by the House of Parliament, and to the comparatively large amount which was being spent this year in combating T.B. That the Minister was keenly interested in all the work of the Indian Affairs Branch of his Department the members of the commission who were present had no doubt. They assured him of their willingness to co-operate with him and his Department in any way that would benefit the Indian peoples of this country, and expressed the hope that the Roman Catholic Church might be restrained from taking Anglican children to their Schools as they had done at Fort George, and other Anglican children from White Fish Lake School to their School at Grouard, in open defiance of Section 10, sub-section 2 of the Indian Act which reads as follows:

"Such school shall be the nearest available school of the kind required, and no Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The Secretary stated that it would surely be a sad day for Canada when any Church or Society could disregard the authority of the Federal Government, as the Roman Catholic Church appeared to be inclined to do.

2. WHITE FISH LAKE

In dealing with the situation at this centre, the Secretary gave the names of eleven Anglican Indian children who had been taken from the White Fish Lake district to the Roman Catholic School at Groverd, 40 miles away. Of these eleven he reported only five of seven children were still on the register at our Society's St. Andrew's School. He mentioned that he had referred this situation to the proper Departmental officials at Ottawa, in a letter written on Oct. 27th last.

The Secretary of the Indian Affairs Branch, replying to that letter on Dec. 17th last stated that instructions were being issued to have those seven children returned to their parents. In a letter recently received from the Principal of our School at White Fish Lake, and dated April 6, 1938, he stated that the order given by the Department for the seven children to be returned "to the Reserve has so far been utterly ignored".

With regard to the number of schools provided for the Anglican and the Roman Catholic Churches respectively in the province of Saskatchewan, the Minister stated that he had not been aware that so great a difference existed, and undertook to look into the matter.

The interview with the Minister ended shortly after five o'clock.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Winnipeg, April 21, 1938.

November 29, 1938

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In keeping with the understanding reached during our interview in Ottawa on the 21st instant, I am now writing for the specific purpose of asking that the official pupilage at our Onion Lake School be increased from 100 to, at least, 110.

In support of this request I desire to point out that while the enrollment at the end of the last quarter (September 1938) was 116, the per capita grant is limited to 100.

I further desire to point out that when two new school buildings were provided on the Onion Lake reserve, one for our Society and one for the Roman Catholic Church, it was my understanding that there was no difference in the official capacity of these respective buildings.

I now find from page 4856 of Hansard for June 30, 1938, that while the pupilage of our Society's School is limited to 100, that of the Roman Catholic School is 120.
In addition to this apparent, though probably unintentional discrimination against our Society, I wish to again direct attention to the fact that while there are 3900 Anglican Indians in the province of Saskatchewan, and 5637 Roman Catholic Indians, the Anglicans have been allowed only three Residential Schools, while the Roman Catholics have been allowed nine Schools of this class. (See Hansard as referred to above). Even if the United Church Schools be added to those of the Anglican Church, the number of Schools granted the Roman Catholic Church is proportionately larger than it should be from the standpoint of equity.

As this and other matters of like importance were discussed by representatives of our Commission at a meeting with the Minister of Mines and Resources in Winnipeg on April 18th last, I am sending you herewith a copy of the official record of that meeting, and from the closing part of the same you will note that the Minister undertook to look into this situation.

While I am not dealing specifically or primarily in this letter with this particular problem, I consider it necessary to mention it, on account of the bearing it has on the pupilage of our Onion Lake School.

As the Roman Catholic Church has been provided by the Government with more Residential Schools proportionately than they are entitled to have in the Province of Saskatchewan in comparison with the Anglican and United Churches, and as their Onion Lake School is allowed an official pupilage of 120, whereas our School on the same reserve is allowed only 100 pupils, I trust you may see that our request for an increase in the pupilage from 100 to 110 is a decidedly modest and reasonable one, and take immediately whatever steps are necessary to secure the same.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

TBRW/KH
Ottawa, December 28, 1938.

Re: Inspection of Onion Lake C. E. and Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential Schools.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 19th instant and also reports of Inspector Brennan on the above noted schools, enclosed therewith.

The records here indicate that the Onion Lake R. C. School is allowed per capita grant for 120 pupils and the Onion Lake C. E. School per capita grant for 100 pupils. I was somewhat surprised therefore to learn from the Inspector's report that the enrolment at the C. E. residential school had reached 122. I am convinced that it is wholly impossible to ask an inexperienced teacher such as Miss Sherstone to give instruction to 62 pupils with any hope of success.

I note that there appears to be no provision whatever for vocational instruction or manual training at this school, despite the fact that the present Minister is constantly reminding us that the courses at our Indian day and residential schools must become increasingly more vocational in character.

In view of the comments contained in the Inspector's report, I am anxious that a survey of the educational needs in the Onion Lake and Battleford agencies should be undertaken by the Indian agents in cooperation with the principals of the residential schools. The Anglican authorities have asked for an additional pupilage of 10 at the Onion Lake school, but no provision has been made in the 1939-40 estimates for this or any other increases at

Dr. Thomas Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.
residential schools. I think it would be in the interests of all concerned if you could discuss the situation with the principal of the Anglican school and suggest to him that the enrolment at the school be reduced to 100 at the opening of the next academic year, in September, and that it be kept at that figure unless permission is obtained from the Department for the enrolment of additional pupils. In addition to this, provision should be made at the school for vocational instruction - carpentry work, auto mechanics, hand loom weaving, etc. It is my hope that the 5% deduction in per capita grants may be restored with the coming session of Parliament. If such restoration takes place it ought to be possible for the principal to make provision for vocational instruction at his institution.

The report on the Onion Lake C. E. school is on the whole one of the most unsatisfactory that has reached me since I entered the Department two years ago. It is simply impossible to promote a worthwhile educational program at a school with an enrolment of 123 pupils with only two teachers in charge.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

With reference to yours #115-1-1 of December 28th, Residential Schools, Onion Lake, I expect to visit Onion Lake within the next two weeks where I will take up the matter referred to in the above letter and will submit a report on my return.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector Of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Montreal Lake I.R. 106,
Montreal Lake, Sask.
Dec. 30, 1938

Dear Mr. Ellis:

I meant to write you every day for the past few weeks but have been very busy indeed. I want to know if you have room to admit any pupils at present.

Norah and Lillian Roberts, two sisters of this Reserve, aged eleven years and ten years respectively, are poor little orphans. Their mother is dead, and the stepfather married again so that now they have a stepmother as well. She (the stepmother) gave one away to be little slave to her sister's family. I want these children taken away to school with the least possible delay. Can you take them as soon as it can be arranged?

Mr. Davis was here today and asked me to get in touch with you at once, and ask you to let him know if you have room for them now. There is another family of one girl and one boy (both illegitimate) who need to be taken away from an immoral mother. The ages are ten and eight. Mr. Davis would approve of their removal too. The names are Harriet Bird and Harry Bird.

Please do what you can for these children. There are at least three others who ought to be sent away but their cases are not so desperate.

With kind regards, and best wishes for a happy 1939.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Mrs. Agnes B. Stenhouse.

P.S. I can arrange regarding getting those children to Prince Albert for you, if you can accept them.
R.A. Hoey, Esq.
Supt. Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

With further reference to my letter of Nov. 29th last and your personal reply to the same on Dec. 20th last, I beg to state that the Chairman of our Commission, the Most Reverend S.P. Matheson, wrote to the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources on Dec. 30th last about a number of matters which he stated had caused him and our Commission very serious concern for some time.

One of the matters he specifically mentioned was an increase in the pupilage at our Onion Lake School from 100 to 110. As the School at this centre had 112 children enrolled at the end of the December Quarter, 1938, I am sending you herewith a copy of a letter just received from the Principal this morning and addressed to him, which furnishes further strong evidence of the urgent need of the increase requested. The writer of the letter is either the teacher or field matron engaged by the Diocese of Saskatchewan on the Montreal Lake Reserve, and you will note that she had been in touch with Mr. Indian Agent Davis, who approved of the removal of the four children mentioned.

In view of the urgency of the situation, the Rev. Principal Ellis is being authorized to receive these...
children, and I very earnestly hope that this action may be approved by your Department, and every possible effort made to have the official capacity of our Onion Lake School increased from 100 to 110.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Encl.
TBW/KH
Ottawa, January 21, 1939.

Re - Additional pupilage, Onion Lake C. of E.
Indian Residential School.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 13th instant, in which you discuss the desirability of an additional pupilage allowance at the above noted school.

I am not in a position at this time to state what provision, if any, will be made in the supplementary estimates of this year for additional pupilage at Indian residential schools. In view of the fact, however, that the restoration of the 5% deduction is now under consideration by the Government and in view of the money required for the promotion of the T.B. campaign, I am not at all hopeful that an additional appropriation for increased pupilage grants will be forthcoming.

I made a careful study of the files relating to the erection of the C. E. and R. C. Residential Schools at Onion Lake. I have found that at the time the schools were erected the Onion Lake R. C. Residential School was built much larger than the Onion Lake C. E. School; consequently, the air space in the dormitories of the former is approximately 22,000 cubic feet more than in the dormitories of the latter. According to the plans on file at this office, the air space in the dormitories of the C. E. School is 35,426 cubic feet. Possibly the school management is using an attic or some room other than the regular dormitories for dormitory purposes. If so, the air space will be slightly larger than the figures just quoted. At the same time, to provide adequate air space for 110 pupils it would require 35,000 cubic feet. As a matter of fact, I am inclined to feel that with an enrolment of 100 the air space at the Onion Lake C. E. School is hardly adequate.

I regret to state that Inspector Brennan's report on the C. E. school at Onion Lake, which reached the Department in December, 1938, is one of the most unsatisfactory reports that has reached this office since I entered the service of the Department two years ago. At the time of the inspection the enrolment had reached 123, with two teachers responsible for the instruction. It was the Inspector's opinion that to ask an inexperienced teacher such as Miss Sherstone to give instruction to 62 pupils was asking a young teacher to accomplish a task wholly beyond her powers. In addition to the Inspector's comments,

I have -

WINNIPEG, MAN. January 31, 1939.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am grateful to you for your letter of the 21st inst., #115-1-1, and have noted the misapprehension under which I was laboring and that the R.C. School on the Onion Lake Reserve has somewhat larger air space than that provided in our Society's School on the same Reserve. My understanding rested on information I received from the late Mr. Gurney Orr, who drew the plans for both schools, and informed me that the plans were almost identical.

With regard to Inspector Brennan's report on our Onion Lake School, which reached you in December last, more particularly that part of it dealing with the services of Miss Sherstone, one of the teachers, the Principal, writing to me on the third inst. stated, in part, as follows; "It is unfortunate that the Public School Inspector inspected her classroom work when she was new to the children and the work".

In another letter written earlier last year, the Principal states that "In speaking to the Public School Inspector last week, he stated that he had suggested making an additional classroom to his Department three years ago, and appeared surprised that no word had been sent to you from Ottawa. Both teachers have too many pupils in their rooms at present, hence the only solution to the problem is the extra classroom".

As the Principal states that one of the sewing rooms can be converted into a third classroom our Commission have decided to appoint a third teacher to this school from the 1st of March next. This teacher will take charge of the Senior
Grades and Miss Sherstone will have charge of the Intermediate Grades. I have instructed the Principal to apply through the local Indian Agent for the necessary classroom equipment for the third room, and I trust that this may be granted promptly by your Department. The appointment of the third teacher will surely place all the classroom work on a satisfactory basis. Although the third teacher has not yet been appointed our Commission have in view for this position a fully qualified and experienced person.

With regard to your information "that no provision whatever has been made for vocational training at this school" I desire to point out that the majority of the children in this school will live on farms when they graduate and I am not aware that any of our schools has a more successful record in general farming activities than our St. Barnabas' School at Onion Lake. To me and to our Commission, a good grounding in mixed farming cannot but be of great benefit to the boys especially in their post graduate career. The girls are also taught all branches of housekeeping, and as a fully qualified nurse holds the position of Head Matron, expert care is taken of the children's health.

Our Commission are in full sympathy with your Department's desire to enlarge the scope of vocational training, but the members have no suggestion to make beyond the very practical one they have submitted for many years past with their list of annual requirements, that detached classrooms be provided with space for vocational training underneath. Our Society, with its heavy bank overdraft, cannot provide such a building, and until such building has been provided, it will be impossible to institute any vocational training course in carpentry, blacksmithing, mechanics, etc., which will be worthwhile. As our Commission has purchased the school with a complete threshing outfit, I think you will see that we are doing as much as we possibly can with our resources to help fit your wards for the life they will have to live when they leave the school.

With very good wishes,

Yours very truly,

T.B.R.W/H
Secretary of the Commission.

P.S. An increase of even five in the pupilage at this school would help us in meeting the cost of the third teacher.

T.B.R.W.
Ottawa,
February 6, 1939.

LLOYDMINSTER, SASK.

31st January 1939.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In conversation with Indian Agent Dr. Hill of the Onion Lake Agency the other day, I gathered that you are under the impression that no vocational training is given whatsoever at the C. E. Indian Residential School.

By what means or how you have come to this conclusion, naturally fails me.

I want, however, to correct that impression - for we teach both sexes all practical phases of work which the children here will be able to apply themselves after leaving school.

Though I readily admit that our resources and equipment are not of the best, yet I venture to state, without fear of contradiction, that the instruction given is systematic and lasting.

If the Department will furnish us with the necessary equipment, so that we will be able to 'make bricks with the straw', I feel confident that we will not be lagging behind in this branch of definite vocational training.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal
Ottawa, February 6, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 31st ultimo, in which you refer to your interview with Dr. Hill, with respect to the instruction provided at the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School.

I cannot recall to mind having written to Dr. Hill at any time in regard to this matter, but I did write to Inspector Robertson and to Dr. Westgate, immediately following the receipt of the School Inspector's report dated October 25, 1928. In my letter to Dr. Westgate I intimated that the Inspector's report on the Onion Lake C. E. School was one of the most unsatisfactory reports that had reached the Department since I entered the service of the Government two years ago. The Inspector was particularly critical of Miss Sherstone's work, the discipline in her classroom, the number of pupils for the instruction of whom she is responsible, etc. It was his opinion that to ask an inexperienced teacher to undertake the instruction of 62 pupils was asking her to undertake an impossible task. It was the Inspector's view that Miss Sherstone was handicapped in that she was wholly unfamiliar with the Saskatchewan curriculum.

The Inspector in his report of the preceding year, in commenting upon the instruction provided, stated:

"I feel that less stress on the academic part of the education and more on the practical, such as training in agriculture, home economics, manual training, etc., would prove of value to these pupils and better fit them for life. I should like to point out that both these teachers have far too many pupils with whom to do first-class work. If they keep up at the pace they are going—

Reverend Henry Ellis,
Principal,
Onion Lake Residential School,
Lloydminster, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
going, I fear for their health.

In view of this comment, it was my hope that there would be something in the Inspector's report of this year to indicate that steps had been taken to make greater provision for vocational instruction. However, there is nothing in the report now before me to indicate that vocational instruction in an organized and systematic sense forms part of the regular studies.

I was delighted to learn from Dr. Westgate's letter of January 31 that it is the intention of the Commission to provide an additional teacher. I feel confident that the appointment of this teacher will result in a substantial improvement in conditions at the school.

The Minister is constantly reminding us that courses of study provided for Indian children must become increasingly more practical and vocational in character, and I feel that it is my duty to emphasize the Minister's opinion in this regard from time to time. Your reference to the equipment needed for such instruction is noted. It is scarcely necessary to remind you however that the funds required for the purchase of such equipment are not provided by the officials but by Parliament itself. Requests for such equipment from time to time should be submitted to the Indian Agent.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, January 24, 1940.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

Mr. W. D. Brennan, Inspector of Schools, Province of Saskatchewan, in a report on the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School, dated December 27, 1939, states:

"It is to be regretted that there have been so many staff changes. There have been six different teachers employed in the last three years. There were three new ones since my last visit, and one of them was planning to quit at Xmas. One of the additions this year was a young lady right out of normal school without any experience. While she tried hard and seemed to be doing good work, she had difficulty in adjusting herself to her new surroundings. I would strongly advise that in future only experienced teachers be engaged, the experience not necessarily being with Indians. This is the second case of this type in two years and the work of the school is bound to suffer therefrom."

In view of the criticism that reaches me from time to time in respect to the courses of study provided at our Indian residential schools, I feel it is only fair that you should be furnished with the critical comments that reach us from inspectors of these schools in their annual and semi-annual reports.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

February 2, 1940

WINNIPEG, MAN.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have received your letter of the 24th ult. and have carefully noted the excerpt embodied therein from the report of Inspector Brennan on the change of teachers at our Onion Lake School during the last three years.

In this connection I desire to make it quite clear that it is the aim and policy of our Commission to secure, so far as possible, staff agents who contemplate permanency of service in the Indian & Eskimo residential school work, and in this important matter a gratifying degree of success has been attained. For your information I may say that all inexperienced workers are placed on three months probation. Should their services during that period be satisfactory to the Principal and to our Commission they are then asked to sign a written contract specifying a definite period of service, and the notice which must be given by either of the contracting parties before such contract can be terminated. You will readily understand that certain conditions may arise which make it necessary to alter the contract, and this is precisely what happened at Onion Lake. Two of the teachers for health reasons, asked to be released, and another was promised a transfer to a school nearer her home whenever a vacancy was available for her. To fill one of the vacancies thus created, a fully qualified teacher who had for some years been serving at this School as a Supervisor, after teaching for several years at two of our other Schools, was given charge of one of the classrooms.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The Inspector might have reported, but I see no reference to it in the extract embodied in your letter, that the Senior Teacher at this School is a university graduate, and is really doing a highly creditable work in developing amongst the children in the School and the Indians on the Reserve some of their finer arts and crafts. She has arranged for the sale of their products through the Arts and Crafts Society in Saskatoon. Our Commission are pleased to have the services of one so capable and so willing to give or her very best to this work.

It is inevitable that some workers must be engaged who have not had previous teaching experience, and after all, I think it must be admitted that the best place to secure the required training for the residential school work is in the school itself.

Since receiving your letter I have been in communication with the Superintendent of Education in the Province of Manitoba (Mr. Low) and have learned from him that the average period of service given by a public school teacher in the province is from one to two years. He stated that while the tenure varies considerably in different parts of the province, the average would be as stated.

While our Commission always welcome constructive criticism of their work, I would again like to point out that one of the most urgent needs at our Onion Lake, our Mikahom, our Lac la Ronge and certain other Schools, is the provision of a detached classroom block, with space made available in the basement of the same for manual training. Our Society feels keenly the disadvantage under which their Indian educational work is being carried on in the provinces of Manitoba and Saskatchewan due to the lack of sufficient residential school facilities. While the provision of the buildings requested may take some time, the members are still earnestly hoping that your Department of Government may soon be able to give to this important matter the careful and sympathetic attention it undoubtedly demands.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

TBW/KH

Ottawa,
April 25, 1941.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 18th instant with reference to the payment of gasoline tax and education tax by Indian residential schools in the Province of Saskatchewan.

These schools are operated on funds provided by the Dominion Government. In the case of the Onion Lake C.E. School the management is under the direction of the Church of England.

This Branch was definitely informed in December, 1937, that the Saskatchewan education tax does not apply to purchases made by Indian residential schools.

I am not certain what arrangements have been made by the Indian residential schools in connection with securing exemption from the gasoline tax in the Province of Saskatchewan.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The British American Oil Company Limited,
Regina, Sask.
Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

During our recent interview in Winnipeg I mentioned the request of the Principals of our Onion Lake and Sioux Lookout Schools for movie picture projectors, and you suggested that I write to you in this connexion.

The value of this means of instruction has been recognized by our Commission, and during the past year 16 m.m. projectors have been provided for our Blackfoot and Moose Factory Schools. The expenditures involved in providing these have left us without funds to secure those now requested, and it will be fully appreciated if your Department can find some way of doing this on our behalf.

The projector recommended in each case is known as the "Filmo S.T. Projector" for 16 m.m. films, with 750 watt, 110 volt lamp, 2 inch F. 1.6 lens, and these may be purchased (at a special rate) from the General Board of Religious Education of our Church, at 604 Jarvis St., Toronto, for $142.00 each.

Where schools are located near a town or city, the staff and pupils are able to take advantage of the motion picture facilities they provide. Neither Onion Lake nor Sioux Lookout are so located, and it is easy to understand the great help the projectors would be to them, especially during the winter months.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Secretary of the Commission.

TBW/kh
Ottawa,
September 17, 1941.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

Re: Purchase of moving picture projectors for Onion Lake and Sioux Lookout Indian Residential Schools

Your letter of September 3, addressed to Dr. McGill, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply. Dr. McGill is, at this date, absent from the office and is not likely to return for several days.

I regret to state that, inasmuch as no provision was made in the current year's appropriation for the purchase of moving picture projectors, it will not be possible to purchase projectors for the Onion Lake and Sioux Lookout Residential Schools this year.

I may state, however, that a great deal of earnest thought and consideration has been given to the best ways and means of providing visual instruction at Indian day and residential schools. You will be interested to learn also that I am today communicating with Mr. John Grierson, Government Film Commissioner, in the hope that a couple of the officers of the Welfare & Training Division can interview him at an early date and secure from him the most up-to-date information on visual instruction.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission,
M. S. C. C.,
38-43 The Bible House,
164 Alexander Ave. East,
Winnipeg, Man.
About two years ago a moving picture projector somewhat similar to the one requested in your communication was purchased by the Department for extension work on a number of reserves in the Province of Ontario. We discovered a few months ago, however, that it was impossible to secure films suitable for instruction among Indians with the result that we sold the projector and purchased a well equipped lantern for this work. I have been informed that in British Columbia, particularly the City of Vancouver, only sound projectors are now in use and that it is almost impossible to secure silent films suitable for instruction at schools. There is also the problem of electrical energy and the question of direct and alternating currents. These are all matters that we intend to discuss with Mr. Grierson.

You can readily appreciate, of course, that it would not be possible for the Government to purchase projectors for one or two schools and refuse similar requests from others. I am simply writing at this time, however, to inform you that, while it is not possible to purchase the projectors requested by you, the matter is receiving consideration by the Department.

Yours sincerely,

Acting Director.
Regina, September 15, 1943.

REPORT ON ST. BARNABAS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I wish to advise you that I visited the above mentioned school on my last trip to the Onion Lake Agency.

Since it was August when I was there the summer holidays were still on and only a few children were at the school at the time of my visit. However, Agent Cameron and I spent the best part of an afternoon visiting this school. Last June there were 116 children in residence.

One thing I noticed was that the barn is leaning badly and the north end has moved at least six inches off the cement foundation. The stall posts throughout the building are also leaning badly towards the east. Something should be done this Fall to straighten and brace the building to prevent it from blowing over because there is certainly a danger of this happening when some of the high gales that are prevalent in that part of the country come along. A Mr. Comish from the Surveys and Engineering Branch at Banff visited the school last Spring and took photographs of the barn in question, therefore our Branch can get the required information from him as to an engineer's point of view. There is a man at Onion Lake who probably would be able to put the necessary repairs on the building. I understand he is not in very good health at the present time but he is a good practical carpenter if his services can be obtained.

This barn accommodates 21 cows and 8 horses, and has a loft that holds 30 tons of hay. Mr. Ellis, the Principal, would like to use that portion of the barn now occupied by the horses for calves and young stock and to build a separate log barn for the horses. This would cost $400.00. The Principal's request has already been submitted to Ottawa by Agent Cameron.

The school owns 52 head of cattle and milks 26 cows. They have 11 pigs and keep 125 head of poultry and 6 work horses.

The school farms 220 acres of land. Of this 170 acres is under cultivation and 50 acres have been summerfallowed. The crops are fair and the gardens are fair. They have 11 acres of potatoes this year.

Livestock

Farming

Exterior Painting - The exterior...
The exterior of this school was last painted in 1930, thirteen years ago. You can therefore imagine what condition the buildings are in now. There are places where no paint is left on the siding at all. The roof is in even worse condition as there is not a bit of shingle stain left on the shingles, and this is causing them to warp, resulting in the roof beginning to leak in the odd place. Consideration should be given to painting the exterior of the building and the roof as soon as the money is available. I hope our Branch will make a note of this because you will realize that not having been painted for thirteen years it is in pretty bad shape.

The interior of the school is in very fair shape. However, I might suggest that some paint be supplied to the school annually, say $50.00 worth, for interior decoration. This paint could be put on by the older boys.

The machinery at the school is in good condition with the exception of the high pressure boiler which has been condemned by the Provincial Boiler Inspector. The jacket heater is worn out but I was informed by the Principal this could be dispensed with for the present time. However, the high pressure boiler will have to be replaced and Mr. Cameron is submitting a report and estimate on the boiler for your information.

I wish to bring to your attention here that the bake oven is in the laundry and I do not think this is a very satisfactory arrangement but of course it must remain where it is for the present. However, when funds are available I think this should be placed somewhere else.

M. Christiansen,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Ottawa, September 23, 1943.

Mr. D. H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

Mr. Christianson, in his report on the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School, dated September 15, states:

"One thing I noticed was that the barn is leaning badly. The north end has moved at least six inches off the cement foundation. The stall posts throughout the building are also leaning badly toward the east. Something should be done this fall to strengthen and brace the building and to prevent it from blowing over. There is a man at Onion Lake who probably would be able to do all the necessary repairs on the building".

It would be appreciated if you would interview the man referred to by Mr. Christianson and secure from him an estimate of the amount required to strengthen and brace this building. You should ascertain if he would be willing to undertake this work if authorized to do so. Your immediate attention to this matter will be very much appreciated.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
October 13, 1943.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

I desire to direct your attention to my letter of September 23 to which no reply has yet been received. As the information contained in Mr. Christianson's report indicated that the work was urgent, I would appreciate hearing from you by return mail.

Mr. Christianson also suggested that a quantity of paint to the value of $50.00 be supplied the school for interior painting. It is understood that the school management will look after the necessary labour. You may arrange to purchase the paint.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, December 1, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Onion Lake Church of England
Indian Residential School, Saskatchewan.

The following telegram has just been received from the Indian agent at Onion Lake:

"Onion Lake Anglican Indian Residential School destroyed by fire early this morning. Inmates all safe. Children from outlying reserves temporarily housed at R.C. school. Outlying buildings saved. Air letter follows."

This was a government-owned school, having been erected in the fiscal year 1925-26 at an approximate cost of $63,000. The authorized enrolment was 100.

Director.

PP
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

On December 1st., I sent the Department the following telegram:

"ONION LAKE ANGLICAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL DESTROYED BY FIRE EARLY THIS MORNING INMATES ALL SAFE CHILDREN FROM CULTIVATING RESERVES TEMPORARILY HOUSED AT R.C. SCHOOL CULTIVATING BUILDINGS SAVED AIR LETTER FOLLOWS"

Wednesday, December 1st., about 6.00 AM, I was notified by telephone that the Onion Lake Anglican Residential School was on fire and that the fire had taken quite a hold. I immediately called Mr Lockhart, farming instructor, and asked him to accompany me to the School, which is about 6 miles from the Agency. I also called Corp. D. A. Dunlap, R.C.M.P. and requested him to come and at the same time ascertained that all available help had already been summoned by phone.

When we arrived on the scene it was evident that there was no further hope of saving the building, in fact, it was more than half gone then. We assisted in measures taken to save the Principal's house and the barn and outbuildings. By 8.00 A.M. the school had burned to the ground. The alarm had been turned in by the night watchman, who woke Mr W. Waterhouse, engineer, at about 4.00 A.M. Mr Waterhouse found that the fire was in the laundry room located on the east side of the building. The whole staff was called and chemical extinguishers were used to put out the fire in the laundry room, but it was found that the fire had got between the ceiling of the laundry room and the floor of the Chapel located just above. The general alarm was then turned in and the firemen used to fight the fire. The laundry had a tin ceiling and this made it more difficult to get at the fire burning between the joists, and the fire spread westward and throughout the building.

All the pupils, 115 in number, were quietly removed from their dormitories to the play room, where they dressed and were then taken to the R.C. Indian Residential School and cared for by Father Pascal until the morning of December 2nd., when they were conveyed to their homes on the various reserves.

Rev. Mr Ellie, the Principal, had been in the building about 2.00 A.M. and had found everything normal. There was a fire in the bake oven and one in the laundry stove, also a fire in the furnace. The two former are located in the laundry and the latter in the North-west corner of the building. Every effort appears to have been made by the staff to save the building and the efficient manner in which the children were safely evacuated and taken care of is very creditable to those in charge.

continued overleaf

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)
Ottawa, December 7, 1943.

AIR MAIL

Re: Onion Lake School.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

Your letter of the 4th instant, relating to the destruction of the Onion Lake School by fire on December 1, has been sent forward to the Minister for his consideration.

In view of all the circumstances, I am personally disposed to think that the offer of the Bishop will be very carefully and sympathetically considered. I am anxious, therefore, that Mr. Ellis should retain, if at all possible, the members of his staff until a decision is finally reached.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Reverend H. A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
38-45 The Bible House,
184 Alexander Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attn. R. A. Hoey, Esq.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Onion Lake School

I beg to confirm telegram sent from the office on December 1st, and regret that I am not yet able to give you any further information in regard to this tragic loss. I take it that telephone communication has probably been broken and can well imagine the turmoil in which the Principal must find himself at such a time. We shall send you a full report of the matter just as soon as it is received.

In regard to the future, I have received a telegram from the Bishop of Saskatchewan offering the use of the splendid building formerly used for St. Alban's College in Prince Albert. This is a brick structure which was thoroughly repaired not many years ago, and stands in ample grounds on the southern outskirts of Prince Albert. It is not in use at the present time and could be made immediately available. As this building was used as a boarding school for boys, it would appear to be admirably suited for the purpose until such time as reconstruction can be considered at Onion Lake. I understand that Mr. Ellis has estimated that the building would readily accommodate 80 to 100 children and I note that the majority of the present pupils come from reserves that are within easy distance of Prince Albert.

I understand that an approach was made to the Department at the beginning of this year to have the building used as an Indian Residential School but the objection was raised to its location in the city. From my knowledge of the local situation I do not feel that this objection is of sufficient weight to offset the enormous advantage of carrying on the Onion Lake work without a serious break. I wired Principal Ellis yesterday, passing on the Bishop's suggestion and asking for his personal opinion. I felt that it might influence him in holding some of the children together and especially in retaining the services of his staff. No reply is yet to hand but I think it well to write you now so that this suggestion may be fully before you with the least possible delay.

I am personally acquainted with the situation in Prince Albert and shall be glad to run up there at any time to secure further information on the spot, if you think well of the suggestion. I may say that
this further loss by fire is a heavy blow to me personally. The Onion Lake building was comparatively new, and was very well pleased with many things in the work there. I certainly feel that in our Principal we have an experienced and most capable administrator, and I feel confident that every possible care was taken to avoid the hazards of fire. The one redeeming feature, of course, is the fact that 120 children were safely taken from the building at 4:30 in the morning.

As our staff is practically complete, it would seem altogether too bad to allow the work to come to a stop if your Department can feel satisfied to accept the offer of the Bishop and to allow the work to carry on for the present in Prince Albert.

I shall write further as soon as possible. Meanwhile, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood
Secretary.

HAA:A.
Ottawa, December 7, 1943.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Onion Lake Residential School.

I am sending forward herewith a letter received from Dr. H. A. Alderwood, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Church of England.

May I direct your attention particularly to the suggestion made in the second paragraph of Dr. Alderwood's letter? You may remember that a somewhat similar proposal was submitted to the Minister by the Bishop of Saskatchewan in January, 1942. At that time, however, the Department was asked to take over the building at Prince Albert known as St. Alban's College on the understanding that it would be operated under the auspices of the Church of England as an additional residential school for the Anglican Indian pupils of northern Saskatchewan.

Canon Dixon, in a letter to the Minister dated January 15, 1943, submitted full and complete information with respect to the service that such a school might render and also gave the actual dimensions of the building. This letter reads in part as follows:

"We would further propose and recommend that such a school be housed in a building already available in Prince Albert. This building is the property of the Diocese of Saskatchewan and is situated on a piece of land measuring 250 ft. by 250 ft., on a hill overlooking the city and quite near the Prince Albert Collegiate High School.

"We believe this building and property would be well suited to the purposes of the school. The building..."
is of brick construction throughout. The cubic contents are 234,800 cubic feet. It is 46 ft. high and has two wings, measuring 75' x 55' and 72' x 33', respectively. It is equipped with steam heating, hot water, sanitary plumbing and electric light. It would accommodate from 75 to 100 children with the necessary staff. It is in good repair throughout but would require certain plastering, redecorating, etc., that would not cost more than $2,000.00.

The last census report (1938) indicates that there are, in the Battleford, Carlton, Duck Lake and Onion Lake agencies the following number of Indians:

| Agency     | Total Population | Church of England | Roman Catholic Church | United Church | Presbyterian |
|------------|------------------|-------------------|-----------------------|---------------|--------------|
| Battleford | 2470             | 664               | 1775                  |               |              |
| Carlton    | 2592             | 1770              | 538                   | 53            | 137          |
| Duck Lake  | 1140             | 537               | 408                   | 80            |              |
| Onion Lake | 1390             | 249               | 1078                  |               |              |

In addition to those classified as Anglican, United Church and Roman Catholic, there is a number classified as of aboriginal beliefs.

There are at present 14 residential schools in the province of Saskatchewan, with an authorized enrolment of 1650 pupils. Three of these schools - Gordon's in the Touchwood agency, Lac la Ronge, in the Carlton agency and Onion Lake in the Onion Lake agency, are operated under the auspices of the Anglican Church. Two - File Hills, File Hills agency, and Round Lake, Crooked Lake agency - are operated by the United Church. The other nine schools are operated under the auspices of the Catholic Church. The Lac la Ronge School, in the Carlton agency, is approximately 200 miles north of the city of Prince Albert.

The Onion Lake school, at the time of its destruction by fire on December 1, had an authorized enrolment of 100 pupils and an actual attendance of 125.
The Lac la Ronge school has also an authorized enrolment of 100. Our records indicate that the pupils enrolled at the Onion Lake School at the time of the fire were recruited from the following agencies:- Onion Lake 30; Carlton 54; Battleford 40; Duck Lake 4 and Saddle Lake 7. It will be noted that only 20 pupils were recruited from the Onion Lake agency. In view of this fact, it is just possible that an educational survey of the Onion Lake agency might be undertaken with the object of deciding what type of school should take the place of the one destroyed by fire. In view of the comparatively small number of pupils in attendance at the residential school, it is just possible that an improved day school might meet the needs of the Indian population.

The subject matter of Dr. Alderwood's letter has been very carefully discussed and reviewed with the officials of the Welfare and Training Division. In view of all the circumstances, I recommend,- (1) that the offer of the Bishop of Saskatchewan be accepted and that the necessary steps be taken to operate the St. Alban's College building at Prince Albert as a residential school, with an enrolment of approximately 100 pupils; (2) that, in lieu of rent, the expenditures for repairs, redecorating, etc., amounting to approximately $2,000.00, be borne by this branch.

It is altogether likely that the Principal, Mr. Ellis, will be anxious to retain the members of his present staff and it would be appreciated if we could have a decision in respect to this matter at an early date.

Director.
Ottawa December 7 1943

Reverend Doctor H. A. ALDERWOOD

Ottawa, December 8, 1943.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

The proposal submitted by you, on behalf of the Bishop of Saskatchewan, in your letter to the Indian Affairs Branch of December 4 - that the building at present available in the city of Prince Albert, known as St. Alban's College, be operated as an Indian residential school - has been given very careful consideration.

We are naturally anxious that the education of the pupils for whose instruction provision was made at the Onion Lake Residential School until the destruction of that building by fire should not be interrupted. We are disposed to think that the St. Alban's College, provided certain re-adjustments can be made, might prove suitable for the accommodation of these children, until an educational survey has been undertaken at the Onion Lake agency and a building program, designed to meet the educational needs of the Indian population, decided upon.

We have noted that the land available at the Prince Albert College, for gardening or for instruction in elementary agriculture, is somewhat limited, and it is our hope that additional lands can be secured at a reasonable cost. We are anxious, also, that the courses of study provided at this school, and indeed at all our Indian day and residential schools, should become increasingly more vocational and practical in character. With this thought in mind, it is our hope that arrangements can be made by the Principal of the school, whereby the senior pupils can receive instruction,

Reverend H. A. Alderwood, B.D.,
Secretary, Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
38-42 The Bible House,
164 Alexander Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.
either by the employment of a man qualified to provide vocational instruction on a half-time basis, or by the attendance of these pupils at the Prince Albert Collegiate or some other vocational centre. A number of our residential schools, established close to cities, have succeeded, in co-operation with the public school authorities, in working out a well-balanced course of study for their pupils, and we see no reason why such a course cannot be worked out at Prince Albert.

In view of all the circumstances, we are prepared:

1. To authorize the operation of the St. Alban's College as an Indian residential school for a five-year period;

2. That certain repairs, such as plastering, redecorating, etc., at an estimated cost not exceeding $5,000.00, be borne, in lieu of rent, by this department;

3. That the enrolment of 100 pupils and a per capita grant of $170.00, allowed at Onion Lake, be authorized at St. Alban's.

An attempt will be made to have the necessary repairs undertaken at the earliest possible date and thus enable the school to open for the reception of pupils early in the new year. It is our desire that the teachers who have been employed until now at the Onion Lake school should be re-assured by the Principal that they will be re-employed immediately following the re-organisation of the school at Prince Albert.

It would be appreciated if we could have from you an expression of opinion with respect to these proposals, at an early date.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

I am in receipt of your letter of December 2, giving information regarding the destruction by fire of the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School. The contents of this letter have been carefully noted.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to inform you that I got in touch with Mr. Cameron, the Indian Agent at Onion Lake and asked him to see the Reverend Mr. Ellis to find out if he had in mind any building in that part of the country whereby the Anglican Indian Residential School could be continued.

I am in receipt of a Night Letter from Mr. Cameron this morning to the effect that Stalbans College at Prince Albert could be used as a temporary Indian school for from 80 to 100 pupils. He further stated this arrangement would have the full approval of the Bishop of Saskatchewan who is most anxious that there be no break in the continuance of the school.

I am passing this on for your consideration. There were 115 children in the school when it burned down. If you are interested in this arrangement at all I could go to Prince Albert and look this proposition over.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Memorandum to:

Dr. H.W. McGill

Re Onion Lake Residential School

I discussed with the Minister your memorandum of the 7th instant and he read the letter Mr. Hoey had received from Rev. Dr. Alderwood.

He approved of accepting the offer of the Bishop of Saskatchewan to use the building formerly used for St. Albans College at Prince Albert and that the children formerly in the Onion Lake Residential School be transferred there, at least as many of them as can be accommodated.

The Minister suggested that in making arrangements with the church it should be clearly understood that they are only of a temporary nature and that the situation should be reviewed after the war.

The Minister also authorized expenditures being made up to the sum of $2,000 to carry out the necessary repairs and decorating.

Chief Executive Assistant.

Ottawa, December 8, 1943.
Loss $100,000 in school fire

A three-story Indian residential school in the Onion Lake agency, valued at about $100,000, was totally destroyed by fire early yesterday morning, according to information received by Mr. Christianson, Regina, superintendent of Indian affairs in Saskatchewan.

The Onion Lake agency is approximately 40 miles north of Lloydminster.

All the inmates and children living in the school were able to get out of the building without injury or serious distress.

Exact number of children living in the school is not known, Mr. Christianson said, but there were 120 enrolled at the close of the June term.

Built in 1925

The school, a wooden-frame structure built by the government in 1925, was operated under the auspices of the Anglican church, Mr. Christianson said.

According to word received from D. H. Cameron, Indian agent at Onion Lake, the children and other inmates from the reserve were removed from the school and temporarily housed at the nearby Fort Chipewyan Indian school. Children living nearby will be returned to their homes until suitable accommodation is found for them.

No details are available as to how the fire started.
Onion Lake Indian School Destroyed

Exclusive to The Edmonton Bulletin

LLOYDMINSTER, Dec. 1—According to information reaching Lloydminster, the Anglican Indian residential school at Onion Lake, about 40 miles north of here, was completely destroyed by fire this morning.

The building, which it is estimated cost about $300,000 to build, is now nothing but a mass of smoldering debris.

Rev. H. Ellis is principal of the school and up till the present no cause of the fire has been made known locally.
Ottawa, December 8, 1943.

The Secretary,
Indian & Eskimo School Commission, M.S.C.C.,

Dear Sir:

On December 1st, I sent to the Commission the following telegram:

MAIN SCHOOL BUILDING RAZED TO GROUND AT 4.30 a.m.
TODAY AND ALL CHILDREN AND STAFF SAFE. OUTBUILDINGS INTACT FULL REPORT LATER - ELLIS

On Wednesday 1st at 4.30 a.m. Miss Watkins came over to my bed-room in her night clothes and stated the school was on fire. I immediately went over and found the fire on the north wall of the chapel, about twelve feet high and two feet wide. I immediately then checked the children who had then left the dormitories and were in the recreation rooms. I proceeded to connect three lines of hose and took them across the roof of the engine room and played the water on the fire. I managed to put this fire out in about 15 to 20 minutes. It then broke out on the roof of the storm porch on the east door of the laundry. This was also put out, but I could see that it was still under the chancel in the chapel.

Mr. Waterhouse and Miss Watkins had already turned in the alarm, and Mr. Smith with Mr. Waterhouse had been putting out the fire in the laundry with three hand chemical extinguishers. Mr. Waterhouse then left to start the pump down at the engine house near the lake shore.

Mr. Swandt and Mrs. Ellis took a fire hose and began to cover the laundry ceiling which is also the floor of the chapel. Mr. Swandt took the ceiling down in places while they took turns in handling the hose.

I noticed then that the roof had caught fire, about a foot square. Owing to the gable ends, I think this was only partly put out, as I left the hose with an Indian in order to get the interior organised with the hose.

We then proceeded to work inside of the building. Little headway was made because of the heat and smoke. I then began to realize that I was beaten, but did not give up hope, hence nothing was removed from the building until the possible last chance. By the time the chapel was an inferno, fire for about sixty feet.

Having been beaten about 6.00 and knowing that we would not be able to save the building, the children were ordered outside with blankets and measures were taken to protect all outside buildings. We placed wet blankets on the roof to protect the residence. A slight wind was now blowing from the East.

At about six thirty the Onion Lake pupils were sent home.
with their guardians or parents and about one hundred children were taken over to Rev. Father Pascal at the R.C. School with three lady members of our staff.

That afternoon with the Indian Agent I visited Rev. Father Pascal and made arrangements to take all the children off their hands the next morning. That day, Thursday, December 2nd, all the children from the outlaying reserves had been delivered to their homes and I returned to the school Saturday at 10 p.m. Mr. Waterhouse took the children for the Battleford area and I with the driver and truck from the R.C. School took the children for Sandy Lake and the Prince Albert area.

**SALVAGED:**
- Main Building Heating Boiler
- Hot Water Boiler
- Two large compression tanks
- High pressure steam boiler
- Electrical pump and motor.

All these have been drained to prevent damage by frost.

The night watchman, who was relieving as Mr. Smith had been working on days to line the pump house with cement was reliable and had a printed list of duties to carry out. It was his first night.

I am of the opinion, that the fire started in the laundry, either from the clothes hung up or an over-heated stove pipe, which caused the tin to fire the roof lining.

I had left the office about 1:15 a.m. myself having spent the evening in placing the ration coupons on the summited sheets. I washed my hands in the bathroom and went down to the engine room and laundry before going home and I did not at any time detect smoke or fire. I was in my bedroom when I saw the night-watchman go over to the house, which was exactly at two o'clock the time that was set for to cover this point. I am fully satisfied in my own mind that the night watchman was reliable and as soon as he smelt smoke he immediately notified the engineer. The trouble must have happened between the time that he went down to the pump house, having his supper and then in the kitchen. It was when he left the kitchen to visit the laundry again that he found the clothes which were hanging up to dry were alight and burning. It is evident that the clothes around the bins in which the clothes dried were placed started the fire to its proportion.

**PERSONAL LOSSES:**

Most of the staff have lost all their personal belongings, such as glasses, false teeth and clothing and about $248.00 in cash which belonged to the school and staff. I have lost all my robes, communion vessels, etc. besides other things which was the means of giving the children much pleasure.

(Sgd) Henry Ellis

P.S. I am preparing this report under difficulties, hence will have time later to check more fully. E.
