Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re Onion Lake School

I beg to thank you for your telegram received this morning and confirm my reply suggesting that the local Indian Agent might meet with me tomorrow in inspecting the school building in Prince Albert.

I may say that our Commission met yesterday and it was unanimously agreed that it would be well for me to proceed at once to Prince Albert and gain full information on the spot. I was delighted to receive your message this morning and feel confident from my knowledge of the building that it offers a very valuable opportunity of continuing the work which otherwise may be left undone for a considerable period. I shall, of course, communicate with you fully after our inspection and conference with Bishop Martin and Principal Ellis and it will be most satisfactory if your Agent can be with us at the same time.

We have just received the first report of the fire from Mr. Ellis and I beg to enclose a copy in case you have not received one direct. I shall value the opportunity of being able to discuss the matter in person with our Principal.

Meanwhile, with kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood
Secretary

Dictated but not personally signed because of absence from the office
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Dr. McGill's telegram of the 8th instant in connection with the Indian and Eskimo School Commission meeting in Prince Albert on the 9th instant.

I wish to inform you I left Regina on the evening of the 8th instant for Prince Albert, arriving there the following morning, and attended a meeting of the Commission that afternoon at which were present Reverend Doctor H. A. Alderwood, the Right Reverend Bishop Henry D. Martin, and the Reverend H. Ellis from Onion Lake. We went over to St. Alban's College to look over the building and although this was a school at one time they have disposed of everything that was in the institution, therefore there is nothing there but the bare walls, the furnace, and a jacket heater. You have the size of the building, cubic contents, etc., therefore I will leave that out. I asked for a photograph of the building but nobody seemed to have one. However, Bishop Martin is having a photograph taken of the outside of the College as it appears from the street and he will furnish our Branch with this.

The following is a description of the building as I found it. It is a three-storey building with a basement, and it was erected about thirty-five years ago. It is built of red brick and has high ceilings on all floors. There is a full sized concrete basement which is divided up into several rooms. The furnace, I believe, is in good shape and I noticed that the grates were practically new. The information I received from Bishop Martin regarding this was that the City of Prince Albert had made an offer to purchase the building and had sent their engineer to check up on the heating plant. Upon looking around I noticed that the registers had been disconnected, and the Bishop stated the City Engineer had informed him the furnace had a heating capacity over and above what was required to heat this building, which is a good thing. The floors are all in pretty fair shape and I noticed that the Auditorium had a hardwood floor. The walls were also in fair shape. Some plaster was broken and would have to be patched up, and the plaster in the top storey might have to be replaced on account of the frost getting into the building but in the other rooms there is only a patch here and there that I consider will have to be attended to. Of course all of the walls would have to be kalsomined. There is a nice suite in the west end....
is a nice suite in the west end of the building for the Principal.

The greatest cost in putting this building in shape would be replacing the windows. A great many of them are broken. Apparently boys from the street have thrown stones through these windows and we noticed whiskey and beer bottles throughout the building where fellows had gone there, had a party, and then maybe thrown their beer bottles through the windows. I also noticed some storm windows that had been trampled on lying on the floor. However, a great many of the storm windows are piled up inside of the building and these probably are in pretty good shape, but there is no use of me saying any more about this because if it is the intention of our Branch to turn this building into a school naturally we would have to get an estimate from someone on what it would cost to replace the glass etc., fix up the plaster where it is broken, and do some kilosmining and painting. As the furnace appears to be in good shape and the building is connected with the City sewers, City Water Works, and City Electric Lights a great deal of the cost is saved right there. The building appears to be well put up and is still in good shape outside of the glass that has been broken, but replacing the glass might cost a considerable amount.

There were approximately 116 children in residence in the Onion Lake School when it burned down and I thought it would be interesting to note that in the event this building was turned into an Indian Residential School it probably would be more centrally located than where it was before. In any event it would save a great deal of hauling.

The 116 children attending the Onion Lake School were from reserves in the following agencies:

| Agency               | Reserve          | Number |
|----------------------|------------------|--------|
| Battleford Agency    | Thunderchild     | 21     |
|                      | Sweetgrass       | 6      |
|                      | Red Pheasant     | 8      |
|                      | Little Pine      | 4      |
|                      |                  | 39     |
| Onion Lake Agency    | Frog Lake        | 1      |
|                      | Onion Lake       | 14     |
|                      | Loon Lake        | 4      |
|                      |                  | 19     |
| Carlton Agency       | Sandy Lake       | 30     |
|                      | Montreal Lake    | 15     |
|                      | Round Plain      | 3      |
|                      |                  | 48     |
| Saddle Lake Agency   |                   | 7      |
| Duck Lake Agency     | James Smith      | 3      |

116 pupils.

Outside of the fact...........
Outside of the fact that there were 19 children from the Onion Lake Agency attending the old school the present site would be more central for the remainder of the pupils. Naturally the Bishop and the Secretary of the Commission are very anxious to keep the school going and the only way that can be done is to take over the building in Prince Albert.

If there is any more information I can give you I will be willing to do so but I think I have covered the ground fairly well and naturally, our Minister will make the final decision in the matter.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
December 15, 1943.

Memorandum:

MR. J.C. KELLY,
SALVAGE OFFICER.

The Indian residential school at Onion Lake, Saskatchewan, was destroyed on the 30th ultimo by fire and the Anglican Church has offered us a building owned by them in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. In order to furnish it the following will be required:

1. 150 single beds with mattresses and pillows, also blankets and sheets, if possible.

2. Kitchen equipment, including large range and other kitchen utensils.

3. Tables and chairs suitable for dining rooms.

4. Miscellaneous equipment would be required to furnish reasonably a building which would be occupied by approximately 150 persons, including adults and children.

I realize that the above is a rather large order, but I thought that it might be possible to secure some of the equipment that would be required for refurnishing this building and I feel certain that you will give the matter your kind consideration.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, December 16, 1943.

Mr. M. Christianson, General Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Building, Scarth & Victoria Streets,
Regina, Sask.

Re: Operation of St. Alban's College,
as Residential School.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 13 and to thank you for the information contained therein.

In this connection I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copy of a letter dated December 8, 1942, forwarded by the Minister to the Reverend H. A. Alderwood, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory. In view of the definite proposal submitted in this communication by the Minister, it is altogether likely that a decision will be reached with respect to the operation of the school at an early date.

Acting Director.
Hon. T. A. Grerar,
Minister of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA,
Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have to thank you for your letter of the 8th, and for your willingness to authorize the use of the St. Alban's College building in the city of Prince Albert as an Indian Residential School to take care of the pupils hitherto provided for at Onion Lake.

I note that if satisfactory arrangements can be made with the Diocese of Saskatchewan, the Department is prepared to use this building for a five-year period, with an enrolment of 100 pupils at a per capita grant of $170.00. This is eminently satisfactory to our Commission, and we are most grateful to you for the prompt consideration given to our suggestion.

As the property belongs to the Diocese of Saskatchewan, I have no authority to speak in regard to the terms on which the building is available, but have immediately passed on your letter to the Rt. Rev. H. D. Martin, D.D., the Bishop of Saskatchewan. I have already been assured by the Bishop that it is his desire that the building should be used for such a purpose and that it will be made available on the most reasonable terms possible. I cannot quite understand the use of the term "in lieu of rental" in your letter, and imagine that Bishop Martin will be glad to have some clarification of this. I note that necessary repairs will be undertaken by the Department at a cost not to exceed $2,000.00, but scarcely think that the phrase "in lieu of rent" refers to the whole five-year period. I assume that it refers to the first year, leaving the rental for subsequent years to be mutually agreed. My understanding is that the Diocese has had to pay a considerable sum annually for taxation but that this will be much reduced if the building is used for educational purposes. There will, however, still be an annual charge to be made, and I feel sure it is the intention of the Department to provide a reasonable amount to cover this and other expenses. To save time, may I suggest that discussion of this point be undertaken directly with Bishop Martin?
Hon. T. A. Grérar - 2.

December 13, 1943.

I have just returned from a visit to Prince Albert, and may say that I was much impressed with the building and the opportunities it seems to offer in this emergency. The question of securing some additional land for farm and garden purposes would not seem to be too difficult, and is being investigated locally.

I have noted carefully your hopes in the matter of vocational instruction, and can assure you of my personal cooperation in working towards this end in all our schools. Prince Albert should offer considerable advantages in this matter, and we shall certainly do our best to use them.

The loss of the Onion Lake School has naturally been a heavy blow to us. From my investigation I feel confident that under the direction of Principal Ellis, the school was efficiently administered and all possible care was taken to prevent fire. I am also satisfied that everything possible was done to extinguish the fire when once it had been discovered. We are profoundly thankful that no life was lost, and are now hopeful that the instruction of the pupils may speedily be resumed. The members of our staff are being retained, and we shall do everything possible to co-operate with the Department in preparing for the resumption of the work at the earliest possible date. Principal Ellis was inquiring if you desired him to do anything in regard to securing the necessary equipment. Possibly your Department will be communicating with him direct in regard to this.

Again thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

N.A. Alderwood

Secretary.

HAATÁ.

Ottawa, December 17, 1943.

Dear Bishop Martin:

It is my understanding that Dr. Alderwood has sent forward to you a letter dated December 8, 1943, received by him from the Minister of this Department. Dr. Alderwood, in his letter of reply, dated December 13, suggests that time might be saved if we communicated with Your Lordship, with respect to the subject matter of the Minister's communication.

When the Minister stated in his letter that repairs at the St. Alban's College would be undertaken by the Department, at a cost not to exceed $2,000.00, and that this cost would be borne by the Department, in lieu of rent, he had in mind, of course, the repairs that were urgently needed and the rental that might be allowed for the first year or so. We have now before us Mr. Christianson's report, immediately following his inspection of the building, and it is just possible that the repairs, plastering, new windows, flooring, etc., may amount to a sum exceeding $2,000.00.

We have at this date 76 residential schools in operation. Of these, 26 are the property of the Anglican and Roman Catholic Churches. The records here indicate that the Department has not at any time paid rent for school buildings. The only exception to this, that I can find, is an allowance made for the rent of a dwelling house at Carcross immediately following the destruction of the Carcross School by fire a few years ago. Residential schools, when built or established by the Churches, are operated on the understanding that the Government will pay a fixed per capita grant, supply the school with the necessary equipment and keep the building in a reasonable state of repair. In practice this policy appears to work out to the satisfaction of all parties concerned. Unless the St. Alban's College building, therefore, is

Right Rev. H. D. Martin, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert, Sask.
in an exceptionally good state of repair at this date, the amounts required to keep it in repair and supply the necessary equipment during the next five year period would, in all probability, equal, if not exceed the actual rent of the building if it were operated on a rental basis. I have not, however, sufficient information at my disposal to express a worthwhile opinion on this matter.

Church-owned residential schools, with one exception, appear to be established in unorganized districts and consequently not subject to municipal taxation. The exception is the Roman Catholic residential school at Squamish, in northern Vancouver. The Department paid municipal taxes on this building for a number of years. Two years ago our right to do so was challenged by the Treasury officials, who took the position that crown property or property in use by the Crown was exempt from such taxes. However, you will naturally be anxious to avoid any controversy with the city of Prince Albert on this somewhat delicate subject. I am confident that the city will be prepared to accept a nominal tax when they are assured by Your Lordship that the building is being used for the education of Indians recruited in the main from the Prince Albert district. Whatever the tax may be, however, it should not be borne by the Diocese or by the M.S.C.C. We could probably meet the levy by an adjustment of our per capita grants, although we are naturally anxious not to establish a precedent by increasing grants at a time when a number of residential schools are experiencing difficulty in financing their operations.

I am anxious that you should, at your convenience, turn these matters over in your mind and let us have an expression of opinion in respect to these tentative proposals.

We are communicating with the Principal and asking him for a list of the equipment that may be required.

I am sending forward a copy of this letter to Dr. Alderwood, for his information.

Yours sincerely,

Acting Director.

Copy sent to Dr. Alderwood
Ottawa,
December 20, 1943.

AIR MAIL

Reverend Sir:

Recent information indicates that if the St. Alban's College is taken over for residential school purposes it will be necessary to secure all the equipment that is required.

We have already taken up with the Salvage Officer the question of securing beds etc., if these are available.

It would be appreciated if you would let me have, at the earliest possible date, a complete list of the equipment and furnishings that you consider would be required in the event of our taking over St. Alban's College. You should give this list by rooms; for instance, the number of beds etc. for the dormitories, the equipment required for the kitchen, the equipment required for the staff rooms and the equipment required for the classrooms. With reference to school desks, these can be secured as follows:

Size No. 5 - small
" " 3 - medium
" " 1 - large

You will note that the above are the only sizes that we can obtain at the present time and the number of each size should be stated.

You may also let me know the length of blackboard that you consider is required in the classrooms.

Rev. Henry Ellis,
Principal,
Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School,
Lloydminster, Sask.
and you should also submit a requisition for the books and stationery needed.

As mentioned above, this matter should have your immediate attention.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosey,

BOARD OF HOME MISSIONS - UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA

299 Queen Street West,
Toronto 2, Ontario,

December 15th, 1943.

The Honourable T. A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

I have today come across the enclosed clipping from the "Regina Leader" of December 11th. I am delighted to know that there seems, according to Mr. Christianson, such good prospects of the Indian Residential School at Onion Lake being rebuilt. It at least gives us the opportunity of reminding you - which, of course, we do not need to do - that in January, 1941, two school-rooms were burned at Alberni, and some time later the school-room at File Hills was burned down. We would not want to prejudice the chances of our Anglican friends of having their school at Onion Lake rebuilt; but we presume that these reconstructions will be placed in order of time. I am sure you would not object to my reminding you of these things.

Yours sincerely,

Sgd.) Geo. Dorey.
Minister's Office

17th December, 1943.

Deputy Minister,

I am attaching hereto a letter addressed to the Minister by Rev. Geo. Dorey, D.D., Associate Secretary, Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, Toronto 2, Ont., enclosing a clipping from the Regina Leader in which Mr. Christianson is quoted as saying that the chances of the Onion Lake School being rebuilt look promising. Ottawa, December 20, 1943.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of December 15 and also a clipping taken from the Regina Leader, sent forward therewith.

It is, to me, a matter of regret that the funds at our disposal for the administration of Indian affairs have not enabled us to undertake the construction of Indian day or residential schools during the last three year period. I can assure you, however, that when the Government's post-war rehabilitation program is under review, the claims of the Indian Affairs Branch for additional educational facilities will be given earnest consideration.

It is unnecessary to state that I agree with you, that schools destroyed by fire as far back as 1941 should have the first claim when appropriations are available.

Yours sincerely,

Reverend George Dorey, D.D.,
Associate Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
United Church of Canada,
299 Queen Street West,
Toronto 2, Ont.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, December 21, 1943.

Mr. M. Christianson, General Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Building, Scarth & Victoria Streets,
Regina, Sask.

I am sending forward copy of a letter received by the Minister from the Reverend Dr. George Dorey, Associate Secretary of the Home Mission Board of the United Church of Canada. I am sending forward also a clipping from the Regina Leader, of December 11, enclosed by Dr. Dorey with his communication to the Minister.

You are, no doubt, aware that the limited appropriations at our disposal have not enabled us to build either day or residential schools at any time during the last three year period, and no provision has been made in the 1944-45 estimates for the construction of such buildings. In view of these facts, no consideration has been given by the Minister or the officials of this Branch to the rebuilding of the residential school at Onion Lake.

We are anxious, however, to have an expression of opinion from you with respect to the statement contained in the first paragraph of the news item taken from the Regina Leader. It will be necessary to have this statement before a satisfactory reply to Dr. Dorey can be prepared for the signature of the Minister. In this connection may we refer to a letter to you dated March 8, 1942, and signed by the Director. In the penultimate paragraph of that communication the Director suggested that before statements on departmental policy were made to the Press, these statements should be sent forward to this Branch to be checked. You might return the newspaper clipping with your reply.

Your immediate attention to this matter will be very much appreciated.

Acting Director.
1. At 6:00 AM this date the writer was notified by D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, that the Indian Residential (Anglican) School was afire and getting out of control. The Agent advised that he was proceeding there, and I informed him that I would leave immediately. Patrol was made accompanied by Alex Finlay only available help at Onion Lake village. The school in question is located about 7 miles east and south of Onion Lake village.

2. On arrival at the school it was seen that the fire had consumed more than two thirds of the entire building, that there was no possible chance of getting it under control. The only measures possible were prevention of its spreading to the residence of the Rev. Ellis, principal of the school, and other surrounding buildings. This was accomplished and fire was confined to the main building. By 8:00 AM the main building was burned level to the ground.

3. The building in question was of wood construction, the western wing three stories high. At the time of the fire the school apart from the staff housed 115 Indian pupils, 59 boys and 56 girls, ranging in age from 4 to 16 years. All the pupils had been safely removed from the building by the teaching staff, and were conveyed to the R.C. Residential school two miles away, there cared for by Father MacCall and his staff.

4. Concerning the outbreak and possible cause of this fire, I was informed by Rev. Ellis that he had been called at about 4:30 AM by the school matron Miss Watkins. The fire was then confined to the laundry, situated in the north east end of the building. The fire was being fought by the engineer waterhouse, farm instructor Schmidt and regular night watchman Smith. According to Rev. Ellis the fire was got under control in the laundry, but it was then seen that it had spread between the ceiling of the laundry and the floor of the chapel immediately south and above the laundry. The laundry ceiling was lined with tin the heat underneath had spread fire to the chapel floor and floor under the chancel of the chapel. Efforts to control this fire by Rev. Ellis and his staff failed, fire then spread the entire length of the building. Efforts to control the fire may be deduced from the following, upon the outbreak of fire the children were immediately removed from the dormitories to the play-room, remaining there for over an hour with the teaching staff until it was finally realized that the fire could not be controlled.

5. Further according to Rev. Ellis, he had been in the main building until 2:00 AM, and found everything normal at that hour with no suspicion of fire. Shortly after retiring to his own residence he heard the night watch on his rounds also, check the fire in the Ellis residence. Over

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The night-watch on this night in question was Stephen Hyman, a senior pupil at the school. This was his first night and only a temporary measure as the regular night watchman Jack Smith had been employed the entire day before on concrete work in the boiler-room. Hyman aged 16 years has been a pupil of the school for seven years, has a younger brother and two younger sisters also attending the school. They are natives of the Sandy Lake I.R. According to Rev. Ellis, Hyman was well acquainted with his duties for the night, having a regular schedule drawn up for him. This included check up of the boiler-room, pump-house and laundry.

At the time of the fire the laundry room contained the clothes of the girl pupils washed the previous day, and were on drying lines and racks. The laundry contained a bake-oven and stove for laundry drying purposes; both had fires in them, and maintained and checked by the night-watch. The other fires over which watch was kept being the furnace in the boiler-room and fire in the pump-house. The Rev. Ellis did not suspect anyone of starting the fire, and believed it to be entirely of accidental origin, possibly from a spark igniting the clothes drying in the laundry, or possible overheating of a stove-pipe, although all the latter had been cleaned at a recent date. Subsequent investigations did not reveal any reasons to suspect arson or that the fire had been started by any person with view to sabotage.

Stephen Hyman who had been removed with other pupils to the R.C. school was seen and the following statement obtained after questioning in the presence of the Junior Teacher Mrs. Davies:

"Last night November 30th, I was night watch at the school. I started work at seven o'clock. My job was to check the boiler-room, laundry, pump-house and other parts of the building. I checked the laundry and other parts during the evening. I last checked the laundry after two o'clock in the morning after I had been to Mr. Ellis's house. That time I put six sticks of wood in each of the fires in the laundry, that is the bake-oven and the laundry drying stove. From there I went to the play-room and stayed about half an hour, then checked the boiler-room and the pump-house. When I came back from the pump-house I went to the kitchen and had my supper, then I went to the play-room. I stayed only a short time in the play-room then checked the boiler-room and returned to the play-room. Shortly after I returned to the play-room from the boiler-room I smelled smoke. I then called Mr. Waterhouse that would be about four o'clock. The last time I went to the laundry-room was after two o'clock when I put wood on both fires. I put about six sticks of 12" wood in each. I don't remember if I checked the draughts on the two fires. I didn't smell any fire then."

The pump-house which Hyman refers to is situated about 300 yards south east of the main building, contains the engine which pumps the water to the compression tanks contained in the main building immediately north of the boiler-room.
IMMEDIATELY NORTH OF THE BOILER-ROOM. The laundry adjoined the part of the building containing the compression tanks and the boiler-room but was not directly connected with them.

9. From Mrs. Mother K. Davies, junior teacher, it was ascertained that she had been awakened by smoke around four or four thirty A.M. She ran immediately to the matron's room then to the farm instructor, awakening them. At that time she saw a glow of fire through the laundry window. The balance of her time was occupied attending to the pupils and their eventual removal from the building.

10. The engineer Wilfred Waterhouse was seen, and gave the following statement:

"I went to bed about 11:30 P.M. on the 30th, before that I had checked the building and found everything in order. Young Hyman was night-watch; he is a good reliable lad. The first notification I had of fire was in the night when Hyman woke me up. I don't know what time it would be. He said there was something burning in the building. I got right up and found the fire in the laundry. All the clothes were alight on the drying lines and racks; also, the clothes bins on the east side were alight. We got the fires out with the chemical extinguishers. When we got rid of the smoke we could see a red glow in the ceiling and the chapel floor. The laundry had a tin ceiling with a wooden floor immediately above it. The fire had got under that. General alarm had been turned in, and it was then we used the hydrants, the hydrant from the boiler-room was used first then the one situated in the ground-floor of the building, but we couldn't get at the fire properly to control it. It got out of hand and spread the length of the building."

11. The hydrants mentioned by the engineer were connected with the compression tanks situated just north of the boiler-room, in the main building. When the fire spread westwards from the laundry it will be realized that it enveloped the boiler-room and part containing compression tanks, and would interfere with successful fighting of the fire. Had the entire fire-fighting equipment been contained in a separate unit from the main building better control of the fire might have been accomplished.

12. Investigations failed to reveal any evidence that the fire originated from any other means than accidental or through the carelessness of anyone. Every effort apparently was made by the Rev. Ellis and his staff to save the building. Great credit is due to the teaching staff under Miss Watkins assisted by Miss Potter and Mrs. Davies in the manner in which they safely evacuated all the pupils from the building without loss of life or any personal harm.

13. This school involves considerable loss to the department concerned, and was not insured, as I understand, is not the practice of the department to do so. All the teaching staff lost their entire belongings, none carried any insurance. No further action will be taken Detachment unless otherwise instructed. Copy of this report been forwarded direct to O.C.F.P. Div.C.I.R., Regina.

H.G.B.C. H.P.W.
O.C. "N" Division,
R.C.M.P. Police, Regina, Sask.

FORWARDED: It is noted that the fire started in the laundry room of the school and spread to the chapel where it could not be controlled. Apparently neither the building nor the contents were insured. Possibly the fire started from an overheated stove in the laundry room and, as it enveloped the boiler room and compression tanks, it hampered the fire fighters.

It would appear, under the circumstances, that no further police action is necessary in the matter and, unless I have your instructions to the contrary, I will consider the file closed.

4-12-43

Commanding N.-Battleford S/Div.
(F. E. Spriggs)

December 21, 1943

The Office of the Director,

Department of Mines and Resources,

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of your airmail letter of December 17th and I hasten to answer it. I was becoming most anxious as to what action was being taken with regard to the rehabilitation of St. Albert's College building here. Dr. Alderwood sent me a copy of the minister's letter to him and so I was awaiting further word from the Department.

In the first place I think I should tell you something about this building. It was built at a cost of approximately $80,000, and is of solid brick construction throughout. It has a splendid heating equipment which includes a boiler of ample capacity installed in recent years, of tubular steel construction, and also a large jacket heater and tank of 220 gallons capacity. The foundations are in perfect condition and the building itself shows no signs of deterioration. There will be some necessary repairs to be undertaken before occupancy particularly with regard to plastering and minor repairs. Unfortunately some boys have recently broken a number of windows which will add to the expense.

The Diocese will need to secure $500 for arrears of taxes on the building to be paid by December 31st. We are hopeful of securing this amount and we are most desirous that the building should be occupied for the carrying on of the education of these Indian children. The main taxes on the building are:

Local Improvement Tax 100.74
Provincial Public Revenue 38.21

making a total of 138.95

The city of Prince Albert is not in a very affluent condition financially. It has a large bond indebtedness which keeps our taxes high. Moreover, they have been most kind to us in past years and I rather hesitate to go to them asking further considerations. Also, of course, there is the matter of insurance on the building; we have always kept the building insured and of necessity we shall have to increase the coverage when it is occupied as a residential school.
It is not my desire to in any way embarrass the Department by asking it to establish a precedent, and if you think that an adjustment of the per-capita grant in this particular instance would do this, may I therefore make the following suggestion: The Department is already using the term "in lieu of rent" with regard to the approximate $2000. for the necessary repairs and the rental that might be allowed for the first year or so. I would therefore suggest that the same term, namely "in lieu of rent", be applied in regard to further amounts paid to the Diocese of Saskatchewan for the use of the building. I do not think that the Department would wish a diocese such as ours to bear this cost. Neither do I think I can apply to the R.S.C.C. for the necessary money.

I am not quite sure from your letter just what action you wish me to take. Do you wish the Diocese to set a yearly rental? If so, I shall be pleased to call our Finance Committee together and name an adequate rental but if the Department would prefer to set the amount they think adequate and fair, then I feel quite sure that this Diocese will agree. What we are all most anxious about is that the work of repairs should be commenced as soon as possible and that the Indian children concerned be enabled to continue their education. I am sure also that this is the desire of yourself and the Department and more especially the minister.

I hope I have adequately answered your letter and given you the information you require. May I again say how anxious I am that this work of repairing the building should go ahead with as little delay as possible.

Wishing you the season's greetings, I am,

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, December 23, 1943.

Dear Bishop Martin:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

The fact that the St. Alban's College building is the property of the Diocese of Saskatchewan and that the school, when re-opened, will be operated under the auspices of the M.S.C.C. is apt to make the initial financing a little awkward. However, we are today communicating with the Principal, in the hope that the repair work can be undertaken under his supervision, at once. I feel sure that Mr. Ellis can undertake and carry through these repairs much more speedily than we can. It so happens that we have no Indian agent in the city of Prince Albert.

I have noticed Your Lordship's reference to taxes, and the city levy appears to me to be very reasonable. Would it be acceptable to the Diocese if we spent a minimum of $2,000.00 on the school, in lieu of rent, for the year 1944, and allowed you the sum of $2,000.00 annually for the next 4 years, on the understanding that any repairs that might be necessary would be undertaken either by the Diocese or by the Principal and that the taxes also would be paid by the Diocese? If this allowance is acceptable to you, it might be advisable to submit a voucher for one half the amount semi-annually.

May I embrace this opportunity to express the hope that you will spend an enjoyable and restful Christmas.

Yours sincerely,

Right Rev. Henry D. Martin, D.D., Acting Director.
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Sask.

CANADA
I have to refer to an article in the Regina Leader Post of February 27th regarding an interview given by you respecting the Saskatchewan Indians and their part played in the present war. I have noted your statement that the regulations bar Indian enlistments in the Royal Canadian Air Force and that there are no enlistments in the Navy—not, however, being due to regulations, but because the Indians do not try.

Our information is that Indians are not accepted in the Navy because it is a strict rule that all personnel must be of pure European descent and of the white race, and among other things because the confined living spaces of naval rating do not lend themselves to satisfactory mixing of the white races with Indians.

I may add that this is confidential information.

In regard to the Air Force, Indians are eligible on the same basis as members of any other race. A number of Indian applicants have been accepted and are now in the Air Force; others have been rejected due to lack of educational qualifications or because they cannot pass the physical test, but not on account of the fact that they are Indians. It is suggested that before making any observations on a question of this kind in the press, the subject of the proposed statement should be referred to this Branch to be checked.

According to our records only three Indian girls have enlisted in the Canadian Women's Army Corps—Margaret Stonechild of the File Hills Agency, and Mary Greyeyes and Gladys Breaver of the Carlton Agency. I note you state that there are twelve Indian women who have enlisted, and I should be obliged if you would advise me of the names and agencies to which these girls belong.

Director.

CANADA
December 29, 1943

Dear Mr. Hoey:

This is to acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 23rd with reference to the use of St. Alban's College as an Indian Residential School.

We held a meeting of our Finance Committee last night when I put before them the contents of your last letter. As I said in a previous letter, we are all most anxious to co-operate with the Government to the fullest extent of our facilities in order that the education of these Indian Children should be forwarded. Our Committee voted to accept the terms, as outlined by you in your letter, for the use of the St. Alban's College building; namely that for the year 1944 the Government will spend a minimum of $2000. on the school in lieu of rent and that the Government allows the Diocese of Saskatchewan $2000. annually for the next four years on the understanding that any repairs that might be necessary would be undertaken either by the Diocese or by the Principal and that the taxes also would be paid by the Diocese. It is also noted that we would be required to submit a voucher for one-half that amount semi-annually. I note in your letter that there is reference made to insurance on the building. This, I take it, will be the responsibility of the Diocese. I might also add that our Committee decided to secure $500. in settlement of past taxes and pay this amount to the City of Prince Albert before December 31st. This means that the building is free of all encumbrance as from December 31st, 1943.

Mr. Ellis has been in the city since last Monday and has been most active in interviewing tradesmen of various kinds with a view to rehabilitating the college building. He is very keen and is most hopeful that the college will reopen in the not too distant future.

Again thanking you for your co-operation in this important matter and with kindest personal regards,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Ep/K
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa,
January 3, 1944.

Dear Bishop Martin:

I desire to acknowledge Your Lordship's letter of December 29 and to thank you very heartily for the information contained therein.

I was particularly gratified to learn that Mr. Ellis had arrived at Prince Albert and was at the moment busily engaged in securing information on the repairs necessary at the college. It is our earnest hope that the school will be in a position to open at the earliest possible date.

I did not refer in my letter of December 23 to the taxes on the school building for the simple reason that the Government has never insured Government property at any time and it is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, under existing Treasury regulations for us to make such payments. I can only express the hope that the Diocese will be in a position to meet this disbursement without undue hardship.

With best wishes for the year upon which we have now entered, I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

Rt. Rev. H.D. Martin, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Sask.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

January 1st., 1944.

Mr. A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am pleased to inform you that events leading up to the occupancy of St. Alban's College here as an Indian Residential School seem to be progressing very well indeed. Mr. Ellis has been here all week and has been very busy about many things and with many people.

There is one question regarding which I must ask your advice, and it is this. Mr. Ellis is receiving estimates from men who will do the necessary repairs to the building. When this work has been accomplished and the accounts are rendered, is it your wish that we forward these accounts for payment direct from the Department, or is it your wish that we submit a voucher to you for any given amount and pay the accounts here. Mr. Ellis asked me this question this morning and as I could not give him a definite answer I thought it wise to write you and get your advice. You probably have a set policy on matters such as this.

Wishing you a Happy New Year—and may we have Peace before the beginning of 1945,

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter 115-1-1 dated the 23rd ult., I beg to advise that I have just returned from Prince Albert where I have planned St. Alban's College for the furnishings and school equipment required and the requisitions were sent to you from there by Air Mail.

St. George's to Accommodate 80 Pupils as Indian School

St. George's college will open early in the new year as an Anglican residential school for Indians to partially replace school facilities which were destroyed by fire recently at Onion Lake, Saskatchewan.

In a communication to city council last night the Anglican diocese of Saskatchewan asking a reduction in outstanding tax arrears stated that they hoped to open the building which had been vacant for more than a year as a residential school for Indians.

With the promise of full settlement of the arrears in taxes he written off upon the opening of the school Alderman C. S. Lacroix moved that $500 be accepted in full settlement of taxes to the end of 1943.

This provides for the payment of approximately $500 against total arrears in taxes of approximately $2,074. The $500 is approximately the total improvement tax portion of the arrears.

A large amount will be spent by the department of Indian affairs in converting the old building for use as an Indian school.

It was pointed out that it would be of advantage to the city to have the school occupied since the teaching staff will be brought into the city and supplies will be purchased here. Council was advised by Rev. Canon W. E. Payton, who was present at the committee session, that approximately 80 pupils will be accommodated in the school.

General:

On December 1st and 2nd I spent a great deal of time at the C. of E. School and on the reserve, in connection with the fire which completely destroyed the main building of the School early in the morning of the 1st. This unfortunate occurrence was reported both by wire and by air mail at the time.

Donald H. Cameron,

January 26th, 1944.

Memorandum:

Re: Indian Residential School,
Onion Lake, Saskatchewan.

Dr. McGill's memorandum of the 20th instant dealing with heating equipment in the ruins of the above school, and bearing your notation dated January 21st, 1944, is acknowledged.

We note Mr. Christianson has advised the Indian Affairs Branch that the heating boiler, high pressure boiler and compression tanks have not been damaged in any way by the fire which destroyed the building on December 21st last, and that the equipment was drained by the water immediately after the building collapsed. He has further advised that radiators, piping, fire escapes and metal beds could be sold.

No information other than the above has been furnished this Service regarding the fire; but the building, except for concrete basement walls, was of frame construction, and is stated to have collapsed during the fire. Under such circumstances, it might be expected that much of the equipment, and other material referred to, will be buried in wreckage and could not be examined.

In this connection, not only heating equipment, but lighting plant units, and water supply equipment were in use at the school. No reference has been made to the present condition of this equipment.

We feel that if present weather conditions at Onion Lake permit, radiators, fire escapes, metal beds, piping and any other damaged metal articles should be removed from the wreckage and stored under the supervision of the Indian Agent. The former boiler room, and engine room should be cleared of rubbish and all heating, lighting plant and pumping equipment completely exposed to view. The Indian Agent should then prepare an inventory embodying both the equipment which does not appear to have been damaged, and material no longer usable.

Copies of this inventory should be furnished to this Service, by the Indian Affairs Branch, for the use of our officer, at such time as an inspection can be carried out.

It will be appreciated that unless it has been possible to protect equipment installed in the former Boiler Room and Engine Room, from the weather, and from ice produced by fire-fighting operation, no inspection should be attempted before the spring. The Indian Affairs Branch should advise us in this connection as soon as possible.

[Signature]

Director

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: St. Alban's School-Prince Albert

There seems to be some misunderstanding as to responsibility for the necessary work involved in placing this building in good order for use as an Indian residential school. It has been our understanding that the Diocese of Saskatchewan were handing over the building to the Department for a period of five years and that the Department would spend a minimum of $2,000.00 on the school in lieu of rent for the year 1944 and a like sum annually for the next four years. The Department would be responsible for the expenditures incurred in necessary repairs at the beginning but the Diocese would take care of these and all the taxes in subsequent years. We received a copy of your letter Ref. #115-1-1 to Rev. H. Ellis dated December 23rd, in which he was asked to act as the agent of the Department in putting the necessary work in hand. We learned that Mr. Ellis had gone to Prince Albert for this purpose and had arranged for the work to be done.

Our Principal has now written to us about various necessary work and seems to be in doubt as to financial responsibility. He desired some partitions to be removed to provide dormitory accommodation for the boys at a cost of $150.00. We referred him to the Bishop of Saskatchewan, whose permission we felt should be secured before any structural alterations were made. He also reports that the heating plant and water system had to be placed in order at a cost of $282.40, and now speaks of laying a cement floor in the laundry and installing drain pipes so that the equipment may operate safely and efficiently. Mr. Ellis also who is to pay for these changes and declares that the Diocese has no money. Our feeling is that these are items which should certainly be included as part of the necessary cost of making the building ready for use. We have no idea as to the amount that has been spent for the initial repairs but cannot feel that the Commission should be asked to face these matters at all. Our understanding is that an arrangement has been made as between the Department and the owner of the building and that our responsibility really commences when the school is in operation. I believe there are about 50 children now in residence and that the staff is complete. Only lack of some necessary equipment has prevented the Principal from bringing in the remainder of the children to the school.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)
I shall be grateful for your reply to these questions as our Principal seems to be in perplexity, and the Bishop of Saskatchewan also speaks of lack of a clear understanding.

Thanking you, and with kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood
Secretary.

HAA:WS
Ottawa, April 19, 1944.

Re: St. Alban's School,
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 12th instant and note with interest the opinions expressed therein.

It is my experience that misunderstandings are apt to arise when schools are administered in part by the Bishop of the Diocese, the Indian Residential School Commission and the Government. However, I shall attempt to give you a brief outline of our commitments at St. Alban's as I understand them. In this connection I am sending forward copy of a letter dated December 28, 1943, addressed by me to Bishop Martin and a copy of the Bishop's reply thereto.

I may state that when the Minister was asked to authorize the operation of the St. Alban's College as an Indian residential school, following the destruction of the Onion Lake School by fire, the request came at a time when we had made no provision whatever in the estimates for the amounts necessary to repair and furnish the college. The Minister's authorization was granted on the understanding that we would attempt to take the amounts necessary for repair work and furnishings from the comparatively small amounts allotted to other residential schools, and this has been done. The sum already spent - and the accounts have not yet been all received - for labour, repairs

Reverend H. A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian & Eskimo
Residential School Comm., M.S.C.C.,
The Bible House, Alexander Ave. E.,
Winnipeg, Man.
repairs and equipment amounts to $14,294.30. This, I feel sure you will agree, is quite a substantial amount. I must state frankly that from the reports we had received on this college, both from the church authorities and from Mr. Christianson, we were of the opinion that the full cost would not exceed 50% of this amount. You can readily realize, therefore, that with no provision made for such an expenditure in either last year's estimates or this year's appropriations, there is a limit beyond which we cannot possibly go.

I can only state that in view of the conditions confronting us at St. Alban's, we shall attempt to do all that is possible with the limited funds at our disposal and in so doing express the hope that your Commission will be prepared to assume at least a small amount of the expenditures necessary for the reopening of this school.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

May 2, 1944.

Re St. Alban's School, Prince Albert.

I have read with interest your letter of April 19th and may say that I had the pleasure of visiting the school on the same date.

My impressions on the whole were most favourable and I was particularly gratified with the excellent quality of the equipment supplied by the Department. The Principal and his staff had worked hard to get the building ready for use, but had been handicapped by the piecemeal manner in which the equipment had come to hand. They had on the day in question some 50 children in residence and I gather than a number of others have since arrived.

I was disappointed to find that a rainstorm had revealed that the roof was in need of some repair, as the rain had entered at one or two points and had spoiled some of the decorating recently carried out. A more serious lack concerned the wooden fire escape which appears prominently in the photograph which I believe you have received. This had been neglected and allowed to rot so that the top section was entirely out of use. Not stopping to discuss the question of responsibility for the expense, I instructed the Principal to see that this was attended to without delay. I have also been in touch with Bishop Martin in regard to it and he assures me that the matter has been put in hand.

In regard to expenditure incurred, I would gather that this has been largely for the equipment necessary to conduct the school. I have most of the figures from our Principal as to the cost of repair and decorating work and it seems to me that this has scarcely exceeded the $2,000.00 amount authorized by the Department. Such further expense as may be entailed in putting the fire escape and roof in good repair is a matter that may have to be discussed with the Diocese of Saskatchewan. I note that at the time your letter was written the Department had spent $14,294.30 on this building, and agree that this is a very substantial amount. It had been my impression, however, that the Government has adopted the policy of not insuring its buildings and I took it that some other provision would be made to cover the cost of replacement and that the purchase of new equipment would be provided by this means.

As I hope to be in Ottawa on Thursday, May 11th, I shall
look forward to the opportunity of discussing this matter more fully.

Meanwhile, with kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.M. Alderwood

Secretary.

Attention Mr. R.A. Heey,
Acting Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Heey:

I visited this school over the weekend and went fully into a number of points of difficulty. I mentioned to you when in Ottawa that we were deeply concerned that our Principal had admitted 150 pupils in spite of our reiterated instruction that he should keep as closely as possible to 100. We knew that the capacity of this building was limited and did not wish to overcrowd it.

My impression of the school was distinctly good and I am happy that many things have been well done and I am hopeful for the future. It was evident, however, that there are too many children there at the present time, and I discussed fully with Principal Ellis how we might reduce the number. He insisted that he had not recruited this large number and that he could have obtained many more. He claimed that the various Agents concerned had sent the pupils in and that he had been unable to refuse them admission. Dr. Morrow, who has been most interested and helpful in the establishment of this school in Prince Albert, kindly came over for a conference with us. He agreed that the school was overcrowded but felt helpless in view of the demand on the part of Indian parents.

We agreed to attempt the following methods of reducing the number. Principal Fisher of Lac la Ronge has a margin of accommodation at the present time and I have asked him to visit Montreal Lake and endeavour to secure the consent of some of the parents there to the transfer of their children from Prince Albert to his school. This should be easier now in view of the fact that the troops in Prince Albert are travelling continually to Lac la Ronge and the trail should be in splendid condition from now on. The journey in a covered truck can be made in reasonable comfort in six hours. The difficulty seems to be with the Indians, who have preferred to go south to Prince Albert, as there has been a good road while up to the present it has not been possible to travel easily to Lac la Ronge.

Another suggestion is in line with the request of the Bishop of Saskatchewan for a Day School to be established at Onion Lake. I have no doubt you are giving consideration to this
and I desire to support the request, as I believe it will tend to relieve the difficulty created by our removal from Onion Lake since the fire. If a dozen or more of the Onion Lake children could be taken home from Prince Albert to attend a Day School it would serve to relieve the congestion. We have carried out certain changes in the school building which will make it possible to handle 125 children safely, and the two proposals outlined above should reduce the pupilage to this figure.

In laying this situation before our Commission on Tuesday, I was instructed to make an earnest request to the Government for an increase in the authorized pupilage at Prince Albert to 125. We believe this to be reasonable in view of the large number of Anglicans in the vicinity of Prince Albert and the strong desire of Indian parents to send their children to the school. May I couple with this request the suggestion that our authorized pupilage at Elkhorn be reduced by 25? We have for a number of years been authorized to receive 155 pupils and you will recall that the report of Dr. Simes criticized our overcrowding of the building although we had just about 130 pupils. We have instructed our Principal not to take any more pupils and believe that 130 would be a fair figure to allow for the Elkhorn building.

Commending these matters to your usual kind attention,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood

Secretary.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter 115-1-1 dated the 20th inst., concerning the question of the enrollment at St. Alban's Residential School. We have 147 children in residence.

I herewith attach the cubic feet area of each dormitory.

You will note there is an area of about 61,441 cubic feet of air space. Allowing about 500 cubic feet per child, gives us a capacity for 122 pupils. As many of the children are very small, the additional pupils do not suffer any inconvenience.

Ottawa, January 2, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

The Elkhorn Indian Residential School, at Elkhorn, Manitoba, and the St. Alban's Indian Residential School, at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, are both operated under the auspices of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada. At the Elkhorn School provision has been made for some years for a pupilage of 135, and at the St. Alban's School, which replaces the Onion Lake Church of England Residential School, destroyed by fire December 1, 1945, grant for a pupilage of 130 is provided.

Owing to conditions existing at Elkhorn, as outlined in the report of Dr. Simes, it was mutually agreed between the officers of the Indian Affairs Branch and the officers of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada that not more than 130 pupils should be enrolled in future at the Elkhorn School.

On the other hand, the St. Alban's Residential School has at the present time an enrolment of 147 pupils. Both the Principal of the St. Alban's School and Dr. Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., advise that this large enrolment is due to the fact that the Indian agents in Saskatchewan have found it necessary to send several children to the St. Alban's School this fall and, as a consequence, their enrolment is considerably above their authorized pupilage. The cubic feet air space in the dormitories at the St. Alban's School is sufficient for 125 pupils. A request has been submitted to us to transfer the grant of 25 pupils, which is not being used at the Elkhorn School, to the St. Alban's School. This would mean that in future the authorized pupilage at Elkhorn would be 130 and at the St. Alban's School, 125. This change would
not result in any increased expenditure, as the per capita rate at both schools is the same, namely $170.00. In view of the conditions existing at both schools, I recommend that the pupilage at St. Alban's be increased to the extent by which we can reduce the authorized pupilage at Elkhorn.

Arrangements are now being made by the Principal of St. Alban's School to return to their homes 22 children, so that the enrolment may be reduced to 125, for whom, as stated above, there is accommodation in the dormitories.

Acting Director.
January 2, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

The Elkhorn Indian Residential School, at Elkhorn, Manitoba, and the St. Alban's Indian Residential School, at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, are both operated under the auspices of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada. At the Elkhorn School provision has been made for some years for a pupilage of 155, and at the St. Alban's School, which replaces the Onion Lake Church of England Residential School, destroyed by fire December 1, 1943, grant for a pupilage of 100 is provided.

Owing to conditions existing at Elkhorn, as outlined in the report of Dr. Simes, it was mutually agreed between the officers of the Indian Affairs Branch and the officers of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada that not more than 130 pupils should be enrolled in future at the Elkhorn School.

On the other hand, the St. Alban's Residential School has at the present time an enrolment of 147 pupils. Both the Principal of the St. Alban's School and Dr. Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., advise that this large enrolment is due to the fact that the Indian agents in Saskatchewan have found it necessary to send several children to the St. Alban's School this fall and, as a consequence, their enrolment is considerably above their authorized pupilage. The cubic feet air space in the dormitories at the St. Alban's School is sufficient for 125 pupils. A request has been submitted to us to transfer the grant of 25 pupils, which is not being used at the Elkhorn School, to the St. Alban's School. This would mean that in future the authorized pupilage at Elkhorn would be 130 and at the St. Alban's School, 125. This change would
not result in any increased expenditure, as the per capita rate at both schools is the same, namely $170.00. In view of the conditions existing at both schools, I recommend that the pupilage at St. Alban's be increased to the extent by which we can reduce the authorized pupilage at Elkhorn.

Arrangements are now being made by the Principal of St. Alban's School to return to their homes 28 children, so that the enrolment may be reduced to 125, for whom, as stated above, there is accommodation in the dormitories.

Acting Director

PP
Ottawa, January 8, 1945.

May I refer to Departmental Letter No. 115-1-1, dated March 1, 1945, with reference to payment of $20.00 per month for transportation of pupils to the Onion Lake Indian Day School (C.E.). Frank Heathen, who originally undertook to perform this service never did do it. Ever since the School opened October 2, 1945, another Indian, James Cook, has been doing the work.

It has been pointed out to me a good many times that $20.00 is not sufficient pay for this job, especially in the winter months. In addition to this, James Cook has to travel a greater distance than Frank Heathen had agreed to do, as he lives farther away on the route and has to make one extra call to pick up a pupil. At a Band meeting held February 8th, the matter was brought up and it was stated that James was having a hard time to carry on due to the heavy snow and bad roads, and had had to hire an extra team at times. I agreed to take the matter up with the Department and request that $30.00 be paid for each of the remaining winter months (February, March and April). I consider that therequest is reasonable and necessary, and would therefore recommend that it be approved.

Donald F. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 21, 1946.

Mr. Donald H. Cameron, Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Mr. Campbell:

I am in receipt of your letter of March 18, with reference to the Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, Saskatchewan, which was destroyed by fire on December 1, 1943.

Immediately following the fire, the Department accepted the offer of the Bishop of Saskatchewan to lease the building formerly used for St. Alban's College at Prince Albert, and the children who had been attending the Onion Lake Residential School were transferred there. It was understood that this arrangement was only of a temporary nature, and it is my intention to review the situation at Onion Lake with the authorities of the Church of England. However, it will not be possible to consider the re-erection of this building during the fiscal year 1946-47.

In order to provide additional educational facilities for Indian children on the Onion Lake Reserve, a day school was opened on October 2, 1946.

Yours sincerely,

Max Campbell, Esq., M.P.,

Ottawa, April 11, 1946.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Saskatchewan.

I am not certain if you have visited the St. Alban's School at Prince Albert recently. If not, I would appreciate it if you would inspect this school as soon as you can conveniently do so.

Our agreement with the Right Reverend Henry D. Martin, D.D., provides that we allow an amount of $2,000.00 a year in lieu of rent, but it was understood that the Bishop would keep the building in good repair so that the children would not be unduly inconvenienced.

I have also been a little concerned about the number of children that are being accepted at this school. Possibly there is plenty of accommodation for them, but, on the other hand, they may be over-crowding the school. Perhaps you could look into this feature of the matter as well, when you visit the school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant, No. 115-1-1, I visited the St. Alban's School at Prince Albert on the 21st instant and examined the building accompanied by Mr. E.S. Jones, Indian Agent, Carlton Agency.

The building is in a reasonably good state of repair with the exception that the interior is badly in need of redecorating and the floors are in poor shape.

In connection with the third paragraph of your letter referred to this school is very definitely overcrowded. Nineteen senior girls sleep in single beds in approximately 8,000 cubic ft. of air space; 53 intermediate girls sleep in approximately 12,000 cubic ft. of air space in 39 cots. Fifteen of these cots have two girls sleeping in each one. Thirty-nine junior boys sleep in approximately 7500 cubic ft. of air space in twenty-three cots, and sixteen of these cots have two boys sleeping in them. Twenty-two senior boys are sleeping in approximately 2500 cubic ft. of air space with one boy in each cot. Some of the classrooms are very decidedly overcrowded and there is insufficient seats for the pupils and no room for the necessary desks if they had them. There are therefore one hundred and thirty-three children sleeping in the building with thirty-one cots having two children sleeping in each one.

The ceilings in the dormitories are very low, that of the intermediate girls being 8'6", the senior boys 8'10", the senior girls 10'3", and the junior boys 10'3".

There seems to be no thought about the health of the children when such a large number are permitted to sleep in crowded quarters. Instructions should be sent out to reduce the number of children in residence to not over one hundred for the beginning of the next term.

It is my duty to point out also that there is an extreme shortage of playground space for the children. Reverend Mr. Ellis, the Principal, informed me that he has the use of the Collegiate Grounds when not in use but this is not satisfactory as the grounds are a distance away from the school and have been in continuous use for some time. The boys informed me that they had been permitted to play on these grounds only three times in the last month. There is much truancy amongst the boys and I believe that having insufficient space for recreation purposes and possibly not very good supervision by the Boys' Supervisor is the chief reason for truancy. While I was at the James Smith's Reserve the following week after my visit to St. Alban's School two truant boys arrived there, having run away from the school and walked across the railway bridge near Fenton. This bridge is anything but safe for pedestrians and they might easily get caught by a train as the bridge is very long and there is no safe place on it for a pedestrian if a train is passing.

The floors of the whole building are of soft wood and are badly in need of paint in many places. They will never be satisfactory unless covered with a suitable surfacing material, such as "mulsumastic", manufactured by the Tremco Company, or some similar material which can be washed and kept clean. The cost of laying this over the whole building would probably be in the neighbourhood of $2,000.00.

When discussing the condition of the interior walls of the building with Mr. Ellis he showed me an estimate of the paint, varnish, and brushes required to do the work at a cost of $462.70 for material only. He said the work could be done by the school staff.......

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
done by the school staff. He informed me that a request had been made to Bishop Martin for authority for this expenditure but that he had received the authority on the date of our discussion, i.e., last April. On the same date I visited Bishop Martin and drew this to his attention. He informed me that on the previous Sunday, which would be the 14th of April, he had given Mr. Ellis authority to spend $125.00 on material and Bishop Martin informed me this was all that Mr. Ellis had asked for. The Bishop was somewhat annoyed with Mr. Ellis' action in this connection and telephoned to him in my presence, reprimanding him both for saying he had no authority and for asking for only $125.00 while leading me to believe that he had asked for $482.70. The Bishop also instructed Mr. Ellis over the telephone to write to me confirming the fact that he had authority from the Diocese to spend $125.00 on materials for interior decorating. (Over a week has passed and I have not yet received this.)

I am not at all satisfied with the manner in which the St. Alban's Residential School is being managed. Reverend Mr. Ellis informs me that he understood he had to report only to our Department. Later he found that he had to take his orders from the Indian and Eskimo Commission. Now he advises that because the building is owned by the Prince Albert Diocese of the Church of England he has to depend upon the Bishop and the Diocese for maintenance of the building. The building itself is not suitable and it is certainly not satisfactory from the point of view of our Branch that we do not know who is to blame if things are not in order.

In conversation with Bishop Martin I criticised the building as a fire hazard. I am sure that if a fire started in the building there would be a great probability of considerable loss of life because of narrow corridors of dry, inflammable material and not easy access to fire escapes or the stairway. Mr. Ellis informs me that the Fire Chief of the City of Prince Albert inspects the building once every month. I think it should be inspected twice monthly to save loss of life if a fire started. I would recommend that a night watchman be on duty the whole of the school term and not just during the winter months. I would also recommend that he be supplied with a time clock with a patrol register for twelve points in the building. It is not necessary for me to point out to the Department that fires can start in Indian residential schools whether there is a fire in the heating plant or not. More than one disastrous Indian school fire has been started by the pupils themselves in an effort to obtain their freedom from a school which they did not like. The number of truants in this school would certainly indicate much dissatisfaction and there are hundreds of places in the building where irresponsible Indian boys might start a fire very easily.

I realize that the Anglican Church was permitted to re-open the St. Alban's School in their building at Prince Albert after the Onion Lake fire and that the need was urgent and more or less a temporary war measure. However, I do not think that this school should be permitted to continue very much longer in a very unsuitable building amongst unsuitable surroundings. Certainly the enrolment should be considerably reduced and I would say that the dissatisfied boys, who are, in my opinion, a menace to the lives of the other children, should be the ones discharged and as soon as possible.

It would be unfair to criticise this school to the extent to which I have criticised it without stating; that in Mr. Ellis' favour he is, in my opinion, a good manager trying to make the best of a bad situation. The children are well fed and well clothed and I believe receiving some education although the classroom conditions are poor. There is very little chance to give them anything other than the regular classroom work because of the shortage of facilities for the other necessary training.

J.R.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)
Ottawa, May 11, 1946.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I enclose, for your information, copy of a report received from Inspector Ostrander with reference to the St. Alban's School.

It appears from his report that the school is over-crowded, and we are concerned about the danger of fire. I feel we should accept Mr. Ostrander's recommendation, that the pupilage be reduced to 100, effective from September 1, 1946.

In view of the fire hazard, we are prepared to allow $40.00 a month towards the salary of a night watchman, on the understanding that he will be engaged for a full year. We are instructing Mr. Ostrander to secure and forward to Mr. Ellis a watchman's clock.

Please notify Mr. Ellis that in reducing the number of children enrolled he should send home the dissatisfied boys. I realize that this action may make discipline difficult in some instances, but we must take every possible precaution to avoid any trouble along the lines mentioned in the second last paragraph of Mr. Ostrander's report.

I feel that you will give the whole situation your immediate sympathetic consideration and that you will cooperate with us in every possible way to improve conditions.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend H.A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
