Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Saskatchewan.

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, reporting on your inspection of the St. Alban's School at Prince Albert on April 21. The contents of your letter have been discussed with the Director and we are communicating with Dr. Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., and Bishop Martin.

I do not understand why Mr. Ellis thought that he would not come under the direction of the M.S.C.C. The school at Onion Lake, which was destroyed by fire and of which Mr. Ellis was Principal, came under the jurisdiction of that Commission and the St. Alban's School was opened to replace the one destroyed by fire. The only additional complication in the matter is the fact that in allowing rent for the building the Department provided that the Bishop would be responsible for keeping the building in reasonably good condition.

We are advising Dr. Alderwood that a night watchman should be employed the year round. Please secure a proper watchman's clock and forward it to the Principal.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, May 11, 1946.

Dear Bishop Martin:

I have just received a very lengthy report from Inspector Ostrander with reference to his recent visit to the St. Albans School. Mr. Ostrander points out that the building is in a reasonably good state of repair except that the interior is badly in need of redecorating and the floors are in poor shape.

It is evident from the report that the building is over-crowded. We are communicating with Dr. Alderwood regarding the matter and instructing him to reduce the enrolment to 100, effective from September 1, 1946.

I understand that Mr. Ostrander recently interviewed you and pointed out the fire hazards that exist. I am advising Dr. Alderwood that we are prepared to allow $40.00 a month towards the salary of the night watchman, provided a watchman is employed the year round.

I feel certain that you will co-operate with us in improving conditions in this building, so that the children may be reasonably comfortable and that the extreme danger of fire will be removed.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Right Reverend Henry D. Martin, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.
May 17th, 1946.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge your 115-1-1 of May 11th in regard to St. Alban's School, Prince Albert.

I have carefully read the report of Inspector Ostrander which follows very much the lines I have followed in my own reports. Our Commission has never felt that St. Alban's was suitable for Residential School purposes except as an emergency measure awaiting the rebuilding of the Onion Lake School. When visiting the school at the beginning of February I was really distressed at the difficulties under which the work was being carried on, but it was hard to see what could be done. We have urged our Principal to rent or lease a piece of ground for garden purposes believing that this would be a wholesome outlet for the boys. We have also urged that anything possible should be done to secure one of the Army huts if they were made available so that something in the nature of a recreation building or manual training shop might be provided. Apparently the buildings at the two training camps in Prince Albert are not as yet being disposed of.

In the matter of overcrowding we have been deeply concerned. About a year ago we had serious trouble with our Principal, who apparently disregarded our explicit instructions that not more than 100 children were to be admitted. The matter went so far that Mr. Ellis tendered his resignation but this was later withdrawn when we realized that he was not wholly responsible for the admission of additional children. The authorized pupilage was increased to 125 when changes were made which utilized part of the auditorium for classroom purposes. A new girls' playroom was then created and additional dormitory accommodation provided which made us feel that we could care for 125. There were 130 children in the building at that time and we then instructed our Principal that for the future the limit must be 125. I think it well to emphasize the difficult position of our Principal in this matter when there are no other institutions provided for homeless Indian children. Mr. Ellis has been at the mercy of the Agents and Doctor of the Department who send orphans or other needy children to the school, sometimes without any consultation or agreement. Mr. Ellis has several times advised us of the arrival of children by train or by road who were landed at the school and he had nothing to do but accept them. While I was
present in the building he was forced to take in two more girls whose mother had just been admitted to the sanitarium for an indefinite period. He protested against this but the Doctor insisted that there was no other place to which they could be sent. When we are condemned for overcrowding I think it well that these facts should be borne in mind. When this school was carrying almost 150 children we were only being paid for 100.

I am glad that this inspection has taken place and am grateful for the provision of a Night Watchman's salary as the fire hazard is certainly great under these conditions. We are immediately notifying Mr. Ellis that the number of children should be reduced to the present authorized enrolment and that he should use his discretion as to the boys to be discharged. From September 1 we shall accept your ruling that the limit must be 100.

In regard to the state of the building there has been difficulty by reason of the unwillingness of the Diocese of Saskatchewan to assume full liability for repairs. It has been arranged that Bishop Martin shall meet with our Commission to arrive at an agreement in regard to this question and we trust that this will be accomplished on June 4th.

Our experience in Prince Albert has made it very plain that there are a very large number of children in northern Saskatchewan who require the privileges of a residential school. I trust that the Department will give serious consideration to the rebuilding of St. Barnabas, Onion Lake and that a larger pupilage will be authorized there to meet the need. The site is an admirable one, the out-buildings are already constructed, the farm is fenced and a good deal of land has been brought under cultivation so that only the main school building is required to re-establish a good school in healthy and convenient surroundings. Our Commission will be greatly relieved when the emergency conditions at Prince Albert can be replaced by something better.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Anderson

Secretary.
Ottawa, May 28, 1946.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of April 30 and my reply of May 10, regarding your inspection of the St. Alban's School, I am now in receipt of a letter from Dr. H.A. Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., in which he states that the Principal of the St. Alban's School has been instructed that no more children should be accepted and that he can use his own discretion regarding the boys to be discharged. From September 1, it is intended to limit the pupilage to 100.

Philip Phelan,

CONFIDENTIAL

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of your letter of May 11th with reference to the report by Inspector Ostrander on his visit to St. Alban's School, Prince Albert. I am glad to learn that Mr. Ostrander finds the building in good repair. The interior walls are, I understand, being painted. Naturally, the floors are being subjected to considerable wear and tear owing to the large number of boys and girls who are continually traversing these floors. Their boots and shoes tend to wear down any material.

I am inclined to agree with the suggestion of overcrowding but of course this matter is not within my jurisdiction. On the other hand I cannot fully agree with Mr. Ostrander regarding the lack of fire escapes. After receiving your letter I again went to the school and I find that apart from the stairs, there are three excellent means of exit. This building was erected as a boarding school for girls, and all its history has been used for that purpose, or as a school for boys. Consequently, the lives of the children were safeguarded as far as it is possible. I can assure you that I will do all in my power to co-operate with you so that the children in residence will be thoroughly well cared for and that as far as is humanly possible every danger of fire will be removed.

Again, I assure you of my interest in this important matter, and also of my co-operation.

I am, faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Bp/e
Regina, May 28th, 1946.

Agent's report concerning Indians and work of Agency during the months of April, May June 1946.

Welfare & Training.

School and Teacherage wood has been supplied in good condition. School has been closed for the Summer vacation, and although the teacher had a heavy class good progress is noticeable, five children tried their entrance examinations, one girl was promoted through her years work.

Stuart Sympoe,

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I submit the following report on the affairs of this Agency, for the quarter ending June 30th, 1946.

Education:— I visited the Onion Lake Residential School regularly during the quarter. This is a good school and well conducted. There are four Indian Day Schools in this Agency—Onion Lake C.E., Frog Lake C.E., Long Lake R.C., and Big Lake Island R.C. I visited the Onion Lake and Frog Lake Schools every month. Long Lake School was visited in May and in June. Big Island Lake is more remote. However, I visited this school April 9th, May 9th and May 17th. The opening of the "Ministikwan Indian Day School" is under consideration by the Department, and, provided a good teacher is secured, this should be an improvement over present conditions on that Reserve.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
Regina, July 22nd, 1946.

QUARTERLY REPORT FOR THE SASKATCHEWAN INSPECTORATE

FOR THE PERIOD ENDING JUNE 30th, 1946.

GENERAL ADMINISTRATION

With regard to the residential schools special reports have been made in connection with the St. Alban's School at Prince Albert and the Gordon's School at Punnichy. As the result of my recommendation instructions have gone to the Principal of the St. Alban's School to accept more than 100 pupils in residence for the next term. The principal for the Gordon's School has not yet completed his staff for the next term. He promises to replace the Indian Farming Instructor with a capable man and to obtain the services of a suitable Sewing Matron and Kitchen Matron. All three of these positions were filled with unsuitable appointees during the past term and the work was not at all satisfactory. The appointment of Engineer was changed several times and Mr. Ireland was holding the appointment at the end of the June term. His services might be satisfactory if the machinery and equipment of the school was in good condition but I do not think that he is a good repair man and he was unable to cope with the regular difficulties with the machinery. Both of the Lister engines have been shipped to Winnipeg to be repaired and a requisition is going forward for new batteries for the lighting plant. The difficulty with respect to water supply has still not been met but the new well is being cleaned out in the hope that it will furnish an adequate supply. A further report on this will be forwarded shortly. The other residential schools have been operating in a fairly satisfactory manner during the past quarter.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Saskatchewan.

October 1, 1947.

Attention: Col. R.F. Neary
Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Colonel Neary,

Acknowledging your letter of the 27th, reference 115-1-1 (WT 1), I regret that the number of pupils admitted in the above school has exceeded the figure authorized. In this connection, I may say that we have just received a letter from our principal, the Rev. G. W. Fisher, pointing out that the number of pupils is too high and expressing the hope that the new quarters for the Lac la Ronge school may soon be opened in order that the surplus number may be transferred.

Mr. Fisher tells us of the continual pressure under which he is labouring and confirms what our former principal said as to the difficulty of keeping down the number in this particular school. He claims that in visiting Lac la Ronge recently he found everywhere a desire to send children in and had thirteen requests from Stanley alone. He has been receiving a great many requests from the reserves which formerly sent children to the Onion Lake school and has been asking many parents to keep their children at home until new school is opened.

This Prince Albert Situation has been a difficult one ever since St. Alban's was opened and Mr. Ellis used to claim that various Agents and the doctor of the Indian Health Services would insist upon pupils being admitted when the school was already over-crowded. The situation can apparently only be relieved by opening the new school and I trust that we may soon have the satisfaction of doing this.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood
Superintendent.

Dictated but not personally signed because of absence from the office

My Dear Mr. Hoey:

I believe the time has arrived for me to write to you and remind you of the half-yearly amount due from the Department 'in lieu of rent' for St. Alban's College building, Prince Albert. You will be pleased to know that as far as I am able to ascertain everything is flourishing at this school. I was there two Sundays ago, and the children seemed very happy and contented, and well fed and clothed.

While writing I wonder if this is the time to ask if the Department has any plans regarding buildings at Pelican Narrows. Our school teacher last summer worked under many and great difficulties, both with regards to the school building and also the teacher's residence. I am quite sure that your representative, Mr. Bowman of The Park, will be able to tell you just what conditions are at this point. I know personally that many visitors, who were there this summer have been very outspoken about the lack of accommodation. I do not wish to bother you about conditions in Northern Saskatchewan, but in view of the report sent to me by our teacher, I thought I should inquire from you as to whether any building programme was contemplated.

I was sorry not to be able to be present when the deputation from our Church met with the Minister and yourself and others some two weeks ago, but it was impossible for me to get away at that time. With kindest personal regards,

I am,

Faithfully yours,

CANADA
I realize that there will be some delay in establishing the new school at Prince Albert, and in the meantime the dormitories at the old school will be over-crowded to the detriment of the children sleeping in them and increasing the fire hazard. Please advise me whether or not I should insist that sufficient of the children be returned to their homes to reduce the number in residence to 100 pending the opening of the new school. These extra children should not have been admitted to the school, but they are there now and there will be some difficulty in contacting their parents with a view to returning them to their homes.

With regard to that part of Mr. Fisher's letter where he refers in the third paragraph to the purchase of cooking utensils, etc., I have to say that I located a quantity of these utensils which could be purchased from a surplus in the hands of the Provincial Government, Department of Rehabilitation, taken over by them from War Assets Corporation. A list of these utensils was prepared and is held in this office as I am awaiting unit prices from the official in charge here in Regina. Mr. Fisher misunderstood me when he says that he understood that arrangements were made for their purchase. I propose submitting the list to the Department and recommending their purchase as soon as prices have been received. I expected to receive these prices today but they have not yet arrived. The list is not the complete requirements for opening a school of 120 pupils. Some of the articles were in sufficient quantity for our requirements, others were not. As soon as authority has been received to take over the utensils in question I intend to check over the list with Mr. Fisher, ascertain what further quantities are required and submit the necessary requisition to the Department.

I have not yet been officially informed that the proposed school will be operated in the near future. I note that Mr. Fisher's letter indicated that a definite arrangement has been made.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan

Copied:
CS
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,

There are at present about 30 children in residence at the St. Alban's School in excess of the authorized 100. The Reverend Principal informs me that he is going to have considerable difficulty financing until the opening of the new school unless these extra children are accepted as grant earning pupils. Of course I realize that they should not have been accepted into the school, and I was particularly concerned over the question of over-crowding and the additional fire hazard resulting therefrom.

Building No. 30 at Ex-122 Basic Training Centre, which will shortly be prepared for the opening of the new Prince Albert School, can be prepared for temporary use by connecting the water and sewage. Mr. Fisher is going to immediately purchase additional coal, and the Department of Public Works will make immediate arrangements to re-connect the water and sewage, after which 30 boys at St. Alban's school, will be moved to Building No. 30, the new school, and Mr. Fisher will arrange for a staff member to sleep in the building for supervision purposes.

I am assuming that we are taking the beds and bedding from the Department of Reconstruction, and sufficient beds will be moved into Building No. 30 for this purpose.

I would recommend that Mr. Fisher be allowed grant for 30 additional pupils at St. Alban's School for the present, and that if it is considered necessary to take an additional 10, grant will be authorized for them also, until such time as the new school is prepared and properly opened.

Until the opening of the new school, the pupils will sleep at Building No. 30 but will attend classes at St. Alban's School, and also receive their meals there.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies, Saskatchewan.

January 27th, 1948.

Dear Sirs:

I have received your telegram of January 21st., and also the copy of your letter of January 22nd. to Mr. J. P. B. Ostrander with reference to supernumerary grants made for children in excess of one hundred now attending this school.

These additional grants are very much appreciated, and will go a long way towards easing the difficulty I have been finding in financing the school, due to the increased costs of nearly everything we have to purchase.

On every side I am being pressed to take in additional children, and if, with the Department's approval, I am allowed to use, for the time being, as an annex to this school, one of the buildings offered us in which to open a temporary Lac La Ronge School, it might be possible by housing all the boys in the annex, to accommodate up to 100 girls in St. Alban's. This would be looked on as a temporary measure only, and immediately the new school is opened, normal conditions would be restored to St. Alban's, with a pupilage of about 60 girls, and 40 boys.

I shall be glad to know if the Department will approve this plan.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.
PERSONAL:

January 30, 1948.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

I have had an opportunity of discussing the fire at the Thunderchild Residential School with the Director. At first I recommended that Mr. Phelan visit Saskatchewan with a view to discussing the following educational problems with you:

(1) To select a site for the proposed new Lac la Ronge Residential School.
(2) To inspect the work done at the Gordon's Residential School.
(3) To inspect the work done at the Prince Albert Army Camp.
(4) To discuss with you the steps which can be taken with regard to the children left without schooling as a result of the fire at Thunderchild.

However, the Director does not wish Mr. Phelan nor myself to leave Ottawa for any length of time, because of the fact that the Educational Sub-Committee will soon start their work and he is anxious that we both be present for all its deliberations.

Therefore, there is a possibility that he may ask you to come again to Ottawa to discuss the above problems and also your day school building program. Therefore, it is very likely that you will hear from him in this regard. In fact, I would suggest that you write him and advise the best time for your proposed visit. In the meantime, he has suggested that if at all possible some decision be reached with the Bishop of Saskatchewan as to the best location for the new Lac la Ronge Residential School.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. J.P.S. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
REGINA, SASK

Regina, June 21st, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 21st ultimo,
File No. 106-0-1/132-2-1/115-1-1 (E), regarding accommodation for pupils at
the proposed Prince Albert Indian Residential School, and my letter of the
5th instant, File No. 1021-303-11 ACE, on the subject, I have to say that we
had a meeting at Prince Albert on the 19th instant to discuss the whole question.
General Turner, Major G.A.F. Clarke, Mr. E.S. Jones, Superintendent, Carlton
Agency, Reverend C.W. Fisher, and the writer were present.

Since writing my letter of the 5th instant on the subject
Major Clarke has received information that the Elkhorn School has to be closed
entirely, resulting in approximately 130 pupils having no school. In addition
there are 161 pupils in residence at the present combined St. Alban's Indian
Residential School and Prince Albert Residential School. In the Pelican Narrows
area there are approximately 200 pupils; Lac la Ronge area 125 pupils;
Stanley area 161 pupils; Chitek Lake Area (the subject of another letter) 30
pupils; Red Earth and Shoal Lake areas (also the subject of another letter)
55 pupils.

In view of these figures it will be seen that if we extend our
pupilage for the Prince Albert Residential School to 600 pupils we will still
not have sufficient room to accommodate all of the children who should be accommodated.
In view of this fact our conclusions were that immediate steps should be taken to
allocate to the Prince Albert Residential School sufficient funds to prepare all
of the buildings mentioned in my letter of the 5th instant on the subject, for 400
pupils by the last of January, 1949, and for a further 200 pupils by the last of
September, 1949.

Major Clarke is reporting to the Department in this connection
and General Turner, who will be in Ottawa shortly, intends to discuss it with
Canon Cooke and Department officials. In the meantime I would recommend that the
funds which were allotted for replacing the Lac la Ronge School be used toward
repairing the buildings at Ex-122 Army Camp for a large residential school.

If we decide upon a 600 pupil...
If we decide upon a 600-pupil school at Prince Albert the Church Authorities should be pressed to place a business manager in charge as it will be a large institution and require the very best of business management to be successful. The matter of assisting the Prince Albert Residential School in a part of the cost of transporting pupils should also be considered.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Carl W. Begg

Dear Mr. Fisher:

It may assist you to have advance information of what Dominion and Provincial Officials concerned with the inspection of schools will expect to find when the two establishments under your principalship have achieved a settled routine.

It is expected that, as the schools are within easy walking distance of each other, activities will be unified rather than duplicated. We shall not object to your proposal to operate St. Alban's for the time being as a school exclusively for girls if the resulting duplications are kept to the minimum.

In assigning girls to the two schools, you are, we expect accommodating at St. Alban's all girls who will attend high school. The rest of the girls for St. Alban's should be selected so as to reduce the number of grades taught by each teacher in the two schools. It would invite adverse criticism to have one teacher at St. Alban's assigned to a classroom of girls in grades 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 while at the barracks another teacher has a roomful of boys in those grades. We think that the academic work will be better handled if boys and girls are taught together in the upper grades. This will probably require the girls of those grades to live at the barracks.

We appreciate the effect which this composition of classes may have on the organization of household duties, Girl Guides etc., but we feel sure that you can re-arrange these activities satisfactorily, particularly as among the three hundred pupils resident at Prince Albert there are likely to be many bigger girls who, although they have done little book work, are intelligent and capable of being trained quickly to be useful around the school.
It is recommended, therefore, that the classes at St. Alban's be as nearly as possible homogeneous groups of girls initially of low academic rating but grouped with consideration for the factors of physical and social development, intelligence and reading readiness. Thus grouped they should be able to advance more rapidly than the children in institutions where these factors may not be given the consideration they deserve. In this appraisal we hope to provide assistance early in the academic year, (by "assistance" I mean the provision of test materials and help in their administration and interpretation). It may be supposed that the handling of this new and large concentration of Indian pupils will be watched with intense interest by educationists and others who will, no doubt, expect that the best educational procedures will be adopted.

The provision of vocational training for pupils at Prince Albert is another aspect that is receiving attention. We hope to provide a cow-barn, pasture and garden land. We look forward to seeing the subject of animal husbandry handled in the classroom and on the farm in such a way that boys will take part in the calf clubs associated with the Prince Albert Cattle Fair and in other ways develop an enthusiasm for adult activity in animal husbandry.

Similar integrated activity should be possible in poultry husbandry and vegetable-raising. Garden plots for boys and girls could be projects of the classwork in nutrition, agriculture and home-making for all pupils.

For the girls we should like to see one of the schools provide a specially-equipped room where the teaching of sewing and allied subjects can be concentrated under the most competent person available. This should not be allowed to become a repair shop where mending and darning dominate the proceedings, although the need for these activities is recognized.

The walking involved in the passage of the girls from one school to the other should provide an opportunity to improve the lackadaisical posture and gait of pupils in whom these defects are not chargeable to dietary deficiency. Supervised walks are, of course, only one aspect of a physical education programme which we expect will include regularly...
appointed classes and organized games calculated to exploit each child's allotment of recreational time. The homogeneous grouping which should improve the standard of work in other subjects should serve to make easier the conduct of games engaging all pupils.

Since space is likely to be ample in the barracks, the provision of library facilities, distinct from a combined games and recreational reading room, should receive early attention.

Finally, to assist in coping with the problem of pupil-supervision which you anticipate will be more difficult in a school where the pupils are not confined to one building, we recommend the immediate introduction of classroom lessons and discussions to prepare the pupils for the early election of group leaders who will share in the government of the student body. During the early weeks the presence of the upper grade boys and girls in the barracks should permit the appointment of monitors pro tem who may not, however, prove permanently acceptable to yourself or to their fellow-students. We would draw your attention to the series of articles on extra-curricular activities which appeared in last year's Indian School Bulletin.

We feel that you welcome this opportunity to demonstrate what can be done in the light of all the criticism and advice which the Department has received concerning the conduct of its schools. We look forward to the success of an experiment where it is possible to select and develop traditions and practices that may serve to guide our procedure elsewhere.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. W.J. Fisher,
St. Alban's Indian Residential School,
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

CAFG/HM.

Re: St. Alban's College, Battleford, Sask.

Dear Bishop Martin:

You will recall our recent discussion with regard to the renewal of the lease on the above building. In reviewing our files, I find that Mr. Hoey wrote you as follows on December 23, 1943:

"I have noticed Your Lordship's reference to taxes, and the city levy appears to me to be very reasonable. Would it be acceptable to the Diocese if we spent a minimum of $2,000.00 on the school, in lieu of rent, for the year 1944, and allowed you the sum of $2,000.00 annually for the next 4 years, on the understanding that any repairs that might be necessary would be undertaken either by the Diocese or by the Principal and that the taxes also would be paid by the Diocese? If this allowance is acceptable to you, it might be advisable to submit a voucher for one half the amount semi-annually."

I understand that this lease was to run for the period of five calendar years and that it will expire on December 31, 1948.

In view of increased costs of repairs and general rental rises, I would like to suggest that the amount of
$2,500.00 a year be considered as the amount of the new lease on this building for the next five years. I would also like to suggest, in view of the possibility of the Department purchasing this building, that the lease be subject to cancellation by either party after one year's notice.

May I, in closing, express my appreciation for the courtesy of your recent visit and hope that we may again have an opportunity of discussing mutual problems with regard to Indian welfare and education in the near future.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sirs:

The question of letting pupils of this school and St. Alban's go home for the Christmas holiday has arisen, and I would like the Department's ruling on this matter.

For several years past we have received a circular governing holidays, but to date this has not been received this year.

Personally, I would rather the children did not go home for holidays, as in many cases, on their return it is necessary to issue a complete new outfit of clothing, and at current prices, this adds a considerable amount to the cost of operating the school.

But I am willing to abide by the ruling of the Department. I might say quite a number of parents have been asking for their children for the Christmas holiday.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Colonel Nassy:

Amongst those making application for the appointment of day school teacher at the Nut Lake Reserve was Mr. Harry Kapusianyk, who came to my office for a personal interview.

Mr. Kapusianyk had many talents which I thought would be wasted at the Nut Lake School, and which were badly needed at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School at Prince Albert, consequently I referred him to the Church of England Authorities for consideration.

You perhaps have heard that he was offered $45.00 a month maintenance, which was protested, with the result that he commenced his duties as Boys' Supervisor at $1,000.00 per annum and maintenance.

I asked Superintendent E.S. Jones to guide him in his duties as I knew that Reverend Mr. Fisher would know little about what the duties of a man of this type should be. He has done excellent work so far as he is able, but I have just received a letter from him, and I am enclosing a copy of it for your confidential information.

As there seemed little possibility to promote much in the way of skating for the boys during the winter, with the exception of skating and hockey, I suggested to Mr. Kapusianyk that he endeavour to persuade Mr. Fisher to provide skates for the children. Apparently he has not been very successful. Mr. Jones also caused a message to be broadcast from the radio station in Prince Albert inviting contributions of secondhand skates. Apparently this was not very successful either.

Is there anything that you could do to assist us in this connection? As you are no doubt aware, there is a lot more these days to purchasing skates than simply having the money available, especially when about 200 pairs are required.

Mr. Kapusianyk's letter would be amusing, if the matter was not so terribly serious. Please note that part which states:

"The school has no organization whatsoever. Nobody seems to have any authority to say yes or no to anything. I have been going ahead partly on my own and partly under Mr. Jones with very little help from Mr. Fisher."

I have no doubt that some of the statements in Mr. Kapusianyk's letter are very near to reports on similar matters relating to that school submitted by Mr. Clark. If you have had a chance to talk to Mr. Clark since he visited the Lac la Ronge School perhaps he could tell you more than...
tell you more than he would tell you in a regular report. What can be done to remedy the situation is completely beyond me. I sometimes feel like recommending that the school be closed, that a new Principal be appointed, and that the whole staff be re-organized. If this is not done I am afraid this school will be a disgrace to all of us.

Yours very truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

B. F. Neary, Esq.,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
THE BESSBOROUGH

Saskatoon, Sask.

All Saints School,
P. A. Sask.
Nov. 26, 1948.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

Well, I've been here a week and my results are still not too good. I now fully understand your problem here, and it will exist until there are some changes made on the staff. I have now contacted all the staff, and here is what I find. The school has no organization whatsoever. Nobody seems to have any authority to say yes or not to anything. I have been going ahead partly on my own and partly under Mr. Jones, with very little help from Mr. Fisher. I can't say exactly where the trouble lies and if I could I wouldn't for other reasons where you understand. I myself have no time for organizing sports, as you can see. I am supervising 46 senior boys. This, in itself, is a full job as the supervisors handle laundry, clean up, etc. & etc. I have, however, started a recreation hall which should be functioning within a week even on a limited scale.

Regarding those skates you mentioned to me while I was talking to you. The rink should be completed this week but there isn't a pair of skates to be had.

I'll be waiting to hear from you.

Sincerely yours,

Sgd. Harry Kapusianyk.

November 30, 1948.

Major D. M. McKay,
Director of Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Major McKay:

Following my conversation with you and Colonel Neary on Tuesday last November 23rd, I am putting in writing the matters we discussed; and I am listing them in the following order.

1. St. Albert's School, Prince Albert.
   I first of all made application for the cheque due in lieu of rent of the last half of 1948. We also discussed the renewal of the lease on this school which expires at the end of this year. Both the time period of the lease and the new rate of rental were left with the Department to decide; and you were to advise me of your decision.

We also discussed the future of this school and mentioned two possibilities. First, the possible purchase of this building by the Department; and second the use of this school as a future High School for Indian children here in the West.

2. Residential School at Onion Lake.
   From our conversation together, my understanding is that the question of the rebuilding of this school was under consideration by the Department; also that the building of this school was linked up with the building of day schools in the Onion Lake vicinity.

3. Residential School at Lac la Ronge.
   I understood from our conversation that estimates had been passed this year for the building of a combined dormitory-school unit in consultation with the Government of the Province of Saskatchewan. I also understood that you were awaiting the return of your Mr. Clark from this area to ascertain further particulars; and also looking forward to an interview with the Minister of Education for the Province of Saskatchewan. You will recall my concern that in the event of the education of these Indian children at Lac la Ronge being placed in the hands of the Provincial Government, I should have the assurance that the teachers appointed would be of our faith.
4. Day School at Loon Lake.

My understanding was that provision for the erection of this day school was being made in the estimates for 1949; and that it is definitely expected that this school will be actually built next summer.

5. Day School at Chetek.

The cost of erecting this school was in the estimates for 1948 and this amount will be re-voted this session. It is to be hoped that this school will be built next summer.

6. New Schools at Red Earth and Shoal Lake.

I understood from our conversation that the erection of new schools at these two points will be investigated. I pointed out to you the needs in these two places and I sincerely hope that something will be done for these Indians.

7. I also discussed with you the very vexed question of supplies not being forwarded to the schools, stating how frustrating this was to the school teachers; and how difficult it was for the children to do their lessons without the proper equipment. I understood that this matter was already causing you considerable concern and that we could look for great improvement immediately.

Thank you so much for giving me your time and counsel and I do want to assure you of my desire to help in every way possible in the education of our Indian children.

With kindest regards,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Right Reverend Henry D. Martin, D.D.,

Dear Bishop Martin:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of recent date with regard to the various matters discussed at our recent meeting in my office.

With regard to the Onion Lake Residential School, presently being operated in the St. Alban's College building in Prince Albert, you will shortly be receiving a separate letter from us concerning the future use of this building. Arrangements are being made to forward you, in the near future, a cheque covering the lease rent for the last half of 1948.

Mr. Clark will shortly be returning from northern Manitoba and we will then be in a position to consider his report with regard to educational facilities in northern Saskatchewan. We have recently had some correspondence with the Minister of Education for the Province of Saskatchewan in this regard.

As I advised you, we have included amounts in our next year's Estimates for the erection of day schools at Loon Lake and Chitek Lake.

We are also investigating the requirements for schools at Red Earth and Shoal Lake.

With regard to school supplies, I feel certain that all outstanding requisitions have now been forwarded if stocks have been obtained from the publishers. There are still certain books which are not being printed in large quantities and, as a result, we are only able to ship out limited quantities of these particular texts.

In conclusion, may I extend my thanks for the
courtesy of your visit and hope that we will be able to have other such meetings to discuss common educational and welfare problems.

Acting Director.

Re: St. Alban's College, Battleford, Sask.

Dear Bishop Martin:

You will recall our recent discussion with regard to the renewal of the lease on the above building. In reviewing our files, I find that Mr. Hoey wrote you as follows on December 23, 1943:

"I have noticed Your Lordship's reference to taxes, and the city levy appears to me to be very reasonable. Would it be acceptable to the Diocese to spend a minimum of $2,000.00 on the school, in lieu of rent, for the year 1944 and allowed you the sum of $2,000.00 annually for the next 4 years, on the understanding that any repairs that might be necessary would be undertaken either by the Diocese or by the Principal and that the taxes also would be paid by the Diocese? If this allowance is acceptable to you, it might be advisable to submit a voucher for one half the amount semi-annually."

I understand that this lease was to run for the period of five calendar years and that it will expire on December 31, 1948.

In view of increased costs of repairs and general rental rises, I would like to suggest that the amount of $2,500.00 per year be considered as the amount of the new lease on this building for the next five years. I would also like to suggest, in view of the possibility of the Department purchasing the building, that the lease be subject to cancellation by either party after one year's notice.

May I, in closing, express my appreciation for the courtesy of your recent visit and hope that we may again have an opportunity of discussing mutual problems with regard to Indian welfare and education in the near future.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Healy,
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6320, file 658-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
To be returned to Col. Neary with comments.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Attention of Colonel Neary

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 9th instant, File 658-1 (E), enclosing draft letter which it is intended to send to Bishop Martin regarding the rental of the building at Prince Albert now being used as St. Alban's Indian Residential School.

I am quite agreeable with the suggestions made in the letter, with the exception of the possibility of the Department purchasing the building. I had not heard that this was being considered, but I may say that the building should be very thoroughly examined by a well qualified person, as I have no doubt it would be, before a decision is made.

I believe that the building is unsuitable, and would require an enormous amount of re-arranging of the interior before it could be made suitable. Of course this is reasonable if the purchase price was low enough.

In the meantime, when considering the purchase of the building, a possible cost of $50,000.00 to prepare it for use, plus a considerable reduction in the dormitory space to have the dormitories as they should be, must be kept in mind.

The draft letter is returned herewith.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
December 17, 1948.

Colonel B.F. Neary  
Supt. of Education  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Dept. Mines & Resources  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Recently while in Prince Albert I had a conversation with Bishop Martin and the matter of renewal of the St. Alban's lease came up for discussion. The Bishop asked me if I'd ask that the Indian Affairs Branch decision on the new rental rate could be given him in the near future. I fully meant to tell you about this when I visited you but other matters drove it from my mind.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook

Superintendent

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Anglican Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended March 31st, 1943.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return, the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, puging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in quarter for all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. Where, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils (or which grant is allowed).

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and determined by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names extend be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered in the Return, ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance into the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
