PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return, is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The annual per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Sir,

In answer to yours No. 99 of the 28th January, I beg to state in regard to your Department assisting in the building of chimney and painting the school house, that the mission and myself personally have expended over $100 on the building already and that it was never thought or understood that the mission should build chimneys or paint the building at their own expense. In fact these things were not thought of sooner about till after the erection of the building, and then all saw the great necessity for both chimneys and paint in order to protect the building from fire and weather and to save both parties from danger and loss as well as to secure the greater health of the school children. For these reasons I offered to do all the necessary labour if the Department furnished the material, which I...
This is all that could be expected of the mission.

Re not sending in names of children to be carried off the 72c. School say nothing as it is easily rectified now by the action of your Department in kindly making the offer they do in regard to the first two quarters, and I send you the names of some whom we wish and expect to be carriers of said grant.

Re agreeing to adopting at our effort etc., a glance at the names of the children on the Register, and the exact attendance of the children will bear me out, and I am sure you can bear me out when I say that it was no lack of effort on my part to retain those we had or to get new ones when these left that caused the deficiency.

I am glad to know that you will investigate it, as I believe new and increased forces have been given you in the matter.

Below are names of children at present expected to be carriers of the 72c. grant:

Boys 66
1. Charlie Quinney
3. Alex. Gut
4. George Marshall

Girls 57
1. Maria Murray
2. Minnie Paired
3. Maria Crookshank
Ellen Singer
We cannot give the names of all but give those we have respect to get and hope yet to obtain the full number allowed by your Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6321, file 658-5, part 1)
Sir,

In reply to your letter no. 31 D. of the 17th January '95, Re Protestant School, Reference marginal note I beg to forward enclosed a letter from Inspector Mcgibbney Repub that he and the mission had expended on this school over $100.00 on the school building. To the Department I rather think Mr. Matheson has valued his services very highly.

The approximate cost of material for chimney and painting would be $100.00. The building would certainly be improved by a little paint and a chimney. There were no promises made at the time of erecting this school, that the Department should go to any further expense which Mr. Matheson's letter brought out. It appears to me that Mr. Matheson is asking for this as an extra appropriation from the Department.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(Signed) George Mann
Indian Agent

I have the honour to report on the Church of England Boarding School of this Agency, as to fire escapes etc.

1. Study. The stove stands on a tile pan. Pipe passes through partition. The ventilator into adjoining room. Thence through floor. The ventilator into brick chimney.

2. Indian Room. Stove sits on bare floor. Pipe passes through partition. Good pipe. Thence connected by a T pipe from study in adjoining room.

3. Dining Room. Stove on tile pan. Pipe passes through partition. Good pipe. Thence connected by a T pipe from study in adjoining room.

4. Kitchen. Cooking stove on bare floor. Pipe passes through the ventilator in floor above. Thence through attic floor.

The Indian Commissioner Regina

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6321, file 658-5, part 1)

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
and parallel with roof to the outlet on roof.

There is a ladder from upper floor to attic.

Indian Children's Dormitory Room. Door on face of building. Pipe passes through the safe in ceiling. Thence through girls dormitory and attic, to the outlet, in connection with water pipe.

School Room. Door set on face floor. Pipe passes through the safe in ceiling. Thence to room above the sleeping room. No way of escape from this room, only by stairs to school room, thence entry door.

Girls Dormitory. Escape by door to veranda, thence by ladder to ground, besides the inside stairway.

Private Sleeping Apartments in main building. Escape by door onto veranda, thence by ladder to ground.

No ladders on roof.

No facilities for strong water in case of fire.

There is a good well on premises.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

Quinn Lake, Oct. 12th 1896

J. R. MacTavish

Dear Mr. Reid,

After the very kind and liberal way in which your department has dealt with me in regard to the school on this Agency I hate to trouble you perhaps I may be asking too much but would it be possible to let me have a dozen iron bedsteads for the use of the Indian children. I am too poor to buy them myself and the price is a terrible job to keep the wooden bedsteads clean in fact almost impossible they are a constant source of annoyance trouble money above all necessity would make me trouble you in this matter.

Hoping for a favorable answer

Yours obediently,

J. R. MacTavish
OTTAWA 12th March, 1896

THIS LETTER HAS BEEN SENT

Your obedient servant,

of Indian Affairs.

Onion Lake, Sask.
April 2nd, 1900.

W. Sibbald Esq.
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake.

Sir,

I wish, through you, to requisition the Dept. of Indian Affairs for three thousand feet (3000 ft. B.M.) of matched lumber for flooring and ceiling of the building erected some years ago by the Department and the Mission to be used as a school for Indian children on this reserve. The flooring is about entirely worn out, and there never was any ceiling put in, as I always was too busy and too poor to put it in. The building needs these repairs badly.

When the building was erected your Department furnished all the lumber and I did all the work, without any further expense to the Department.

This arrangement still holds good so far as I am concerned, i.e. I will put in the floor and ceiling at my own expense if they furnish the material.

Yours obediently,

(sgd) J.R. Matheson,
Principal Onion Lake Pt.Bdg.School.
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose a copy of a letter from the Principal of the Church of England Boarding School at Onion Lake, which speaks for itself, and beg to recommend that the sum of $75.00 be contributed towards re-flooring and ceiling the building. Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

September 26th, 1923.

L. Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake Agency,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir:

As we have no means of catching soft water which is so essential for the working of our Institution where so much laundry work is done, I herewith ask the Department to bear the cost of the following Eavetoughing, viz:

460 ft. of toughing @ 22¢ per ft. .... $101.20
75 ft. of Conductor piping @ 22¢ per ft. 16.50
30 Elbows @ 35¢ each 10.50
5 - 150 gal. tanks @ $10.00 each ... 55.00

$183.20

I would further draw your attention to the fact that as these buildings are without Eavetoughing, there is no way of stopping the basements from being flooded during the wet seasons, or preventing the foundations rotting out; but, apart from the preventive measure the water itself is so essential.

Therefore, I would ask that the Department supply us with the above.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
principal.
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a letter received from the Rev. H. Ellis, principal of the Onion Lake (C., of E.) Boarding School, in which he asks the Department to bear the cost of equipping the school buildings with eavestroughing at a cost of approximately $183.20.

These buildings have never been equipped with eavestroughing and they are badly needed. I would ask the Department to authorize the expenditure if it can see its way to do so.

I should add that the figures given by Mr. Ellis include skilled labour. Unskilled labour would be furnished by the mission staff.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

Residential School, in which he requests that the Department bear the expense of equipping the school building with eavestroughing, and submitting an estimate of the cost of the material required for the purpose.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of this expenditure. You should arrange for the purchase of the material as mentioned by the Principal. If possible, competitive prices should be obtained, and the material purchased from the firm quoting the lowest price. Besides the material for the eavestroughing, you may purchase and have supplied 5 - 150 gallon tanks. The total cost should not exceed the estimate submitted by the Principal, viz: $183.20. It is expected that the labour in having the eavestroughing installed will be done by the school authorities without any expense to this Department. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of the material.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I have been instructed by our Indian and Eskimo Commission to ask the Department to bear the cost in having the furnace at the school repaired, which requires four new tubes over the fire box which are burnt out, thus preventing the heat from rising; a damper and rod and minor repairs to the cold air pipes.

Not knowing the price of these repairs which have to be secured from the manufacturers and the time it will take to adjust these repairs, I am at present unable to give an estimate of the cost.

For the past two years local experience has been secured to adjust these matters which has not been satisfactory; therefore I would ask that an experienced furnace man be secured to make the said repairs.

Yours truly,

EXHIBITARY NOTES ON REQUIREMENT

1. ONION LAKE. NEW AND ENLARGED MAIN SCHOOL BUILDING, WITH OUT-BUILDINGS, LAND, ETC., OR ANOTHER SITE, TO TAKE THE PLACE OF THOSE OCCUPIED AT PRESENT.

Part I.

(a) The present buildings are old, unsafe, antiquated in design, and incapable in every way of accommodating the number of children awaiting admission.

(b) The site which they occupy on the seepage side of a slough renders the basement of both buildings liable to flooding, a condition which has already existed, and is, in consequence, unhealthy.

(c) The land attached to the School at present is inadequate and unsuitable for extensive farming operations.

(d) No out-buildings of any consequence such as a stock-barn, granary, poultry-house, piggery, implement-shed, etc., have ever existed at this School.

Part II.

It is suggested:

(a) That a new site be selected during the winter or early in the spring, by representatives of the Department and the Society.

(b) That the new main School building should have a capacity of enrolling not less than 100 pupils.

(c) That the out-buildings mentioned under sub-section (d) above should be provided.

(d) That not less than one section of land should be attached to the new Institution.

(e) That provision be made in the estimates for 1924 for providing the School with a good strain of milking cows, not less than fifteen in number, 100 hens, and a couple of pigs.

(f) That these requirements be given precedence over all others included in the list on page 2 of this docket.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, No.115-1-5, informing me of the intention of the Department to erect a new building for the Onion Lake (C.of H.) Indian Residential School; and asking for a recommendation as to the number of pupils that should be provided for.

This school has always, in a large measure, been recruited from outside Agencies and whilst I cannot write positively with respect to this, I believe that during the last few years recruiting from these outside Agencies has been restricted to the number that the school could accommodate, and that many more pupils could have been obtained if the school had been able to take them.

There are at present 42 children on the roll at the school, 25 boys and 17 girls; this number is made up of children belonging to the following Agencies -

| Agency            | Number |
|-------------------|--------|
| Onion Lake Agency | 19     |
| Battleford        | 4      |
| Carlton           | 8      |
| Saddle Lake       | 11     |

Of the above, eight Saddle Lake children are being transferred to the Edmonton Indian Residential School, and their places are being taken by eight more children from this Agency, which will leave the total the same, i.e. 42, but made up as follows -

| Agency            | Number |
|-------------------|--------|
| Onion Lake Agency | 27     |
| Battleford        | 4      |
| Carlton           | 8      |
| Saddle Lake       | 3      |

This number should easily be increased to 50 with recruits from this Agency, and in speaking over the probabilities of recruits from other Agencies with the Rev. M.Ellis, the principal, he informed me that he felt sure he would have no difficulty in making this number up to 80 from those sources; therefore 80 is the number we are both agreed the Department should be asked to provide for in the new school.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to your letter of the 17th April I notice an item of $40,000 for the erection of a residential school for the Church of England. You are of course aware that the proposition is to change the site of this new school some miles away from the present school. This means that provision will have to be made for a residence for the Principal, as it will be impossible to erect a school for $40,000 that will provide accommodation for him in the school, especially in view of the fact that there is a staff of four or five and the principal has four or five children. You could not begin to consider having the Principal living in the school proper. I would suggest that $4500.00 be arranged for in some way, to erect this Principal's residence.

No provision, you will notice, has been made for the erection of stabling. This is essential.

In your letter you also drew my attention to the fact that the Church authorities have requested you to consider the erection of the school at Lac Sioux instead of Onion Lake. I am satisfied that conditions could not be worse than they are at Onion Lake, and the Department should not consider, for one minute, the substituting of the money for a school at Lac Sioux. Even if this were needed, it could be put off for one year. The school at Onion Lake has suffered untold inconvenience for many years. It is insanitary, damp and is just hanging together. I am glad that you are not able to agree to this change.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

D.C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 9, 1924.

Dear Canon Gould:

Considerable thought has been given to the subject matter of your letter of March 14th. The Department considers that conditions at the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School will allow no postponement to building operations and I wish to urge you to agree to the programme which was outlined in our Estimates for this fiscal year.

Provision for a new school, to be conducted by the M. S. C. O. in the Lac Seul area, will receive the serious consideration of the Honourable the Superintendent General when our plans for next year are being discussed. I trust that $40,000 will be available towards the buildings for the Onion Lake Institution. Next year it may be possible to complete and furnish the buildings, to erect a principal's residence and the necessary outbuildings.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.C.L.,
General Secretary, M. S. C. O.,
604 Jarvis St.,
Toronto, Ont.
Ottawa, May 9, 1924.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your No. 309-11A of the 3rd instant, with reference to the amount in our Estimates for the new Church of England Indian Residential School at Onion Lake. I wish to inform you that the $40,000 which will likely be provided is for the purpose of making a start on the main building which will accommodate 75 or 80 pupils. Next year I trust the Department can make provision for the completion and equipping of the buildings, for a principal's residence and for the necessary outbuildings. The activity could be transferred to the new building and farm in the fall of 1925. I note your recommendation that the Onion Lake building programme should proceed and that the appropriation be not diverted for a school in the Lac Seul area.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Memorandum:

Dr. Scott.

I should be pleased if you would decide concerning the accommodation in the new Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School. Commissioner Graham thinks we should make provision for 75 children. The Principal and the Agent recommend a pupilage of 80. Inasmuch as the Anglican Church are not pressing for a Central Saskatchewan school because of the new building at Onion Lake, I believe we should provide accommodation for some children from the Carlton and Duck Lake agencies. The Principal and the Agent have studied the question carefully and I wish to recommend a pupilage of 80.

Supt. of Indian Education.
June 4, 1924.

Memorandum:

Mr. Orr,

Dr. Scott asked me to speak to you concerning commencing the new building for the Onion Lake C. of E. Residential School. He wishes the work undertaken as soon as possible. The following information concerning the site is contained in a telegram from Dr. Westgate (File 115-1-9): It is situated on the shore of Long Lake; has an altitude of 100 ft. above lake level, with excellent drainage. He recommends capacity for 80 children.

I wish to draw to your attention that the road from Lloydminster north to this site (35 to 40 miles) is up and down hill and freighting facilities will be bad.

June 7, 1924.

Dear Sir:

I am sending you today under separate cover blue print copy of a sketch plan which has been prepared for the proposed new Onion Lake School, and I would ask you to kindly look over the same and return it to me at the earliest possible date with your comments.

As the new school will be located a great distance from the railway it is proposed to erect it of frame construction on a concrete foundation. Every care, however, will be taken to see that the building is warmly built. It will be heated by a low pressure steam system of heating.

The well and pumping machinery should be located in the room marked lighting plant, pump, etc., on the basement plan. By locating the well so that it will come in this room, it will be possible to utilize one gasoline engine for the pumping of water, generating electric current required for lighting the building, and the operating of laundry machinery. This proves a most economical installation.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.
June 7, 1924.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have your telegram of the 4th instant with reference to the new Onion Lake School, and I have wired Indian Agent Turner the necessary information for the locating of the well.

I am sending you today, under separate cover, blue print copy of a sketch plan which has been prepared for the proposed new Onion Lake School, and I would be glad if you would look this sketch over and return it to me. You will observe that accommodation has been provided for eighty pupils.

As the new School will be located thirty miles from the nearest railway station and in hauling materials it will be necessary to ferry across the North Saskatchewan River, the style of the building will necessarily have to be of frame construction on a concrete foundation. Every care will be exercised in the preparation of the specifications to see that the school is warmly built. It will be heated by a low pressure steam system of heating. The level of the basement floor will be four feet below grade, and with a ten foot ceiling ample light and ventilation will be provided for this entire floor. The boiler room, of course, will be four feet lower than the rest of the basement, in order to provide a gravity system of steam heating.

Please return the sketch at your earliest convenience, with your comments in order that the plans and specifications may be completed.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
41-63 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

Plans for new C.of E.School at - Onion Lake.

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant, No.116-1-5, relative to the proposed new Onion Lake School, I beg to state that a number of the members of our Commission have examined the blue print sketches which you so kindly forwarded, and which are being returned herewith.

The members of the Commission who have examined the sketches have desired me to convey to you an expression of their appreciation of the care which has so obviously been taken to make this institution as comfortable and convenient as could well be managed for an institution so remotely situated from railway facilities. While expressing their approval of the plans in general, they requested me to incorporate in my reply to your letter a few suggestions concerning certain requirements which, although not indicated in the sketches, they have no doubt the architect may, in his own mind, already have arranged to supply. They are as follows:

1. Basement Plan.

(a) Dairy Room.
(b) A Coal bin in or near the boiler room.
(c) Doors leading to the outside from the Recreation rooms.
(d) They observed that the food from the staff dining room must apparently be carried through the Pupils' dining room, but appreciate the Architect's difficulty in altering them.
2. Ground Floor.

(a) That there should be a door leading to the outside from the Chapel, preferably on the right hand side of the entrance from the passage.

(b) As the Chapel, so called, will probably have to be used as an Assembly Room as well as for religious services, they were of the opinion that the room could be made to serve this dual purpose if one end of the Chapel were screened off with folding doors to serve as a Sanctuary.

(c) As no Indian room, so called, appears to have been provided, they suggest that one of the staff bed-rooms at the front end of the passage be set apart for this purpose.

3. The First Floor.

The centre room in the front might be fitted up with shelves as a library and reading room for the children.

4. The Second Floor.

(a) Toilet and closets to be added to the dormitories and bedrooms.

As no front elevation accompanied the sketches, the members were unable to ascertain the use which was to be made of the spaces above the boys' and girls' dormitories. They presumed that it was your intention that the elevation of the ends of the building would cease at the top of the boys' and girls' dormitories and be covered with the temporary roof in order that the elevation of those ends might be extended to the same height, should necessity arise, as the roof of the second floor. If they are right in this opinion, they wondered if it would not be better to have the walls around the spaces referred to extended upwards to the same elevation as the central part of the second floor when the building operations are in progress, rather than have this extension made at a subsequent date.

As you state in your letter that the building must be of frame construction on a concrete foundation, it was also suggested that the thickness of the foundation should project sufficiently to admit of having the building brick veneered, should this, at any future date be found necessary.

The above suggestions I beg to commend to your sympathetic consideration, and remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

TBK/W.K. Field Sec.M.S.3C.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with which you forwarded me blue print copy of a sketch plan of the proposed new Onion Lake School.

I have looked this plan over very carefully and it appears to me, on general lines, to admirably meet the requirements. There are one or two small changes, however, which I would suggest be made.

Basement Plan

It is a long distance from the kitchen to the staff dining room, and the food for the staff would have to be carried through pupils dining room in full view of the pupils. Would not an improvement be made by closing opening which I have marked A, making one at B and putting counter at C.

First Floor Plan

In the infirmary quarters on this floor only one doorway is shown leading to the corridor, and this doorway is placed as far as possible from the stairs. Would it not be much safer if additional doors were put in at points which I have marked X. These extra doors would be quite close to the stairs and would be an aid to egress from that part of the building in case of fire.

General

It is noticeable that no provision has been made for open air sleeping porches for the pupils. I would suggest that these be put in on the first floor as outlined by me in red pencil. The centre porch could be used by infirmary patients.
patients and would also serve to effectively cut off all communication between the boys and girls porches. The second floor does not lend itself so readily to the placing of sleeping porches, but even here some small provision of the kind could be made. This I have marked also with red pencil. These porches could be supported by pillars from the ground floor.

The blue prints are being returned you by concurrent mail, under separate cover, and I hope that my comments upon them will be found of some little assistance in making the final plans.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

P. S. I should mention that arrangements have been made for boring a well which will be situated in a suitable place to be covered by room marked lighting plant, pump, etc. This work will be commenced in the course of the next three days.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.
Deputy Superintendent General,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
June 24, 1924.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have your letter of the 17th returning sketch plans for the proposed new Onion Lake School, and I note your comments on same. With reference to your suggestions I would say as follows:

1. Basement Plan:
   (a) We will try and arrange to provide a dairy room.
   (b) Coal bin: Will you please advise me if it the intention to use coal or wood. If coal is required a bin will be provided.
   (c) Doors will be provided in the recreation rooms.
   (d) By placing a door in the passage leading to the scullery it will be possible to serve the staff dining room without passing through the pupils dining room.

2. Ground Floor:
   (a) Outside door will be provided to chapel.
   (b) Folding doors can be arranged.

3. Second Floor:
   (a) Toilets and closets will be provided.

With reference to your remarks regarding the space over the dormitories, I would say that there will not be sufficient room over these dormitories under the roof to provide additional accommodation. The rooms in the centre portion of the building will only be nine feet high, as they are principally occupied by the staff, but the end portions of the building will necessarily have to be eleven feet as they include the class rooms and dormitories. This will make it possible to provide dormitories on the top floor in the centre portion as shown on the sketch plan.

The foundation will be so planned that the building can be brick veneered if it is so desired at some future date.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
41-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott.

Plans and specifications have been prepared for the proposed new Church of England School on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, Sask. In planning this building it has been necessary to keep in mind the site for the building which is located on the Onion Lake Reserve, approximately 35 miles from a railway station. The building, as planned, is of frame construction on a concrete foundation, with a low pressure steam system of heating. In the specifications for the building care has been exercised in providing only what is absolutely necessary for the operating of the school. Everything is included in the plans and specifications with the exception of the water supply and sewerage system. It is impossible to include these items as we have not sufficient detailed information in order to prepare the necessary plans and specifications.

It is rather difficult, owing to the location, as all materials have to be transported a distance of 35 miles and ferried across the river, to arrive at an accurate estimate of the cost, but I am of the opinion that the building can be built for approximately $75,000. The plans have been approved by Doctor Westgate and Canon Gould. Accommodation is provided for 80 pupils.

Will you please advise me the newspapers in which advertisements may be inserted, inviting tenders for this building. I beg to submit for your approval that we advertise in Edmonton, Calgary and Battleford.

ARCHITECT.
Memorandum,-

Hon. Charles Stewart.

July 10, 1924.

I beg to send herewith a memorandum from the Architect of the Department, with reference to the proposed new Church of England school at Onion Lake, Sask. This memorandum is intended to show that your instructions have been followed with reference to the style of building, and the economies practised in designing it.

I shall be glad to receive the names of the papers in Edmonton, Calgary and Battleford in which we are to advertise.

In a day or two I will be sending you a like memorandum with reference to the Roman Catholic boarding school at McIntosh, Ont. These two buildings and the wing to the new building at Kamloops will finish our contract work for this year.

Deputy Superintendent General;

Dear Mr. Scott:

In reply to the question raised in your letter of the 24th ultimo (No. 115-1-54) as to whether coal or wood would be burnt in the furnace in the new Onion Lake School, I beg to say that until the Turtleford to S. Paul de Metis Railway has been completed wood will be used on account of the prohibitive cost of hauling coal. Once the railway has been completed coal will be used.

I am of the opinion that if a furnace with interchangeable grates could be procured this would be the best kind to have installed.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Calgary is the largest city in Alberta, and between Winnipeg and Vancouver.

Calgary has the largest railway shops on the continent used exclusively for repairs.

Calgary is a large flour milling point, and another mill of 5,000 bbls. capacity is under construction.

Calgary's various industrial plants employ over 3,000 people, with annual pay rolls exceeding $4,000,000.

Calgary is the centre of the best beef raising and ranching district, and the headquarters of the live stock industry of Alberta.

Calgary is an important wholesale and jobbing point and the headquarters of many commercial travellers, many of whom cover Saskatchewan and British Columbia as well as Alberta.

Calgary is the headquarters of many financial institutions operating in Western Canada.

Calgary is the centre of a rich agricultural district of 25 million bushels of wheat produced in 1923 in the territory approximately 100 miles around Calgary.

Coal shipped from mines within 100 miles of Calgary amounted to 1,200,000 tons in 1923.

The only known helium gas supply in the British Empire is located near Calgary.

Calgary Stampede and Exhibition, July 7th to 12th, 1924. A wonderful show, living pictures of early pioneer life, and the best sport events known to the Frontier West.

Sirs:

August 15th, 194.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

We notice you are calling for tenders for the Onion Lake School, to be closed on the 20th. We got in touch with your Mr. Graham, Indian Commissioner at Regina, and he suggests that we write you direct.

We would be glad to have you advise us who gets this contract, so that we can get in touch with them for any material that they may be requiring.

Thanking you in anticipation, we are

Yours truly,

SASKATOON HARDWARE CO. LTD.

[Signature]

J. L. S. Hutchinson

TENDERS WANTED

SEALED TENDERS addressed to the undersigned and endorsed on the outside Tender for Indian Residential School - Ontario, will be received at the office of the undersigned up to noon of the 25th day of August, 1924, for the erection of the above mentioned building.

Plans and specifications may be seen at the Post Office at Edmonton and Barrhead, at the Calgary Builders Exchange, at the Department of Indian Affairs at Okotoks, and at the Department of Finance at Calgary.

Each tender must be accompanied by an unconditional acceptance by the Bank of Canada for ten per cent of the amount tendered, payable in Canada at the order of the undersigned. (War Bonds of the Dominion or Provincial Railways will also be accepted.) Acceptance by cheque or postal order if required to make up an odd amount, but the undersigned reserves the right to reject any tender which is not upon or fail to complete the work contract.

The lowest or any tender not necessarily accepted.

DUNCAN C. SCOTT
Deputy Superintendent General of
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, July 15, 1924.

TENDERS WANTED

SEALED TENDERS addressed to the undersigned, endorsed on the envelope "Tender for Indian Agency Building, Onion Lake, Sask." will be received up to noon of the 28th day of July, 1924, for the erection of the above mentioned building.

Payment may be made by money order at the Post Office at Edmonton and Battleford, at the Calgary Builders' Exchange, at the office of the Department of Indian Affairs at Onion Lake, and at the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

Enclosed therewith shall be attached an accepted cheque on a chartered bank of Canada, payable in full amount of the tender, payable to the order of the undersigned.

(Warn: Canadian Dominion or Canadian National Railway Bonds will also be accepted as security, or Bonds and cheque if required to make up the difference between the amount tendered and the amount of the Bond.)

The lowest tender will be accepted, but tenders will be rejected if the person or persons tendering declare their entire inability to, when called upon to do so, or fail to complete the work contract for.

The lowest or any tender not necessarily accepted.

DUNCAN C. SCOTT,

Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa. July 19, 1924.
Sir:

I beg to report to you that as yet we have been unable to find water at the site of the Onion Lake School.

A telegram received today reports that they have drilled 100 ft. and are still going deeper.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner

MEMORANDUM:

MR. SCOTT.

With reference to my memorandum of yesterday regarding the tenders received for the proposed new Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, a tender has been received this morning from James Priel of Saskatoon amounting to $58,500.00.

This is the lowest tender received. He has submitted with his tender the required deposit security.

[Signature]

ARCHITECT.
Ottawa, August 26, 1924.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned begs to report that, it having been decided to erect a new Indian residential school at Onion Lake in the province of Saskatchewan, tenders were called for, receivable up to noon of the 25th day of August, 1924, and the following were received:

- Permanent Construction Co., Edmonton, $73,900.00
- A. W. Cassidy & Co. Ltd., Saskatoon, $70,457.00
- S. Brown, Winnipeg, $66,900.00
- Smith Bros. & Wilson, Regina, $65,440.00
- Wilson & Wilson, Ltd., Regina, $64,900.00
- Poole Construction Co., Regina, $64,900.00
- Baird Construction Co. Ltd., Calgary, $64,527.00
- The Bennett & White Const. Co., Calgary, $64,167.00
- Claydon Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, $63,927.00
- James Friel, Saskatoon, $60,500.00

The undersigned would recommend, pursuant to the requirements of Sub-section 2 of Section 36 of the Public Works Act, that the contract be awarded to the lowest tenderer, Mr. James Friel, for the amount of his tender as above cited, namely, $60,500.00, the same being reported by the architect of the department as a fair and reasonable price for the work, and money having been provided therefor in the Vote for Indian Education, No. 286.

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

August 25, 1924

From: F. H. Smith,
Acting Postmaster,
Edmonton, Alberta.

To: The Department of Indian Affairs,
A. F. MacKenzie, Acting Asst. Deputy Inspector, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise you that I am returning to your office today under registered cover, four blue prints, copies of the plans and specifications for the new Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, Indian Reserve, Saskatchewan. Every facility has been provided to all the firms who wished to examine such plans and specifications.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Acting Postmaster.
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Vouchers No. 74 and 75, amounting to $40.00 and $6.85, respectively, in connection with wells for the new C. of E. School at this Agency.

Mr. Stean, owner of a well boring outfit in this neighbourhood, was engaged to bore two wells on the new school site; but after boring 22 feet at one spot and 16 feet at another, he was forced to abandon the attempt owing to the sandy nature of the earth, which was so fine that it fell through the bucket before it could be lifted to the surface.

The wells are now being drilled and at this writing one hole is down over 100 feet, and the well driller has informed me that there are good indications of striking water soon.

The vouchers enclosed are for meals for Mr. Stean and for 1000 feet of well cribbing which I had to purchase in preparation for Mr. Stean. This cribbing, however, can be made good use of at the Agency.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Mr. J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

The Secretary of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ont.

Sir:

As the Government is doing some building at Onion Lake Reserve, and as they generally appoint a Clerk of Works or Supervisor, I beg leave to offer myself for the position. I was Clerk of Works in the Lloydminster Post Office when it was building. Should you see fit to choose me, I assure you that I will endeavor to discharge the duties of position to the best of my ability. If you should want references, I will be pleased to furnish same.

Yours with respect,

E. E. Miller
MEMORANDUM:

The contract for the erection of the Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, Sask. has been awarded to Mr. James Friel, Contractor, Saskatoon, who has submitted the lowest tender.

The unsuccessful tenderers' cheques may therefore be returned, and the banks notified to release the bonds.

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.
MEMORANDUM:

MR. SCOTT.

I had a personal interview this morning with Mr. Clark Reilly, Executive Secretary, Association of Canadian Building and Construction Industries, with reference to the standing of Mr. James Priel, contractor of Saskatoon, who has submitted the lowest quotation for the erection of an Indian Residential School at Onion Lake. Mr. Reilly advised me that the contractor above mentioned has successfully carried out the erection of a number of buildings in Saskatoon and other western cities, and that according to his knowledge the man is qualified to carry out work such as that tendered for.

No accurate information could be obtained as to his financial standing.

[Signature]

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.
September 4, 1924.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that your tender of $58,500.00 for the proposed Onion Lake Indian Residential School is the lowest received by the Department. The Department, however, does not feel warranted in accepting the tender or entering into a contract until a copious water supply at the site of the school is assured. This we are endeavouring to arrange and you will be communicated with further on the subject.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Deputy Superintendent General
